title: Good basic smartphone
text:
I needed a lower cost basic smartphone to replace my really old Samsung J2 smartphone that's at least 5 years old. This LG K31 smartphone is just a little larger but works just fine for my smartphone uses.....mostly text, phone calls and a few basic news/weather apps plus light photo picture taking. This phone works fine for me.
One thing I hate on this LG phone is the 3 symbols normally on the phones' bottom are absent on this phone and hard to clear all opened apps unless you look hard. Connections to the wi-fi is good and really the phone works like it should. This phone is locked for Net 10....which I have and does include a new Sim card. Battery life seems decent for this phone. It does come with a charger cord as well. I got a heavy duty armor case to protect this LG phone from accidents/falls or drops. 4 stars

title: Excellent Motorola smartphone as usual
text: I rated this Motorola e5 smartphone 5 of 5 stars. I have had other Motorola smartphones before, Moto E 1st & 2nd Gen versions and both worked very well for me and so far, this Motorola Moto e5 has been excellent for me! Easy to transfer my apps and stuff from my prior Samsung Galaxy smartphone to this Moto e5 smartphone. Screen size is around 6 inches in size and I like the larger size. The only thing my prior Samsung Galaxy phone had better than this Motorola e5 phone is photo editing.....a bit harder to do on the Moto e5, but in time I will get used to it. Pretty much has what you need to get by with making phone calls, loading up apps and so on. I inserted a 32gb micro SD card for additional storage capacity. Good built-in camera too. Really nothing serious wrong with this phone and works very good for me!

title: This could have been a great smartphone......could have been!!
text: I needed a replacement Net 10 smartphone as my old  smartphone crapped out on me finally. So I wanted a more up-to-date & larger smartphone that my carrier Net 10 can be used on & I ended up getting this RCA Q1 smartphone. I never knew RCA made smartphones also. I have a decent RCA tablet that works just fine for me. Also, I also ordered a Micro Sim card kit for the phone to be used as a Net 10 smartphone for myself for around $7.  You can use 2 micro Sim cards on this phone. Decent basic smartphone with a nice 5 or 5.5 inch clear sharp display with all the usual smart phone features on it. You can easily add your own micro SD card for additional storage space. I think the internal memory is 12 to 16 gigabytes already. Android Marshmallow version and rather speedy phone for me. It came with a rubberized case you can fit on the phone's backside. It has 2 cameras, one front and one rear side. I think it took maybe 1 to 2 hours tops to get this phone up & running and migrate the apps from the old phone to this RCA smartphone. I have or had one huge issue with this phone.....the cell phone service keeps crapping out on this phone! I can use the apps just fine, but could never make phone calls on this phone. I actually contacted Net 10 customer service by chat 4 different times to get the cellphone service portion working again on this RCA smartphone with very little luck. It would work okay one day and not the next day. I got fed up with this phone...so I transferred my phone number and Sim card to a Plum smartphone....and that one works great!! But that's a different smartphone all-together and I reviewed that Plum smartphone on another review. This RCA smartphone would have been a 5 star phone only if the cellphone part kept working instead of crapping out every other day. 2 star rating.

title: Great basic flip-type cellphone!
text: I had an old Motorola 2G flip-cellphone and it died on me and needed to replace it with a newer flip-type cellphone thru Net 10 and ended up getting this LG flip-type cellphone since Net 10 does not recognize 2G cellphones anymore. Personally, I like this LG cellphone much better than my older Motorola unit. This cellphone is very easy to use, pretty user-friendly menu system, nice ringtones available and nice musical message reminder, and simply a much better basic cellphone compared to my last Motorola unit. This is a 3G cellphone. Making a phone call is easy...flip it open and turn on the phone, dial the number and then press "send". The battery charges pretty quick. It has a built-in camera with is easy to use with typical cellphone camera quality....tho I am not sure how many megapixels this camera is. And setting up the voice mail message center on this cellphone is easy to set up. If you need a basic non-smart phone cellphone, this LG flip-type cellphone really is a good 3G cellphone to get. Caller ID information shows inside when you open up this flip phone and also on the outer lid also....just the area code & phone number....no name ID information tho.  5 stars on this cellphone simply because it does everything I need it to do without a fuss.

title: It's a ok phone
text:
It's a ok phone nothing special, it's your basic Android device that's it. The only two downsides to the phone is the battery life and sound. If it wasn't for them two things I would have giving this phone a 5 star rating. But other than that it's still a great buy nevertheless for anyone on a budget.
Just remember to carrier your charger or a battery powerbank with you at all times.

title: It's worth your money for sure
text:
For the money this phone is will worth what you pay for it. It might not be the fastest phone out there, buy for what you pay for it the device is fast enough. There just a little lag at first on a couple of apps, but once I got it set up as need to the phone does speed up some. The good thing there is a opinion on here the phone to speed up any app you're using in the settings. After you turn it on and make sure each app you want to go faster it's all good from there.
The battery life is ok, it's not the best but it will do you just fine in mean time.
The brightest could have been just a little bit better for outside use, but other than that this phone is a pretty good device.
The cameras are pretty good, the only thing I would that if the front facing camera would have had a flash on it that would made it a little bit better.
But for only $99 for this phone is still a pretty good deal nevertheless, you're getting your money worth. I will do another review in due time after I have used the phone long enough to give another opinion on it.

text: There is not enough room on the phone to download not a single app... When I put a SD card in the phone some apps will download to it... But the thing is slow that it's not even funny.. So I can do Facebook, Kik and watch YouTube videos as I am doing nothing at the haunted house but I can't even do that on this phone.. Yes I didn't expect much out of this phone but I do expect it to handle the basics like other Android phones do.. But sadly this phone can't even handle the basics as other Android phones can. So you're better off getting another Android phone then this basic touch screen phone that seems  like it was made in 2006 or 2007... This not a true Android phone so keep looking for another one beside buying this useless thing...

title: A very good cellphone wonderful screen audio and camera
text: I really like the Sony experia 5 ii.  I have used it for two weeks and I can already give my assessment of this equipment.  It is light and very thin, the body is made of glass and the metal edges make it very easy to hold and it slides easily into any pocket.  It is very slippery so I suggest you put a casing on it as soon as possible.  the volume buttons on Google assistant and camera trigger are all located on the right side of the device I don't like this because they are easily confused and you end up pressing the one you don't want to touch.  When I carry the phone in my pants pocket, if you accidentally pressed a key, the phone emits a vibration letting you know that the accidental touch protection system is activated, this I also see as a negative point because every time I feel the phone vibrate and I think that  it is a notification.  The screen is very good, it looks excellent and the colors are vibrant especially in videos and photos.  The minimum and maximum brightness are excellent in my opinion.  A very good screen that makes you enjoy multimedia content to the fullest.  The phone has a flagship processor from last year the sd 865 but does not have 5 g networks which leaves it behind other rivals.  This device opens all applications very fast and I have never lagged or frozen.  Very good connectivity wifi Bluetooth antennas everything works wonderful.  The battery lasts all day with moderate use, I am very happy in this regard.  The cameras take beautiful photos in good light conditions, nothing to envy to other flagship equipment on the market at night, they are good but I think they lack a little more detail.  I am not very passionate about shooting videos but I have no doubt that they are very good too.  Conclusions this phone is one of the best I have tried this year apart from the fact that it lacks access to 5g networks, it is a device that is very enjoyed to listen to music due to its hight audio quality, watching videos is very pleasant because of the excellent battery screen that meets  with long use and a processor and ram memory that make it fly when opening games and applications.  I highly recommend it if you like slimmer phones and smaller than most of the ones available on the market.

title: Is a tool is a phone is a awesome
text: This smartphone is designed for a specific user.  It is built sturdy and is really heavy.  The excellent screen have a quality and the colors are adequate I only wish the minimum brightness was lower.  The viewing angles are very good I expected less from this phone.  The processor and the memory ran are  efficient which allows you to do anything without delay.  The front camera is decent but not great meets its objective for occasional photos, the rear cameras are good and take clear photos.  This phone has sensors to take photos with zero light, that is, without flash.  When you take the photo from a short distance, they come out clearly despite having absolute darkness but when you try to take it with more than 10 feet the photo is completely bad.  The battery is a strong point in this equipment I have been able to use them for 4 days with intense use without having to recharge it.  This device is not to show your friends as the most beautiful phone but if you work in construction making deliveries or rescuing people this equipment is ideal.  I forget to say that you can attach a flashlight or ultraviolet light to this equipment to disinfect surfaces that in these times of pandemic will be very useful, the bad thing is that these accessories are not included in the box. This phone is water dust and drop resistent all the charging port and memory have protection rubber. In general, oukitel wp7 is more than a smartphone, it is a tool for daily use in extreme and external conditions.  I recommend it to people who are going to use it for tasks that require conditions that another phone cannot handle.

title: Amazing for $229
text:
This phone is amazing at $229. I've run it 24/7 for 6 months straight, never a problem. Battery life is long, charging is fast. Build is nice. Memory ridiculously large. It's fast. Never a glitch or stall. And it boots up fast. And I've taken some nice photos with this. Playing any multiplayer video game is lighting fast with zero lag or issues.
Negs: bluetooth connectivity issues. Glass could be stronger. The speakers better. The camera(s) & video suck in low light. (How about one really good camera instead of four!) And everytime the reorientation moves it shows an annoying info label for a few annoying seconds. I wish that were gone.
Overall, I thought this would be an emergency backup cheap Chinese knock off phone but after using it, it has become my main phone forever.

title: I Love This Phone!
text: The RAZR Flip is a really nice phone. Small, with a unique look. The battery life is decent but I understand why it's not great. I have always loved Motorola and I really wanted a RAZR for the longest time but the old RAZR's didn't really offer up all that many features. So I had to get a Samsung Blade instead. Finally I have a RAZR phone! The phone is easy to use and setup. The screen has a weird feel at certain points but you get uses to it. I understand why it has those bending points though. I really wish the upgraded RAZR 5G supported Verizon's 5G but it doesn't. So I will stick with this older version until Motorola upgrades that phone to support Verizon's 5G or they come out with the RAZR 3. The only thing I do not like about this phone is that it uses an ESIM and that it's locked to Verizon's network. So I can't simply swap a SIM and I can't use it with any other carrier. Those are the only things I think this phone fails on. Other then that, I would recommend this phone and especially Motorola.

title: Same-Old, Same-Old. Treo 600, I mean Centro....
text:
I like the Treo Centro. It runs on the very dependable Sprint CDMA/EV-DO network. But it is the same phone as the Treo 600 that came out back in 2003. Palm decided that since the 600 was such a big success, that they had no need to make any kind of effort in designing a new phone. This holds true with the Centro. This phone has the (((SAME))) hardware as the Treo 600, 650, 700, 750, ect. Just a bit more memory and a so-called updated OS. The OS might have an update number of 5.4.9, but there is zero difference in the OS. I can not tell a difference at all. This is sad seeing as they made a Lunix based OS called Cobalt years ago and it has never seen the light of day.
The Centro still has the same bugs as every Treo since the 600. Start-up time is very slow. Which is really bad when you are in need of making an important phone call, and the phone resets for no reason. Making you wait up to 60+ seconds for it to come back online. The limited RAM of 64MB's, is so much lower then most PDA's currently on the market. You can use ZLaucher to transfer programs to a memory card, but this can not be done with all software. And since the web browser uses RAM, not memory cards, you still only have 8MB's to work with in Blazer. All software must be loaded into RAM before being it can run, So prepare for the phone to reset at least once a day to get the those limited RAM resources back.
Still no WiFi, which was the complaint in 2003 and Palm has not added it yet. The Centro still has the same 312 MHz Intel XScale processor. Signal strength is still pretty strong, but voice quality is still not great when compared to every other phone I have used before.

Sprint is marketing this as an affordable PDA at $99 with a contract. But when you know that the hardware is going on 5 years old, price really doesn't make current PDA owners care a whole lot. I bought the Centro because I hated my Motorola RAZR 2 and I needed to get something better. But after using the Centro for over a month now, I see no difference what-so-ever in this PDA and the Treo 600 and 650 that I owned a few years ago. Smaller packaging, but the same phone. The Centro is a good example of what a PDA maker SHOULD NOT DO. While Motorola, Nokia, Samsung, HTC, ect have all updated their lineups with powerful PDA's, Palm has sat idly by doing nothing with their forum star power. Palm used to control a huge chuck of the PDA software market, but now Microsoft has caught up and passed PalmOS by. No new companies have used PalmOS. Let me rephrase that, NO ONE is using the PalmOS anymore; except for Palm.
So if you don't have a PDA and want an affordable one, then the Centro might be for you. If you want power, then Sprint has much better PDA's then the aged and milked-to-death Treo's.
More then likely the Centro will be the last PDA-Phone ever made by Palm. They have lost crazy amounts of market share and have been laying off employees. So who knows, maybe the Centro will be a collectors item. A PDA that has never evolved, never been fixed, never been changed in any, meaningful way.Treo

title: The reasons Why Sprint Nextel are the best!
text:
Sprint in my opinion the best wireless carrier out their. It is odd that they merged with Nextel, because they are my second favorite.

Sprint's native network reaches over 250 Million POP. That, with the roaming, their network reaches 290(Digital only phones) or 295(Digital and analog phones) people. that makes it the largest Wireless network in the USA.

You get to roam on Verizon's, ALLTEL's, ect networks for free as well.

Sprint only offers Unlimited data plans. They offer them for both their Visions and Power Visions access. Prices range from $10 to $25. $25 being the Unlimited Power Visions (EV-DO) access with all of the Sprint TV channels and some Sirius satellite radio, along with other streaming radio channels. Other content can be added, but you would need to check the list. They are always adding new things.

Sprint is the only carrier that will let you use your Smart-Device like a Treo 650 with the unlimited Handset data plans. So with Sprint you can use the Unlimited Data on your Treo 650 for $10 a month. Both Verizon and Cingular charge $45 a month for this. T-Mobile $20.

They also allow their customers to use their phones as modems, with moderate use. Other carriers either do not have this feature, or have it shut off.

Sprint has also added Free Incoming plans to their Fair & Flexible plans. These are plans that keep adding new minutes to your plan, as you go over your bucket.

this keeps you from paying 45 to 60 cents a minute in overages. Also keep in mind that other carriers charge roaming and long distance fee's on top of the overage fees. So you can be paying into the $2 dollar a minute range for going over your plan minutes. T-Mobile USA is notorious for this. You pay a fee for the overage minutes, a fee for the long distance, and a fee if roaming. T-Mobile USA's network is pretty small, so you could roaming easily.

Another thought to throw around. Is Sprint uses 1900MHz signals for their CDMA/EV-DO coverage. They are also building out their 800MHz coverage with the licenses acquired from Nextel. Since 1900MHz needs more towers to cover a given area, this allows your phone to have more tower choices to choose from.

This also increases Internet speeds, because speeds drop with distance.

So I have found Sprint's data speeds to be faster then Verizon's. And Much faster then Cingular's and T-Mobile's Internet speeds.

Sprint also uses Lockline for their replacement insurance provider. They cover Any phone on your account, purchased from Anywhere, no matter if it is New or Used. Other carriers insurance providers only cover new phones purchased from the carrier.

I could go on and on, but just take this into consideration before choosing another carrier just based on a commercial. Or the bucket of minutes they "Claim" they are going to provide you. Minutes don't mean a thing if the network is not dependable and the calls sound like crap.

Also keep in mind that Sprint uses CDMA, which is the same network technology Verizon uses. CDMA is the most efficient network technology.

Check out [...]

and

[...] for more info.

title: Palmone Treo's are the best! Sprint PCS $10 Visions access!
text:
The New-Age Treo's are the best smart devices ever made! I have used the T-Mobile Sidekick, the AT&T Motorola MPX, a Nextel Blackberry, a Samsung i600, and even an older style Treo in the form of the Treo 300. And out of every smart device I have ever used, the Treo 600 and 650 are 1000 times better then any of them!

1# The Treo's have large color screens with full keyboards, but are still small enough to fit in your pocket.

2# The battery life is insanely long! Both of the new Treo's claim four to five hours talk time, I have found even longer. I often lay in my bed at night surfing the web for hours and hours, and by the time I am ready to go to sleep, my Treo 600 and 650 still have enough battery life to go a few more rounds.

3# Because the Treo's are so popular the prices for accessories, software, add-on's, ect are Much cheaper then those for the other types of smart devices on the market. There is even talk by Palmone to start using Linux as the Palmsource software core, so there will be even more software available. And because Linux is open source, the phones will eventually be cheaper then those running the Microsoft Pocket PC. With the added bonus of the dependability of Linux!

4# Because the Treo's are of the Candy-Bar style design, they are much easier to talk on. Because there is no flip, or antenna to fumble with.

5# There is a software lancher called "ZLauncher" which has many features for your Treo's software interface. One of which allows you to see the exact level of signal strength. By using this tool you can so how much better the Treo's antenna and related components work, compared to any other phone on the market. I get a great signal with Sprint, but with Sprint and my Treo, my service is even better! I get signals with my Treo in places where my Sanyo and LG did not. In fact, I get better signal strength with my Treo, then my friends get with their phones!

6# Palmone has a patent on a new design of smart device that they are working to bring to the market. A design nothing like the designs currently available. A PDA phone that will be thinner and still able to have a large full color screen and keyboard. SO the next generation of Treo's will be even better!

The only downfall to the Palmone Treo's today, is price. That is because they are still new to the PDA phone market. Once they start making more and more phones, the prices will come down. And once they restructure their PDA manufacturing and company purpose in general, the prices will come down. I don't normally write reviews on phones, because I used to be a Die-Hard Motorola phone fan, and I guess still am. But if Palmone keeps making phones this perfect, then I will only buy their phones for the rest of my life! I can not say enough good things about these phones! Try one and see what I am talking about. Use it with Sprint PCS's $10 unlimited Visions access!

Russell

title: Warranty? What warranty?
text: I had been very happy with my Motorola A630 until the battery started losing its charge within a day, even when the phone was turned off. The friendly but incompetent customer support kept me on the phone for an average of 40 minutes for the repeated calls trying to figure out the problem. After the phone had finally been sent to their technical service center, they returned it to me that the phone was irreperable "due to customer abuse." I have done nothing to that phone that could have caused any damage (unless using it to make phone calls counts as "customer abuse"), but got the same comment, without explanation after I had sent the phone in for a second time for reevaluation. It seems that Motorola is just trying to get out of fixing or replacing the phone free of charge under warranty. You'll be fine with a Motorola phone as long as it works. After that, you're on your own.

title: Just hope that your phone never quits working
text: I had been very happy with my Motorola phone until the battery started losing its charge within a day, even when the phone was turned off. The friendly but incompetent customer support kept me on the phone for an average of 40 minutes for the repeated calls trying to figure out the problem. title: Decent Phone , Good Customer service.
text:
Over all I am satisfied with the product, even though my experience shows there are some quality problems with this phone.
I ordered one and received it, but the phone was Dead On Arrival. I talked to BLU customer service who verified it was dead, but because I purchased from amazon I had to go back to them to replace it.
BLU answered the phone quickly, and were nice knowledgeable people. Amazon gave me a return, and did ship the replacement immediately.
The second phone I received worked fine, but the charger unit was dead.. the USB cord was fine , and the phone charged fine off other chargers I have. Once again I talked to BLU customer service who immediately sent me a new charger. Again I have to say BLU customer service was pleasant to talk to, Friendly and Knowledgeable and they solved the problem. I now have a phone that works well.
So overall The phone itself I would give a 4 to due to the early quality problems, But overall I would rate the experience well, so I'll give a 5 to the Review.
On to the phone: It is what it is - an inexpensive GSM phone that has blue tooth and wireless I had to get a micro sim to fit it, but With T-Mobile that was no problem. It runs Android 9 not 10, but that is in the description and unless you need some odd app that only runs on 10 , or you are hung up on “must have the latest”, this is a good phone. The second phone has worked well now for a month, with no problems. I am impressed with the battery, a full charge can last me for two to three days.( I don't use the phone a lot, I live on a computer, not the phone.) For the cost, I feel this is a very good deal.
One comment , this comes with a case (And I like their case.) and screen protector in the box. While this is in the last photo they show for the product, It might be better to put also in the description. When you see the product on Amazon, it suggests buying a case extra. (In December when I bought mine it suggested both a case and a screen protector. ) And you do not need those.

title: Great if you have a tablet, since you won't necessarily need a smartphone.
text:
I actually purchased this to replace a Nokia Lumia 920 smartphone--one of the most powerful on the market, and imo much superior to any iPhone, hands-down.

I later bought a Nexus 7 (2013 October version) and soon realized that all the features on my smartphone were pretty much redundant. The Nexus, being an extremely powerful tablet mostly suited for gaming, has no issues at all running anything on the Android market, or on Google Play.

After that, my smartphone had no real use for the prefix part of that, and all I was really using it for was the phone part. So, obviously, it made sense to just drop it and its astonishingly high mandatory data rates and get something that did the only thing I really needed it to do: Send and receive calls, texts, and sometimes emails.

Since smartphones are becoming staggeringly expensive (especially if you're still an iPhone user, in which case you probably just go with familiarity since the phone hasn't really improved since the 4 [Siri was already on Android phones long before then, not that it was all that useful to begin with]) and also have new problems, like practically mandatory external chargers (ATT treats these as a casual given that they're happy to sell you, like it's somehow okay that the things can't even be used for one day without being recharged), abysmal battery life, poor voice quality in favor of data speeds, and basically, tons of stuff you *HAVE* to pay for that practically no one really needs. Data plans are only going up in price, and how "smart" do you really need a smartphone to be? At what point is it just a mini-computer and only secondarily a phone?

Anyway, if you're like me and just said no to the smartphone boom that made cell phone bills shoot through the damned exosphere while *sacrificing* basic features older phones had (such as, say, working for the entire freaking day with normal use, and acting like having secondary chargers has always been the case), phones like these are really the way to go. Use your tablet for the tough stuff, it's far better at it, anyway. And less expensive, so long as you just use Wi-Fi for your data.

If you want a small computer that doesn't even bother acting like it's technically a phone, knock yourself out and get an expensive smartphone. If you're a little smarter than that, get a tablet (they're now far more affordable and even sub-$200 ones are more than adequate for most people--and they don't have contracts) and a phone that acts like it's really a phone. You'll save a ridiculous amount of money in the long run and end up better off than you were before even if cost wasn't the motivator. Smartphones are so battery-craving and in many practical ways no better off than before, so they're really just absurd with the advent of contract-free, inexpensive tablets.

I hope these things come back as viable options for people instead of the all-the-way-downhill iPhones of today that still dominate the market exclusively due to familiarity with the brand (it's true: Everything an iPhone has ever done has been done before on Android, bar nothing at all except the mechanism that makes it more expensive). Joy to the world when something like the Razrs come back and we go back to having practical technology instead of cool-but-pragmatically-worthless technologies on phones.

title: Pretty good price for a little android phone
text:
I upgraded from a LG 840g (which was a dumb phone, they both have the same screen size) I buy a new burner every year with 3x minutes 1200 and 1 year of service.
I looked at all the tracfone androids out there, this one had 4.4 os, and decent processing, etc. so went with this. I"m not the kind of person who blows over $100 on a cell phone. This + 1yr service was $120, a pretty good deal, since the 840 was $95 with 1 yr svc.

About the "smart phone" upgrade, meh, there are some features and apps that are cool, I can load skype and use it over wifi, texting is a lot easier/better than the last phone. They are both very close in size. My gripe is I hate google and all the crap they do half-cocked. their idea of integration is very sketchy. like signing up for spam and spying 24/7. Apps don't shut themselves off, so you have to go under settings>battery> and shut everything off manually or else they keep running... using up memory and battery.

Seeing how small this is, I would have liked a bigger phone, but low price won out. I use my ipad for apps, surfing, and media and I love it!

Coolest thing I've found so far on this phone, I can have caller ID and text messages read automatically, ha ha, I don't even have to pick it up, it just says for example, "text message from Jimmies - your pizza is ready for pickup"

Getting my contacts loaded from my MBP was a cinch: exported contacts to vcard, sent vcard via bluetooth to the phone after paring it, somehow i can't remember- found the file sent and imported into contacts. took about 5 minutes to do the whole process!

Trying to surf the web on this is a total joke. Everything is mis-sized and way too small.

gmail is crap, box full of spam, so I will only use it for password resetting stuff like that and an account at goggle play to get free apps.

FYI: PROMO CODES FOR BONUS MINUTES DON'T APPLY TO ANDROID PHONES. I even called tracfone to get the extra 250 minutes added, nope sorry! but with the triple minutes/text/data per the android phones, which comes out to be way more than 250 standard minutes on the 840, I still come out ahead.

I highly recommend going to the tracfone website and checking out the animated tutorial for this phone, covers the basics.

title: The worst phone that I had ever bought

I wont buy any other sony ericsson product ever.  At least mobile phones.  Also, sometimes the home charger does not charge my mobile.  It is really bad.

title: Simple phone, easy to set up and use.
text: I bought this phone for my mother who is hard of hearing and seeing. Easy set up, just add the sim and it was ready to go. This phone was loud enough for her to hear and the speakers were great in capturing her voice so the listener can hear her. The keys were big so she can see the buttons. The only thing that was confusing and hard to do was entering the names to the phone book. I don’t have it so I can not accurately rate battery life.  Both my father and mother like the phone. They are in their late 60’s.

title: Star i9220 an imitiation of Galaxy note 1 (Skype problem)
text:
This is a single core phone. Even if you root it(has anyone rooted this?), you cannot overclock it. The front camera is really horrible. You cannot use it for Skype if you are in a regular light room or there is not enough white light. The front camera is only 0.3 Mega Pixels and the rear camera is 7.62 Mega Pixels. Chinese are not capable in making sensitive lenses yet. The speaker phone is bad too. Also, you cannot play 1080p only 720p HD. If you decide to return it you have to pay $35 shipping to Hong Kong and three weeks after they receive the phone you'll get your money back. Remember you will not have any warranty whatsoever except the first two weeks of trying the phone.
Now the good things:
It boots very fast, Wifi is great, the phone is good in every country. I have tested it in three different countries. You have to know how to set it up in other countries but for ATT just insert the simcard.
If you want to spend this much money and want only to use only one simcard you can buy LG optimus L7(unlocked), a much better phone and the genuine phone not a Chinse knockoff. Search for it on Amazon.

title: its a great phone for the price
text: its a great phone for the price. boost mobile is a good network and gives big savings on cel service. I would buy again if I had to.

title: Great Phone
text:
Great phone touch screen works well, very responsive an accurate, nice features, ok battery life about 2 to 3 days depending on usage.
Looks great and the dual sim works great on both accounts. There can be a slight echo when talking but nothing major. I highly recommend it

title: Almost perfect but can't continue using
text:
Update. The company contacted me and offered to remedy my situation so i added another star for customer service.
This phone is practically perfect for my needs.
It has a super long battery life and the features are easy to use.
The FLIR app is fascinating and fun to play with. There are other useful "tools" such as a protractor, compass, decibel sound meter and gradienter that I like to play with also.
This phone is heavy and rugged just as described. I call it "Chunk" because its so bulky but that doesn't bother me at all. Just wanted to let others know, this is not a dainty girly phone.
I've dropped it with zero issues. I believe it can handle way more than what I can do to damage it, which says a lot.
Unfortunately, I need to move to a different phone for a couple of reasons, and I'm seriously bummed about it.
First, the phone does not stay connected to any Bluetooth device. Headphones will play for a random amount of time and just stop. I stream all day everyday and have tried different speakers along with headphones and it does the same thing with every one. This is the biggest issue I have with the phone and why I will not be able to use it anymore. I can't stop what I'm doing all day to walk back to the phone and start the program again to play in my headphones.
Second, the phone is set up in a way that my carrier, xfinity, does not support the phone. I had to get hooked in with ATT paying almost $70 a month while the other 2 phones on Xfinity are less than $100 monthly together. If I go back onto the Xfinity plan, ill only be paying $20/month more... This is also a problem because I live in a terrible signal area. Xfinity service worked so much better than the ATT does. If the phone worked with bluetooth, I would pay the extra money but I can't justify the cost when it doesn't properly stream to my devices.
I hope this helps.

title: so upgrading to the Volt was a great choice. I had looked at the S3

title: One Star
text: Does not work for oversea

title: Good enough for me
text:
When you're coming from a nightmare situation, almost anything better is good.

I am a recovering BLU Products user. After 3 years and 8 devices (only 2 of those are user-related replacements) I'm done. Their recent madness with the Life One X2 led me to search for a decent replacement, which led me here.

I knew I wouldn't find something with the same operating power as the Life One X2 (64GB memory 4GB RAM) at a similar price, but I was gonna try. The Moto's memory was enough for me. I back up all my photos to Google and I've never got to 32GB memory before, so the extra memory in my phone was just sitting there. The only thing I was gonna miss was RAM.

So yeah, it's a little noticeable, but not much. Not enough to make me want to take it back, and definitely not enough for me to go back to my life one x2. I like the design of the phone, the layout, Android 7 is awesome.

The prime ads aren't bad. I'm adding screenshots of what happens when I use the fingerprint sensor vs turning on via the power button.

Pros:
~five across apps, very nice, can fit all my apps I use regularly on one screen
~night mode: blue filtering, great for migraine sufferers
~5000mAh battery: guys, THIS is worth everything!! I'm a super heavy user and I get at least a full day of use. Hubby is a light user and can get 2 or more days without charging.

Cons:
~back door: seriously, I broke two nails and almost quit between installing SIM cards for mine and hubby's phones. If it weren't gonna damage the door I would've used a knife.
~speed: it's something I'm just gonna have to get used to. But it's not bad.
~uninstallable apps: I don't use Amazon Alexa, Goodreads, prime photos, but I can't uninstall them.

title: great mid-range phone

title: Avoid Boost Mobile like the plague!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
text:
I decided to write this review for two reasons: (1) To warn everyone about Boost Mobile, and (2) Hoping that someone might have the same problem I am having now and can provide some help.

This review concerns my whole Boost Mobile experience. Here goes!

I purchased the phone because Boost Mobile has a great $35 unlimited talk, text, and web (2.5 Gb at high-speed 4G LTE) and Hotspot capability for $5 for 1 Gb of data (in addition to the phone's allocation).

I went to the Boost Mobile website, created my account, and activated the phone. The phone appeared to work OK, but the data was only 3G. I called Boost Mobile customer service. I have to warn you... the 800 number is nothing short of voice-mail hell!! The options given only run you in a circle. You can talk to a customer service agent only if you want to "add a service." All other options are just information that never leads you to a real person.

Once you reach a customer service agent, you must be able to speak Filipino-ish. You will NOT (even if you demand it) be able to speak with a Customer Service Supervisor in the United States!! No matter how much you scream at the Filipino operator. It's not going to happen!!!

The first agent told me that the $35 plan would only provide 3G data. I told him, "According to your website, the service is 4G LTE until 2.5 Gb and then slows to 3G speeds." He told me that the site was wrong. I hung up and called another operator (wading through voice-mail hell again). This operator spoke clearer English and told me the first operator was wrong. I did all of the normal "reboot" and "refresh" crap with nothing helping the situation. I finally gave up, wiped my information, and took the phone back to the store. Oh well, another surprise was to be had. The phone can't be returned once activated! NICE!!

Since I had already paid for one month of service, I decided to "reboot" and "refresh" the phone. Still 3G!! I did notice that the phone would show five bars for 20 seconds and then zero bars with a red "x." It would cycle through this 3G, five bars, no bars with a red "x" about every minute. When out and about, the phone would do the same thing. I felt that the phone having reception and losing reception was a bit dangerous... after all, most of us have our phones for emergencies while we travel!! Finally, I found an option to switch the phone to CDMA only. This keeps service at all times and the "off and on" information mentioned above stops. Also, I had to turn the "Connection Optimizer" off in order to keep the phone from switching back to "LTE/CDMA" mode.

Remember that I mentioned that I purchased the phone for hot spot use? Well, if I log into my account, the hot spot are "grayed out." A banner near the hot spot information says "Options are grayed out because account is in restricted status." Nobody (and I mean NO ONE) at Boost Mobile can tell me what this means, why it's on my screen, and why I can't add hot spot service!!!! Apparently there is no Filipino-ish translation for "restricted status."

I have to add that I went to a local Boost Mobile store. I should have known there was a problem when I walked up to the store and noticed the bars on the windows!! :) I felt like I was stepping into a third-world country when I walked in the store! ha ha ha ha The person there told me the phone was broken and it should have been receiving 4G data. Hmmm.... Perhaps this "expert" is not really an expert at all!! He made the diagnosis with the phone in CDMA mode. I would have thought he would have checked the mode FIRST!! Oh well, who am I? Certainly no Boost Mobile LG Volt expert! :)

So, now I have a beautiful phone that can't do the two things I purchased it to do!!

I would stay away from this company. The lack of any customer service and ability to resolve problems has turned me against the company!! I could have purchased the same phone (LG Realm - 3G only) for $70 less than I paid for this phone!!!!!

You have been warned!!! :)

title: Great Low Budget Smartphone
text:
Had this phone for a little over a month now after using two different Tracfones. It is definitely a step-up from those. Bigger screen, more responsive touchscreen, better internet reception, better camer7a and video , more readily available apps. I'm absolutely loving it, and find it tough to put down at times. Doesn't have that many preloaded apps like Samsung or the IPad, but honestly don't think those can do much more than this phone. I even like the cases that are available for it.

Now a sticking point for some may be the data that is available for it now. Boost offers 3 standard option for calls, texts, and data. Calls and texts are unlimited on all 3 options far as can tell. 35$ give you 1GB of data. 45$ gets you 5GB of data. 55$ gets you a whopping 10GB of data. Didn't see any other competitors offering 10GB at the time. Appears T Mobile may have joined the party recently. Although 10GB sounds like an awful lot of data, it really isn't. Phone worked almost seamless when I had it, but once your data reaches its limit, Boost drops your speed from 4G to 3G. The phone doesn't work nearly as well at 3G, and videos won't really play at the 2G they get dropped too. I think it's important for new buyers to understand this. I think they should also understand that this phone uses up data in pretty healthy chunks. I went through 10GB in about 2 weeks, and I didn't play one video game or watch any full length movies. Pretty much convinced all data plans are a scam to get you to add more money or buy more cards. I digress though. Boost does have an option for 30$ on auto-pay that gives 2GB, which is what I'm now on. Didn't see a need to buy all that extra time that'll be gone in an instant anyway.

Despite that data issues, I still love this phone. At 3GB the phone still works pretty effectively as long as you don't do any gaming on it or stream anything longer than a few minutes. For those things, you probably do need an IPad or Samsung.

Would like to add as of June 13, 2016, Boost now offers unlimited Data for $60, with it dropping to $55 if you use the automatic payment (autopay) option. The 10GB option for $55 is now gone. $45/$40autopay still gives you 5gb. $35/$30autopay now gives you 2gb.

title: Price/performance point is OUTSTANDING!
text:
I traded up from a Pixel 3XL. Just about everything on the LG G8X is better. There is no pause when launching or using apps. A good non-productive example is with the CoC game. The loading progress line with the 3XL would pause for several seconds at about 75%. With the G8X the progress line shoots across the screen with no perceptible hesitation! All apps are noticeably quicker. The dual screen is really a novelty for me. For now, I don't use any apps that take advantage of it. However, It is a great bundle price vs. the G8X by itself. So, I see it as an investment until more dual screen apps are available. As far as size goes with the dual screen, its footprint is actually smaller than my old 3XL with its case protector. Plus, it only weighs 3 grams more than the 3XL with case. I don't notice any difference! I was concerned about the fingerprint reader from all the negative reviews. And, they were right. If you use the screen reader exactly like your old physical reader, it is terrible. That was until I noticed that the position of my thumb when training the reader was way different from how I positioned it while in use. After re-training the reader from my "use" position, the reader is very reliable. Not quite as much as my old 3XL reader which was virtually 100%, but close. I go an entire a week without a "bad" read. Let me offer some tips. Have clean hands. No big deal in these China virus days. You should already be doing this. As said before, place your thumb (or finger) in the same orientation as when it was learned. Again, no big deal since holding your phone is pretty much the same each time. And finally, do not press your thumb down hard on the screen. I don't know if this causes the print to be flattened (smeared) or if the touchscreen thinks it is responding to a navigation command, but a light touch seems to always work. The other great feature is the battery life. My 3XL's battery would often not last the full day for me. The G8X will have 60% battery left when I put it down at night. Outstanding!
So, no regrets. Awesome phone and nerdy, gadget dual screen, which I hope gets more apps. Even if it doesn't, it is still cheaper and better than phones that cost hundreds more. I bought the same phones for my daughters and they love them!

title: It's the accessories that will kill you....
text:
The Treo is a really easy phone/PDA to learn and to use. It's packed with great features, and it's is truly and all-in-one, too bad it can't pick up the laundry too. Potential buyers, just be aware of the following:

1. I could not get it to sync with my laptop with Windows 98. You need Windows 98 SE or ME or above. Solved the problem by buying a new laptop $$$.
2. If you're a woman with fingernails, you'll need the carrying case. The rounded smooth plastic buttons on the keyboard are difficult to use without the vynle cover.
3. The reception is no where nearly as clear as the digital phones. The reception from my bedroom is at best, really bad.
4. You'll spend another small sum on the protable keyboard, cradle, sync cable for travel, car recharger, a second charger and cradle for the office and memory.
5. Learn to back up your data. If your Treo crashes, you'll hear yourself letting out a gutteral scream that you didn't know was in you.
6. If you're storing pics and lots of data, you'll need more memory sooner than later.
7. Get a hands free earpeace so you can be on the phone and look at your calendar and contacts.
8. Join a support group for others who want to lynch the techies who write the manuals for these things. It'll take a couple of cups of strong coffee and an 30 minutes before you end up taking the dog out for a walk.
9. The stylus unscrews to reveal a pointy end to reset your Treo if it freezes. The Tech line is never open when your Treo gets stuck and it's making a loud clicking sound. Plus, when it freezes, you can't get the help number that is stored on your Treo. Tatoo it on your forearm, it'll be more useful.
10. There is no "OFF" button for the Treo and yes, it will freeze on you.
11. You cannot drive and use the Treo like your cell phone, you'll be risking your life and the life of every other dirver on the road if you try to type, send an email, or update a contact or calendar entry.
12. There is no spell check, so expect that most of your emails will be gibberish or unintentionally funny.
13. You can take out a second mortgage to buy the Treo and all it's accessories, but it's really worth it.

title: Very satisfied with this phone
text:
I bought this phone to replace a Moto G5 Plus. I've had it for a week now, and as a light to middle-weight phone user, I'm very satisfied. Snappy performance, plenty of RAM and storage, and a full battery charge can last me over 2 days. The rear camera is good, the action camera is great. It has NFC, it's unlocked for the US carriers, it can take an SD card. I wasn't sure if I'd be crazy about be the weird dimensions or punch-hole front camera, but I discovered that I actually really like the elongated shape and don't mind the front camera at all. It also seems to go on sale frequently. It was a really good value at $250, and nearly impossible to beat at $200.

I read some discussion on the internet about how the touchscreen seems to miss some folks' rapid finger taps, like when typing. The one I bought from Amazon in Jul 2020 doesn't have that issue with either the bare screen or with a tempered glass screen protector - it registers my touches every time. It did miss some touches with the standard new-in-box plastic screen cover in place though (the one you're supposed to remove anyway), so I would suggest if you use a screen protector, go with tempered glass.

title: A mans phone for sure!

after about 2 months of ownership and adjusting to pounding on keys again I've concluded that this is MY FAVORITE PHONE OF ALL TIME. I would compare it to a 60s muscle car 4speed stick with all modern suspension(comes with android 10) and a new big block(6ma 2 day battery life). The combo fingerprint sensor has hepatic vibration response and doubles as a home key on long touch. The scroll by keyboard feature is there(you just have turn it on). This thing is dense and heavy, feels like your holding half a brick AND I LOVE IT!
love the industrial look with the brushed aluminum as well, great phone!!!!

title: So far so good
text:
So, I've had this for about an hour now and this is all based on that initial experience. Will update if anything goes awry later, but... Setup was seamless! Just log into your google account from your old and new phone, then follow the prompts. It'll take a while for OS updates and your apps to download and install, but it does that all in the background. Came with about half a battery, so I was able to get going immediately. Honestly, with the cases off, it's maybe 30% thicker than my old Galaxy S8 with a cracked screen, which isn't a problem at all. I LOVE the color of the back. I've seen a few complaints about the included case, and well... Mine is fine! It's probably not the case I'd get, as I'd prefer something sleeker and may be buying a new one, but this one is thick, fits snugly, and it seems like it will provide outstanding protection for this phone. So far it's running quickly, I've been logging back into all of my accounts. There are probably a few utilities that aren't great or that I'll miss from my Galaxy, but the beauty of Android is that ALL of that is customizable. There are tons of alternative calling, messaging, firewall, antivirus, camera, gallery, and file manager apps on the market, which I'll be exploring in the coming weeks as I use this more, but stock Android is also very usable without tons of customization. I'll miss the NFC and Qi wireless charging that this phone doesn't have, but for a ~$100 temporary/backup phone, those aren't completely necessary.

Update: I ended up needing the NFC for my blood glucose meter, so I had to replace the phone, but I'm still using it daily. It's a great device to carry around while I'm working on projects and listening to music. Since my SIM is in my main phone, this one is basically an iPod touch. I've used it for the past 4 days straight on WIFI with Bluetooth turned on, listening to music and the battery is only now at 59%. It's a slow charge, but also lasts FOREVER on a charge! Gives me the opportunity to work on projects without distractions from my regular phone constantly buzzing to tell me about something that I "might" want to know about. Works well using Youtube and Twitter and connects to all of my stuff really reliably. It's also very lightweight and I love that the headphone jack is on top.

title: but I was annoyed enough by the limitation of stock Android that I ...
text:
tl;dr -
This phone is incredible, but I was annoyed enough by the limitation of stock Android that I returned the Amazon Prime exclusive version (on which you cannot unlock the bootloader) and bought the standard edition.

Full -
I was a cheapskate and decided to buy the Amazon Prime exclusive version to save $60. If you're okay with stock Android and you don't care about playing with settings, there's nothing wrong with that edition. Honestly, the ads on the lock screen didn't bother me. They full screen when you have no notifications, and slot in as the last notification slot if you do. Once you unlock the phone, they're gone until the next lock screen.

The only real modifications Moto has made to Android for this phone are built into a special Moto app, which allows a couple of tweaks. The main settings concern inertial gestures (which allow you to open the camera or turn on the flashlight by moving the phone in certain ways), and fingerprint gestures (which replace the intrusive software navigation bar with swiping left for back, right for recents, or tapping for home). You can also disable the obnoxious boot sound. Everything in this app is great, they did a really good job in centralizing the non-standard tweaks and making them actually useful.

The rest of the Android experience is pretty stock. The launcher is a slightly modified version of the Pixel Launcher, where they've only put a custom lock screen in and made the app drawer transparent, both of which are tasteful. All of the other settings are basic Nougat, which makes the interface very efficient. However, if you don't like the white background in all of the menus and Android apps, it can glare at you a bit, and you cannot apply themes to the whole interface without unlocking the bootloader and rooting the phone.

As far as hardware goes, the battery life is unbelievable. I've yet to see less than around half charge by the end of a day, it lasts forever. Turbo charging is also a nice feature, and lets you emergency charge your phone quickly when you only have access to power for a short period of time. No NFC, but that's pretty typical of a mid-range phone, and I don't really miss it. I'm never going to run out of RAM or storage (4GB/64GB model). The graphics processor is very zippy and keeps up with that octa-core processor nicely. I've noticed no lag under really any circumstances. The camera's nice, pretty on par with what's available in the rest of the market, and not much to be said about it. The brightness and color of the dual-tone flash comes through well on the camera, and makes for a very visible flash light. The screen is nice, good contrast in the sun, and dim enough at night that I don't blind myself. It's "only" full HD, not 4K, to give those of you who like to text with a microscope something to complain about, but for us mere mortals the resolution is perfect.

The radios are sensitive and reliable. I get LTE with decent consistency in my apartment, where my old Zenfone 2 couldn't with the same SIM. I like having dual-band WiFi, as I can finally put everything on my 5 GHz network and clear up some 2.4 GHz interference. There's no Wireless-AC, but how much are you really downloading on your phone? Bluetooth has been pretty reliable, nothing out of the ordinary.

Ultimately, the only reason I was unhappy with the particular phone I got (seriously, the ONLY reason) was the permalocked bootloader. I've now switched up to the standard version (which I only booted on stock Android long enough to toggle the developer switch for bootloader unlocking), and running AOKP, I couldn't be happier. The extra features that really make this phone nice for me were theming, the ability to tether (this is a carrier limitation for me which can be overridden with aftermarket ROMs), and manual control of whether to use LTE or 3G since I drive for work and end up in some places with weird reception. If none of these are important to you, there's no reason you'll be disatisfied with this phone. It's probably the best phone you can get in this price range, and with the cross-network compatibility, you don't have to worry about switching carriers if you move (this is rumored to also take 2 SIM cards, with one supplanting the SD card, but I've yet to try). Whatever you need from a phone, you can achieve on this hardware, and you'll be hard-pressed to find anything much better shy of the $500+ range.

title: Sticking with the Exalt
text:
Love this flip phone but lost my first one after a year's use. Don't want or need a smartphone so went looking for a replacement. Saw the Exalt II but didn't want to pay the premium for a few, albeit nice improvements. So found a source for the original Exalt. Still love this phone except that now I cannot get the clip-on armor casing I had for the first one as they discontinued it. Oh well. Still the phone I want.

edit: Aug 2018 - Last one I ordered and reviewed got wet from a large poolside splash. Put it into a bag of rice and no-go yet. Screen did dry though. May yet come back and if so I will keep it as a backup. Anyway the new phone arrived in 3 days and first thing that greeted me was a series of cards on the box informing me that Verizon was no longer activating CDMA phones as of June 2018. Another card listed a series of carriers which utilize Verizon older 3G network and would activate my phone. I still tried to activate it being an existing Verizon customer who had just lost a phone that was working fine on their network very recently. Tried online first but received standard message about CDMA phones not being supported anymore. So then I went on the web and found the only real answer to the issue. Do it on the phone using *288 and then following instructions.Worked like a charm and Verizon even backed up my data from the backup cloud. Only thing I lost was the pics since I wasn't using an SD card. Was so happy to get my new phone up and running I bought a TurtleBack leather case for it since I was always dropping my last phone which wasn't armored (see above).

title: This phone comes with a standard processor, reachable ram memory and big battery.
text:
My older phone is a LG Stylo 3 Plus. Have to change because the screen was cracked but functional. After being 2 years with the cracked screen decided to give this phone a chance. Need a little more ram room and a better looking with Stylus.

Pros> The display is a huge difference, everything looks more clear and the space is comfy for my fingers. The keyboard is more fluently to write and fast. Battery last forever. Stylus is responsive. Material are less heavy than the Note 9 but more sturdy than the Stylo 3 Plus. Screen seems more gorilla glass like than the Stylo 3 plus. Either way it needs a good case protector.

Cons> Sounds from speaker is weak. After disabling unnecessary apps the phones sometimes gets time loading. (I believe is weak processor for big software). My Stylo 3 plus is more responsive and faster.

Conclusion> If you are the type of person that doesn't neccesary needs to spend thousands for a phone. This is a good option. A person who knows how to maintain memory and looks for apps with less space. You will love this phone. Big features and processors means more space and more battery requirements. This phone comes with a standard processor, reachable ram memory and big battery.

title: Hit or miss.  Read if yours have random crash or restarts
text:
I purchased this moto G plus 5 (with Amazon ad) when it was on sale with the lightning deal. It was straight forward to migrate from an iPhone 6 and I was up and running after some setup. The phone was snappy. No issues whatsoever. The only cons I saw were the camera (slow and delayed) and smaller screen size(I prefer a bigger screen than what it is). But hey, for what I paid , it is a very capable and adequate phone.

Unfortunately, after few days of use, I started seeing Random crashes or restarts. The frequency of restarts was tolerable maybe once every other day. I noticed the restarts were getting more frequent and annoying and was debating what to do. Googled around and found this to be a common problem. I tried putting it on safe mode to troubleshoot but decided not to because I had to use some of the apps during the day.

I decided to get a replacement from Amazon and got the new phone within 2 days. I set up the new phone with exact same apps and setup and config. It's been over 3 weeks and the phone hasn't restarted ot crashed once. I'm really happy with the phone.

To summarize, these g5 plus could be hit or miss. If applicable you might want to try to exchange for another. Battery life is excellent , snappy and running Android 7.0 and more than adequate for avg or above avg users. These can't be and shouldn't be compared with top of the line Samsung or iPhone. I just wish the cameras are better and the screen size is bigger but it is something I'll willing to live with.

title: Phone calls would go silent but not drop then audio would return. (Verizon is SC)
text:
Received phone and was very impressed with the Moto Z4. But after spending an evening setting up apps and transferring data from my working iPhone 8 Plus I was very happy. Then the next day I started noticing that during calls the audio would drop out, then come back during phone calls not matter were I was located at my house. I even went as far as moving closer to a windows and even tried outside. No luck in resolving my problem. I then called Motorola and after asking them if they were experiencing problems with the Z4's and was told no. I went thru the basics (reboot the phone. make sure its up to date, and killing all apps) they had me reset the network connection. Still no luck. I read many forum posts but nothing worked. I then ran across a a forum on Motorola's site that had pages and pages of people complaining about a combination of the Snapdragon Processor and a poorly designed antenna as a probable culprit. I responded back to a text message form Motorola that I'm still experiencing problems and then responded to an email that my call was being closed. A day or so later I received a call from Motorola and informed them that I had already initiated an Amazon Return and order another brand of phone.

I honestly loved the phone, but I need a phone to make calls and the Moto Z4 didn't. I downloaded and app called Network Cell Info which display signal strength and location of the Verizon towers i was connected to. And this app showed towers disappearing and reappearing constantly which I am guessing is my problem.

I have concluded that its a combination of 2-3 bars signal and the Moto Z4's processor and antenna. If I lived in an area that was blanketed by cell towers and 5 bars I believe I would still own the Moto Z4 but because I do not I am returning the phone & case. But the screen protectors will end up in the trash.

title: Great phone, fully supported by T-Mobile, it does download recent updates, but there are some issues ...
text:
First month I was totally in love with the phone, but now I'm getting less excited. I'm sure you've heard about the good sides, so here are some not so good:

1. The geolocation apps (maps, fitness tracker) keep crashing. It's especially annoying for my fitness trackers when my running workouts are getting interrupted in the middle. This is a big reason why I need a smart phone and obviously it's a bummer.
2. No compass. I don't know if this device doesn't have compass at all or it's not good enough, but for practical purposes there is no compass. That means a few things, like if you're looking for directions (especially walking), you need to move for sometime before you can see which way you're going on the map. Also, if you want to let's say see the stars on the sky, that is not going to work either.
3. Sound quality. Definitely not as good ss other phones.

I'll probably keep the phone for some time but if I'd known about that before I would definitely not bought it.

title: Great phone at a good price!
text:
Please finish all system updates. I had signal issues until I finished all of the updates.

The phone has a C-Type charge port and an audio jack. This model comes with an amazing fast charger, but the cord is super short. The life of your internal battery can be improved if you choose to only charge it after the phone drops to 20% or lower charge.

The Moto actions are really neat! Holding phone in hand make two fast chops to turn on the flashlight. Also, you can hold the phone in your hand and twist your wrist twice quickly to open the camera app to take quick pictures. The Moto actions will work even when the phone is locked. There are other Moto actions but I only found these ones useful.

I did not like all of the added Amazon apps. I only kept Amazon Music active and disabled all of the other onboard Amazon apps.

If you are a Pokémon Go user, the game loads fast enough. However, switching between pages in the game can tend to be slow. It has yet to crash because of RAM over use.

Overall, I would recommend this phone to anyone who wants both value and performance.

title: Some issues with Quality of software and hardware, but it was affordable.
text:
I like the phone very well at first, and the battery held up well for me over the 9 months I have had the phone.
It crashes more than other phones I have owned which is annoying. This happens when using Google Maps regularly lately. The latest problem I am having is that the phone thinks that I am tapping on the touchscreen when I am not. Sometimes it stops thinking that and I can use the phone normally. Other times it is unusable. It is always the same spot on the phone, so it opens google search from my home screen and messes with me while I am trying to call or text. Since I am inside of the 1 year warranty period, I contacted BLU and will add information about their response to my review as it unfolds. I have bought a few BLU phones in the past and found that they were very good for their price. I don't think that they are quite up to Samsung or ASUS quality, but you can afford to replace them once in a while which is nice. They also have features that the other phones don't such as dual sim, external storage, etc.

Update - after 48 hours, no response to my email.
I found that there is a BLU support website. That worked much better. I had a pretty quick response and they will RMA the phone. I wouldn't have it for 2-3 weeks though, which would be tough. In the meantime, a new firmware update came out this week and it seems to have helped with some of the issues I was having with restarts, and the touchscreen hasn't glitched in a few days, so I am not going to return it at this time.

title: This is a great phone, with tons of features
text: Are you kidding me?  If you're on the fence about this phone, get off.  This is a great phone, with tons of features, and lots of good-quality, inexpensive cases available online. I love the dual cameras, and the screen is surprisingly large for a $99 phone (which is how much I paid. Bought one for my wife, too.)  I am new to Android, so there was a bit of a learning curve.  But that's not so much the phone as it is the OS.  Best part ... I paired this with the $45 all-inclusive auto prepay plan at Verizon.  I get unlimited phone and text, and because I auto-pay, they double the data from 500mb to 1gb each month.  Because I do so much of my data over WiFi, I haven't come close to surpassing the 1gb in the three months that I've had the phone. One other thing to think about is tax. As a pre-pay plan, it's very low.  Never any BS charges, so I never pay more than $48 and change.  Lastly ... this replaced my crappy ATT service, so I get much better service as a result of the deal, too.  Overall, a major upgrade for less $$.  Hence the 5 stars.

title: good looking hardware, bad software and menus
text:
(...)
The good: its a very nice looking phone; its the right size, neither too small or too big; blue tooth enabled. The best is the blue tooth that allows you to use wireless headsets or connect to your PC and use the phone to send/receive faxes, surf the net, or update the address book.
The bad: you cannot read the screen outside unless its dark (Its like trying to watch TV when the sun is hitting the screen directly.); the camera is a gimmick that fades away pretty quick (I never used it that much); the software is slow; and the menus are counter-intuitive.
The worst is the software and the menus. I havent seen a phone that has easier menus than Nokia and this Sony Ericsson is no exception. Nokia's menus are very intuitive and easy to use, this phone's menu is just badly designed, meaning that you have to push more buttons than necessary to perform common tasks like adding a number to your address book, or editing an address book entry, moving messages around, going back to the main menu, etc. Also, because the menus are software-based (vs. being hard wired into the chip like phones with monochrome screens) there is a lag sometimes between the instant you push a button and when the menu is displayed on the screen, like using a computer with little memory. Also, you are not allowed to erase the built-in TMobile graphics and sounds, which take up memory space, and you cannot use a recording as your Ring Tone (they do that so that you dont use "protected" music for your ring tones and are thus forced to buy it from them). Finally, the phone actually crashes if you stop a voice record command immediately after starting it.
All in all, nice looking hardware but with crappily designed menus.

title: Fantastic Dumb Phone (6 stars!) works on Net10 perfectly
text:
UPDATE: I have had this phone for almost a year now. It has been dropped repeatedly including a 9 foot drop off a roof onto hard packed dirt. An extra note is that the screen is tempered glass and has NO scratches after a full 11 months of abuse. (There is a reason I wanted this type of phone ;-)

NOTE: I have been using this phone for two weeks and I am 100% satisfied. Photos were taken by this phone to show resolution and color accuracy.

NOTE I purchased this phone in March of 2020 and paid $79 for a refurbished phone, they are $150 new as I write this review.

I think this phone is ideal for rugged living outdoor people that don't care about "apps" and other smart phone silliness. Its great for builders, farmers and anyone else that plays and works hard on the edge.

If you want a tough dumb phone this is the ticket. Dropped it the day I got service on it. Bounced a foot off the asphalt. Yesterday it fell in mud, I unplugged the headset and closed the plastic flap on the headphone jack, and then (gently) sprayed it off with a garden hose. #&$^@% Awesome!

Includes calculator, timer, stopwatch, alarm, world clock , calendar, simple web browser (works for forecast.weather daht gov), FM radio (excellent long distance reception, requires wired headphones for antenna but can play mono through the loud speaker), speaker phone (very loud), flashlight, 5MP camera with 720P30F video camcorder (with decent picture and good white balance), audio recorder (can also record the FM radio), SMS and MMS texting.

This phone is full 4G-LTE and sounds better than my older LG smart phone (according to my friends). The speaker phone is very loud (you can turn it down) and you can play the radio through the speaker but you have to have a headphone plugged in as an antenna.

This phone connects to a computer as a regular USB storage device (umass) and offers full access to your SD card and access to the phones public storage. Verified works on Windows 7 and Linux -- no special software needed.

There are no apps and no GPS but it does appear to talk on the network when you are not actually using it so I assume it can still track you somehow but what I really wanted was a tough phone and the ability to say: "Sorry, I have a real phone and it won't run you silly app" the next time I ask for help at a brick and mortar and they tell me they have a *%# app.

The only hiccup I had with this phone was getting the data working, you don't have that problem if you are reading this review, I already figured it out and wrote some instructions:

GETTING DATA SERVICE TO WORK:

Note, depending on your carrier you will need to contact them to get the "APN" configuration that they use and then you will need to manually enter this info into the phone. Try searching on their website for "apn configuration" if you cant contact them by phone.

You need to already have phone service, then you configure APN. You use the APN information from YOUR carrier (they will need your SIM# or phone number). For example, Net10 has a site at net10 dot com slash apn, enter your sim or phone number and they will return a page with the APN info you need to put into your phone

Here is how to put this APN information into the SONIM XP 5700 phone:

1. click: System Settings (from application screen or the menu button (top left on keypad)

2. click: More... (this is a menu item in system settings)

3. click: Mobile Networks (scroll down)

4. click: Access Point Names (APN)

5. [Press the menu button, top left on the keypad]

6. click: New APN

7. Enter the information from [YOUR CARRIER] in the appropriate text box on the phone.

*** DO NOT ENTER any other information than what the carrier gives you.

8. [Press the menu button, top left on the keypad]

9. click: Save

10. After you click save you will see the APN screen, make sure the APN you just added is ticked (a blue dot to the right of it) and press the back button (top right of keyboard) 4 times to get back to your main screen.

11. Turn off the phone, wait a minute and turn it back on.

GOAL! Browser and MMS texting should work, it does on mine.

Feel free to share these instructions.

title: Works in Texas
text:
I've had this phone for 4 days now. So that why I only gave a 4 star and not 5 yet.
I live in Austin TX, and the phone works great. From reading a previous review before I purchased the phone, ended up helping me tremendously. You'll need to disconnect the Vo-LTE. First set up your phone. Add all the updated, and apps. You can try making calls but it will take 7-10 second for it to go through. 90% of incoming will go straight to your voicemail. Go to your phone like your trying to place a call, dial *#*#86583#*#* that code will disable voLTE. Your phone should work perfectly after that. I do have T-Mobil as my provider.

title: this is by far the best boost mobile phone i have ever owned
text:
I actually bought this phone at wal*mart lol for $60....this is by far the best boost mobile phone i have ever owned. It's fast, doesn't bog down (user error aside*) it comes with 4gb internal storage and a 1 gb sd card. You can swap the sd card for something bigger of course. Also, this phone is a 4g Lte phone! I have been with boost mobile for 5 years now, and this phone is nice! It is fast, has good ram to play all the games you want to play without slowing down. Don't shell out $300-$800 for an iphone or galaxy phone unless you really want them, with a 1.2ghz quadcore processor and 1.3gb ram this phone can compete with the best out there. Like i said before, user error* aside, this phone is fast and nimble. I've done side by side comparisons with my friends galaxy S4 and this phone keeps up with it pretty well, maybe a sec or two behind in loading some of the online apps, but that was about it. So if you want a great phone on a budget, get this one!

Pros:

-fast loads/decent ram
-4.5'' touchscreen
-a cheaper alternative to galaxy or iphones
-4g Lte able/3g in unsupported areas
-Kit Kat android 4.4

Cons:

-not a galaxy or iphone
-small sd card

*user error is anything that might cause undesirable phone performance i.e. downloading too many resource hogging apps, no upgrades to external storage, and looking online at sights that give you adware, spyware, or malware, and or anything else that might cause your phone not to function properly.

title: Works flawlessly on T-Mobile!
text:
I bought 2 of these when my daughter and I switched from AT&T to T-Mobile to cut our plan cost in half. I had previously had a Blu R1 HD and it worked flawlessly with AT&T. So since AT&T and T-Mobile networks are similar, I figured the BLU R2 LTE would be a good choice for the switch. I was right! We walked into a local T-Mobile store with these phones and a 64 gigabyte micro sd card for each. The store personnel had no problem with us using these phones. The setup was easy and we walked out about 20 minutes later with both phones operating with our original phone numbers on the T-Mobile network. We did purchase the T-Mobile sim card in the store, but other than that there were no surprises.

It's been 3 months now and we're still extremely pleased with these phones. The battery life is great. The picture quality from both front and rear cameras is awesome. We chose to add a 64 gigabyte sd card because we both take lots of pictures, and with both cameras being 13 megapixels, we didn't want to have to worry about running out of space. So far, neither one of us have run into any apps that don't function properly.

At this point, I wouldn't hesitate purchasing these again and recommending them to friends and family!

title: Don't try this first if you can afford one of their more expensive offerings
text:
I'd never heard of Blackview before. What I did know that I find myself in environments hostile to electronics, and I wanted to consolidate my work phone (T-Mobile B66) and personal phone (AT&T B2) phones into one. A little over $100 seemed like a fair price for a trial.

I expected it to be bulky and slow. It is a ruggedized phone with an oversized battery after all, and the specs aren't great by modern standards.

It's actually a lot more svelte than it looks. It's slightly thinner than my old Galaxy S10+ in a case. The screen protector that came with it is good enough that I still haven't put on the tempered glass ones I ordered. It can definitely handle missing my pouch and bouncing down a flight of concrete stairs as well.

Regarding performance; It's actually better than expected. Not overwhelmingly so, but it can do reasonably well playing Golf Rival or War Robots, and is just fine for the majority of work apps.

The closest thing I have to a complaint is onboard storage, can't expand it when using dual SIMs, and I filled it up. Again though, that was kind of expected.

title: Customer Service
text: This phone is a good phone for the price! However, the sellers falsely advertise the components of this product by indicating that it comes with a clear case.
