When I contacted the seller regarding this issue and asking if they would allow me to exchange them for clear cases I was just told that this phone comes with assorted cases. If I saw that in the description, picture, or title I wouldn't complain. Also, in the reviews, people had clear cases! I don't understand why I received multiple phones without this clear case. I did not see that in the description and they offered me no help at all. I would go to a different seller and that is what I plan on doing when purchasing more of these. title: It's not the worst, but it's not great.
text:
I waited a while to write this review because I wanted to have some time with it. That said, I am not overly impressed. Like many other people, mine is very slow and loaded with garbage programs that can't be uninstalled, meaning that you NEED to buy an SD card if you want to do anything other than calling and/or texting. It sounds like I was lucky, because mine was unlocked, making the fact that it's loaded with a bunch of AT&T crap even more irritating (I use Tracfone). It's good for simple calling and texting, but any "smart" functions don't work on mine- I have to be connected to wifi, even though I bought a data plan. But that might not be a problem with the phone, that might be a problem with my carrier. The normal camera is very, very grainy if you are in anything less than full light, and the selfie cam looks like crap no matter what. I haven't had the overheating problem, but I also don't use mine for much other than texting.

TL; DR: if you want something that is *just* for calling and texting, this is phone is sufficient. If you want to take pictures or install apps... or anything that requires space... you're better off looking elsewhere.

After a few months I went back to my usual name brand cell phone. More expensive, but worth it!
I then, to lessen the monetary loss, used this item just for music. After a few months the battery lasted less and less and less, Until I just discarded it and went on with my life. Two sayings prevail: "You get what you pay for" and " Caveat Emptor."

title: my best phone in years...did I get lucky with my 650?
text: As someone who used the original Palm Pilot and eventually the Handspring Visor with Visor phone, I thought off and on about buying the Treo 650. The very mixed, sometimes extreme, reviews of the 650 and the relatively high price for an unlocked Treo kept me away. With the release of the next generation of Treos drmatically forcing down the price of the 650 I decided to take a chance. After a week of fairly active use I have to say that I am extremely pleased with my new Treo. I bought my new unlocked (Cingular branded) Treo online. The phone clarity is as good as any mobile phone that I have owned. I have not had any dropped calls. The browswer and e-mail client that came loaded on my Treo work well. I live in a country where the fastest mobile data connection is still GPRS/EDGE, so my Tro 650 is just right. I easily synced my Treo with my MacBook with no problems. Over all for $225 + shipping and handling of $20 I have to say that this was a real bargain.

title: Great phone for the price
text:
I'd been looking for a smartphone that would not require me to get a data subscription with my GSM carrier. The Blu Studio 5.3 II offered the best specs for the price (outside of buying direct from China) . I am primarily a business user - not much gamimg at all. After 3 months of use, overall, I am very happy with this phone, with just a couple issues that keep it from being 5 star.

Pros:
* Large clear screen, and no scratches with regular use
* loud enough phone.
* Strong WiFi + easy to connect to a variety of sources, yet seems to use very little power when out of range but scanning for a signal
* snappy performance
* have only had to do a hard reset once, although I do shut it off every night to clear stray tasks
* 1gb storage + 32 GB SD addn gives me plenty of space for apps

Cons
* 512 ram is kind of all for android 4.1. I occasionally get low memory warnings, which is kind of a pain.
* I wish volume & screen brightness settings had more gradations, especially on the low/dark side. Lowest setting is too loud/bright for me.
* As other reviewers have noticed, the screen will go dim after just a few seconds of idle. I assumed this was an android power feature. When reading or typing I have to touch the screen frequently to keep it bright.
* Tough to fimd a good case. I bought a Note II generic case. Phone fit ok, but case is alrwady wearing out.

My only other comment is simply a curious observation. Less than a week after getting my phone I bruised the screen pretty badly. After another week of use the bruise went from the size of a nickel to a large, elongated thumbprint! I was very disappointed, bit figured it was my own fault. I had to go out to a camp for a week, so while gone I took the battery out and let the phone sit without power. When I got back, the bruise was gone and the phone had no touch issues where the bruise was!

title: Excellent value overall
text:
Disregarding the fact that most smartphones these days are way overpriced, the OnePlus 7 Pro is an excellent value for its price compared to the competition. The 7 Pro appears to have been discontinued sometime in late 2019. There's a MacLaren version that costs several hundred dollars more that offers 5G and a fancier case, but I didn't care for the phone color or the premium price. The 7 Pro offers nearly pure Android 10 with a minimal Oxygen OS by One Plus. With 256 GB storage, 8GB RAM, Snapdragon 855, 90 Hz refresh rate, three lenses, no notch, motorized pop-up selfie camera, and other features, this is more of a computer or small tablet than a phone. It's nearly identical in size to the Samsung Note 10+.

I only have a couple of quibbles that keep me from giving it 5 stars. If Amazon allowed, I'd give it a rating of 4.8 stars. One quibble is that the camera lacks a picture ration of 16:9, which fills the typical computer monitor screen. At present, it only offers 4:3 or 20:9, which will have black bars on top and bottom when displayed on your desktop or laptop. This can be compensated for by downloading a third-party camera app that offers the 16:9 ratio, which I did for now, until I see if they offer a software update to correct this feature. Another is that, lacking an LED notification, it's supposed to have horizon lights, long lights along the curved left & right edges, but they're not working in my sample. Many others online also confirm that theirs are not working either. One more omission is the converter for a standard earphone plug to the C-type USB connector. I had to order that separately from OnePlus.

The packaging of the product is the best I've seen for almost any product. It's almost like you bought a fancy piece of jewelry from Tiffany's. Included is a very nice quality slim clear plastic cover to provide non-slip grip and protection for the phone, and the screen comes protected with a perfectly factory-installed screen protector that's nearly indistinguishable from the glass. You can only tell it's there by looking or feeling closely along the edges of the screen.

Overall, it's probably the best and most powerful large-screen smartphone for the money. Fast, clean, smooth, and powerful. Presumably, a new model is coming out soon, probably the OnePlus 8. When it does come out, you may be able to find the 7 Pro at an even lower price.

title: Edited review.
text:
While I originally gave this product a 1 star review, I'm changing it to a 5 star review, because when the company learned of my issues with the phone, they were quick to offer a solution to my problem. I have to add that I did not contact them, they contacted me to see what they could do to rectify the issue. While I was not able to get my phones connected to a carrier in the USA, the phone itself is a great phone and the price is unbeatable. They seem absolutely sturdy and durable, even after several drops by my kids, the phones remain pristine in appearance. I wish I could have gotten service for them because they are great, especially if you're tough on phones.

Purchased these phones as Christmas gifts for my children 12 and 10, as I refuse to spend close to a grand on phones for kids, the price was right. However, they've been an absolute nightmare. They are not compatible with any cell phone carriers in the USA. I've spent more money on sim cards than I did on the phones and none of them work. Overpriced paper weights is what they are. Unfortunately my son accidentally threw away his box so I can't even return them both. Will try to return at least one.

title: This phone's battery will last WEEKS for a light user, and has good service
text:
I mostly use my phone to surf the web occasionally throughout the day and send text messages. This phone essentially doesn't need to be charged. I only connect it to the charger, maybe once every couple weeks and it doesn't even get to full charge, but that's how ridiculously huge this battery is. There are laptops with smaller batteries than this phone. It literally takes over 15 hours to fully charge this thing from zero with a low-wattage charger, but it also supports 18W charging. It doesn't matter though because this thing will go several days on a 20% charge for me.

I had the WP5 before, which was a fine phone, but doesn't pick up a bunch of the cellular channel for T-mobile, so service was awful.

This phone does not have that issue. It picks up more 4G channels than many phones you get in the USA. It picks up one 5G channel, which is the most common 5G cannel and works fine if you have coverage. My city doesn't have great 5G coverage, so I just turn that feature off, since it doesn't reliably receive phone calls and text messages if it's constant switching networks. This is not really an issue with the phone.

The WP5 had a charger port cover that was extremely difficult for me to remove without using a paper clip or something. This phone has an easier to remove cover for charging, not that you'd need to use it much!

This phone is HUGE. Like 4x bigger than a normal phone, and the screen isn't any bigger. So if you want this phone, keep that in mind. It will strain your hand to use it for a long time, but that's the price we pay for the 15000mAh battery. The WP5 was way bigger than other phones, but this phone is like twice as big as that one. I'm pretty sure you could literally crush an iPhone or Samsung phone using this phone as a hammer and it would still work afterward.

title: A phone with good build quality/display/utilities,decent battery/connectivity, average camera and confusing speaker volume
text:
I bought this phone as a standby phone when my Samsung Galaxy S8 had an issue. The build quality of the phone is excellent with a metal body design. Other than NFC it has almost everything that is expected in a smartphone. The display is good and clear and did not observe any issues in bright sunlight. The 4000+ battery with heavy use will last close to 1.5 days. The phone get fully charged from 0% to 100% in 3 hours or less. Bluetooth initially did not find any devices, however after a restart everything was good.The phone may confuse many users who switch from iPhone/Samsung/Motorola/LG which show LTE for LTE connection. This phone show it as 4G for an LTE connection. This phone has an FM radio, Calculator, currency converter, Unit converter and application lock as part of phone UI. The easy mode and kids mode in phone will be useful while giving phone to seniors or kids. The audio recording option in call is also a good feature of this phone. In short, this phone has everything that one may look for. The camera of the phone is good in bright light, however do not expect it to be equally good in low light photography.

Now to the downside. As a phone if you are using near your ear or with a head phone or with a Bluetooth headphone everything will be fine. However, if you are in a conference room and put the phone in speakers not everyone may understand what others are saying in call. The same applicable for others as well. If you put the phone in speaker mode while driving, then it is a disaster. You will not understand anything the other person is saying in call. I am still trying to find an option to resolve this major issue. In short the speaker is just average. It is loud, however the quality of sound is just average. This phone is yet to get an upgrade to Android O. Also, surprisingly this phone does not come with an ordinary earphone in the original box.

Overall, the phone is good for its price.

Update on 9/2:

After more than a month of use the following is my experience. I use phone a lot. I did not experience any call drop due to phone issues. Connection to Bluetooth headset has issues at times. It drop connection back to phone while talking. Battery will last more than a day, however it will not be enough to cover the second day. Camera is more like a hit or miss. Daylight photos are 70% success. Low light photography has only 20% success. At times, the camera app crash or freeze. Speaker volume is good and loud for watching videos and music. However, for call it is unusually weak and I don't know why it is so. The phone will need close to 3 hours for full charge. However, initial 50% charging can be achieved by around 40 min of charging. As we get closer to full charge it slow down charging. That is my observation. The phone did not show any slowness. It still has Android 7 with latest security patch. Also, received an update to Zen UI. No issue observed with GPS. Occasionally, it get warm while using GPS. The phone does not get warm in long hours of call or internet usage.

title: Elegance, innovation, and design at a $150 price tag.
text:
The Sharp Aquos Crystal is an experiment in elegance, innovation, sleek design, and compromise, all at an affordable price tag.

Design: It is a flat front, with simply no bezels around the screen, save for the large chin. The glass simply melts along the edges of the device. The lack of a bezel gives it a frankly eye-catching amount of dazzle that few phones succeed to do. All around the device is a pseudo-metal band that makes it feel a bit more high-quality than it seems, which is impressive. The back is rounded like a Moto X or Moto G, but the battery cover is a somewhat grid-dotted form, one which helps the grip of the phone... Something that can help a bit.

Hardware: Specs are simple. Quad-core 1.2GHz processor, Adreno 305 graphics, 1.5GB RAM, 8GB storage, nano-SIM slot, microSD expansion, non-removable 2040mAh battery, and a TFT capacitive 720p display. Capacitive is a touch-screen standard by now, but I'm not sure about the TFT bit. Look at the screen closely, and you might see the reflections of a series of dots, forming a grid system on the display. I'm not familiar with touch-screen technology, but I will say a visible grid on a smartphone sounds like we walked 10 years back to Palms. This isn't helped by the 5 inch, phablet-like size of the device. It is basically the size of the iPhone 6, albeit with more pixels per inch, and it is a bit clumsy to one-hand. Thank that metal band.

You're also dealing with an 8MP shooter of a camera, with a 1.2MP selfie-cam, both of which are incredible to view through the screen. The front facing camera sits at the bottom of the phone, asking you to hold it upside down to avoid a strange camera angle.

Holding it upside down reminds you... Where's the earpiece? How do you talk? Simple. Direct Wave Receiver. Akin to Google Glass and the bone conduction, DWR simply transmits sound waves through the air, into and around your ear. The upside? You can hold the phone anywhere near the ear and you can hear the person. Downside? You can't hear them much anyway. It's not exactly loud.

Top it off with a simple rainbow notification light, and you have some surprising hardware.

Software: Inside the ROM, a near-stock version of Android 4.4.2 sits in, given a few resources to cater to Sprint and Sharp hardware. All the Google apps are installed, stock phone, messaging, music, video, gallery and the like are included. Beyond that, there's an Assistant app to replace Google Search, however you can still install Google Search if you don't want it. There's a Clip Now feature that basically makes screenshotting your phone as simple as a swipe gesture away. OfficeSuite is available on the device, and Sprint/Boost offers some type of video voicemail that is available. I haven't seen anything about that on Ting, and I don't think I care.

The device offers Harman/Kardon Clari-Fi to improve Bluetooth/headset sound quality. I've yet to test this, but I imagine it isn't impressive. The display also lends itself to "frameless effects," an effect that applies graphics along all sides when certain actions occur, in order to complement the edge-to-edge display.

As for the Sprint-centric element, we have Mobile ID, that video voicemail, and "Connections Optimizer," a tool that attempts to ensure even and strong signals to Sprint towers and your trusted wireless networks to ensure even voice and data access that maximizes speeds and performance. Unfortunately, I saw it prioritize 3G when I had a 4GLTE signal in my area. I turned this off and ignored it since.

Performance: Incredible. The OS and most software don't lag much, if at all. It's a smooth experience almost through it all. Gaming is a cinch, video is immersive to a new level with no bezels, and reading is fantastic. Having previously owned the Samsung Galaxy S III, I don't regret purchasing this one. And for the $50 difference between it and this on Amazon, there's no question. You buy this one, unless you aren't doing anything related to Sprint. In which case, sorry, it's a bit CDMA only. Don't understand? Look it up.

Final testament: Sharp has made an impressive product, and it all holds the elements of a good phone. The specs don't put it up with the latest and greatest phones, but for a great and beautiful product with an experience that is barely compromised, it is worth every cent.

title: i730, an Improvement over the i700.
text:
Deciding on the best phone/PDA for you will depend on your lifestyle.

I am an author, publisher and speaker; I speak all over the world and fly more than 4,000 miles each week. I do not check bags and do not have room for paper books. I spend a lot of time on airplanes and sequestered on the other side of Security waiting in airports. I get to read a lot of electronic books (eBooks).

In other words, your mileage (lifestyle) may vary.

If you stay at home, get the paper book (pBook).

If you spend a lot of time driving, get an audio edition (aBook).

For me, being able to read eBooks is a major consideration.

The i700 came with MS-Reader; the i730 does not. Probably because Samsung/Verizon realize reading is not as good on the smaller screen. You have to download the Reader from Microsoft--no charge.

On the i700, the text block on the screen measures 1 5/8 x 1 3/4; on the i730, it is 1 3/8 x 1 3/8 with very wide margins. In other words, much of the (smaller) screen is not even used for text.

The i700 is a bit better for reading books but that model does not have WiFi or Bluetooth.

To advance eBook pages in MS-Reader, you press the side or the bottom of the large button. However it is too easy to press the reverse button at the same time; then i730 exits the Reader.

Audio books play well on the i730. Get a one- or two- gig storage card; audio takes up a lot of space.

One storage card challenge has been solved on the i730. On the i700, you could touch the card unconsciously and it would spring and fly across the room. That could be an expensive loss. The i730 holds onto the card when you release it; you have to pull it out of the unit.

Size of the i730 is about the same as the Palm but a bit thicker and heavier. The Samsung SCH-i730 weighs 6.8 ounces with the slim battery and measures 4.4 (5.2 including the antenna) x 2.25 x .9 (with the slim battery) inches.

I purchased the i730 for its additional capabilities: mostly WiFi. WiFi can be turned off to reduce power consumption.

Bluetooth initiation was quite easy. I use the i730 with the JABRA FreeSpeak 250 headset.

I am use to the peck-peck keyboard so I do not use the thumb-board very much. Since the screen is smaller, the keyboard is very small. It is a greater challenge to touch on the right squares. You can enlarge the "buttons" (squares) but then you lose the numbers.

Text messaging is much better than on a phone. You can use the keyboard or thumb board. When I fly in to deliver a speech, I text message the meeting planner on landing. That tells him or her that I am in town; a text message does not cause an interruption like a cell phone call.

EVDO coverage has expanded to more cities. See

http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/tg/feature/-/571610/103-9341655-9959826

I have not been able to get my desktop computer to talk to my notebook computer on the network. So I use the i730 to update the notebook Calendar and address book. Just sync with the desktop and sync with the notebook from time to time.

The i730 I rec'd came with both the slim and pregnant batteries. I bought a carrying case online. The i730 is slimmer than the i700 so the belt case is slimmer-and more comfortable to wear.

The i730 does not have a camera.

On trips to Canada, I've found the Verizon phone works, WiFi works, text messaging works and message retrieval works but the i730 (like the i700) will not retrieve email or surf the web.

I've had a Samsung i700 with Verizon for two years. I understand the Pocket PC. Like the i700, I spent a lot of time on the phone to Verizon i730 Support to set up the i730.

Dan Poynter, ParaPublishing.com

title: Touch screen malfunctioning
text:
I was hoping for a great Windows phone, and it could be, but this one has some problems. Mainly the touch screen. It seems to be in need of calibration. That is, touches on the screen more than 50% percent of the time result in errant selections. Whether its typing, swiping or any of the other myriad things you do with your fingers, this phone does not respond reliably. I've gotten to the point (in a few days of ownership) that I cannot text on this phone. Why? Because it takes forever! I am constantly correcting multiple letters from a single touch, wrong letters from a touch or just plain nothing! I don't know if this is a manufacturing fault or a refurbishing problem, but I need some help from the vendor to get a working phone. I hope you guys read this and offer some assistance. This, of course was typed on my trusty computer keyboard.

Update: I called Tech Venture, and the gentleman I spoke to was really helpful and got me a replacement phone. I just want to make it clear that my problem was due only to the iffy phone screen. Other than that the phone is great and Tech Venture was pleasant and easy to work with.

title: Great phone. Don't expect to get your amazon rebate money.
text:
[...]

Ok, so I've always known rebates often turn out to be a scam, but is that really the best they could do? Right before they tell me I didn't indicate the product on the form (which I did, have a copy right here), they specifically state what product I purchased!

Talk about insulting.

Anyway, back to the phone. The bluetooth feature is nice, though I leave it off most of the time because I'm concerned with bluetooth security issues. It does work well with my BlueTrek G2 headset, though the battery life of the phone is severely reduced even just having it on, not talking on it. The phone syncs great with my Apple PowerBook and the bluetooth adapter, which made it a breeze to get all my phone numbers added to the phone.

As expected, the picture quality from the camera isn't great, but I've found it is good enough for taking pictures to use as wallpaper on the phone. If I want to take pictures, I'll use a regular digital camera anyway.

The address book is decent, though I found some features missing that my previous Nextel (Motorola) phone had. Namely, you can't add enough numbers for people in the phone. I'm probably one of the few people to have this problem, but I have dozens of contacts for whom I need to have their home/work/cell phones and pager in my phone. This comes close with home/work/cell but no pager.

The organizer is ok, but lacks a few things. It has an alarm feature which is quite loud, and can be set to recur. There is a way to have calendar entries change your profile, which is nice for automatically changing it to silent when your meeting starts. It doesn't appear to support recurring calendar events. I haven't tried syncing it with my work calendar yet to see how it deals with recurring events there, so I have hope it'll work ok.

Text messages: I get paged for a living, as I'm a Unix admin with an oncall rotation. This means I'm quite familiar with a number of electronic leashes. This is the worst phone I've had yet for text messages. This thing makes a short noise when you receive a message and then remains silent afterwords. Worthless! My last two phones and my oncall phone at work continually sound until you press a button to silence it, which is a must if it is to have a chance at waking me up if it's been a bad night. Near as I can tell, there's just no way of improving this part of the phone. My plain pager for work isn't perfect either, but it at least beeps for a minute before quieting down to one chirp a minute.

Call list: It has one, but I'm not thrilled with it. It does distinguish between incoming, outgoing, and missed calls. However, it seems to collapse multiple calls together sometimes. I say sometimes, because it appears to be only with missed calls, but I'm not certain. I think it just collapses the missed calls down if there are multiples in a short amount of time. Bottom line is, I'd like to see at what time each call was missed, not whichever one (earliest or latest, not sure) it chooses.

Overall: Great battery life (unless I'm using bluetooth!), good sound quality, great form factor, seems durable (the vibrate/silent has vibrated it's way off the table a few times!). All in all a great phone, [...], still a great price for the phone.

title: Updated! Android 10 update fixed my issues. 5 stars
text:
The phone itself is very good. I purchased 2. The phone that I purchased for me is great. The phone that I purchased for someone else is not. It turns itself completely off multiple time a day (This a known issue. Do a google search for Moto G7 turns itself off or something similar & you will see what I'm talking about). If you are relying on a cell phone for your primary phone you understand why this is problem. This started happening outside of Amazon's 30 day return policy (about 45 days after purchase), so I had to contact Motorola. If you cannot be without a phone for the time it takes to return yours and receive your "like new" replacement, for $24.99 they will send a "like new phone" and place an extra $200 hold on your credit card (you will also be charged tax for the full $224.99 which I'm guessing won't be refunded). This for a problem that they know exists. If you buy this phone (don't) make sure that you keep an eye out for any problems within the 1st 30 days and return it immediately for a full refund from Amazon. You would be better off not buying this phone.

Update. The phone updated to android 10 and that fixed the issues with the phone turning itself off. I can now highly recommend it.

title: This phone is heavy and huge, and a great buy
text:
I bought this phone as a GPS and Wifi device mostly for my motorcycle, so my review doesn't cover cell phone and carrier specific items.

I think many people that look at this phone might also be looking at the Armor X series for a rugged phone, and I had both the WP5 and an Armor X7 and did a comparison. Spoiler, the WP5 won.

I set it up both and ran them side by side for battery, photos, GPS, and overall usage. The WP5 won hands down, and I don't think it was close. Side by side photos were the biggest difference. I wanted a GPS dashboard phone that could take better than decent photos without getting my iPhone out at every stop. The Armor X7 photos were junk. Both inside, outdoors and in low light. The WP5 is not an iPhone for sure, but it was markedly better in all conditions and at least 80-85% as good as the iPhone8. Next, overall Android operating system response also went to the WP5. Both right out of the box had Android 10 and very little bloat which is nice, but the WP5 felt smoother and faster than the X7. The X7 felt sluggish even at times and took longer to execute the same operations. Uploading photos to GPhotos for example to compare on the PC was really slow. The camera alone was enough for me to drop the X7, but add in the sluggish performance and it was a no brainer.

Battery life is crazy good (compared to iPhones). Went 5 days with 0 charging. I decided today to charge at 10% left, so probably could have finished out the 6th day. That included GPS screen on usage for a bunch of trail riding, downloading all the maps and apps to get started, playing around on it, and taking a few photos. Charge time from 10% to 100% was almost exactly 4 hours @ 2.0 A. The downside is this thing is huge! Photos attached show it next to the X7. We've taken to calling it the "lead brick" around my house. It's definitely rugged and feels that way. Raised edges on the screen side mean you can use it without a case and set it face down on a table without worrying.

GPS seemed to be spot on as well. I did a 1 K walk around with both the WP5 and iPhone8 side by side and the tracks are really close. I also mapped both my rides on routes I've ridden before so I could see the track differences. Tracked in Avenza Maps for both. The WP5 overlaps the other tracks from May and June on the same trail very well. Also compared to my Fitbit Ionic GPS, and it was matching my Strava tracks for the same route too. If there is an issue with GPS on the phone, mine did not experience it. I'm very comfortable using it for GPS duty in the future.

Brightness was good. Still visible in outside direct sun. It's not as good as the iPhone, but better than the Armor X7 for sure. No concerns using it and seeing while riding down the county roads to the trail heads.

If I was carrying it around in my hand all day, it might get tiring. But it's truly a 5 day battery life kinda phone even with a lot of usage. I was worried it was too big at first and thought the X7 was a better fit, but the other pros outweight the weight and size con significantly.

I would definitely recommend it if you are looking for big battery life and a smooth Android experience in a very rugged package.

title: Nearly perfect smartphone
text:
The Palm Pre is a great alternative if you don't want AT&T with an iPhone. It's smaller, multitasks (up to 4 open programs at a time for me) and has a beautiful screen.

The Great:
- Palm WebOS is very slick, easy to use and responsive to gestures
- Small for factor
- Beautiful and bright screen
- Pushes multiple email accounts as they arrive
- Pandora Radio app
- 8GB of built in RAM for photos, music etc
- Did I mention multitasking?
- App Store (but very limited as of writing)
- Free turn by turn app
- Physical keyboard for those who like to 'feel' buttons.
- 3MP Camera (with decent quality, it's no DSLR)
- Sprint's Family Unlimited Data only costs $129 for two phones!(Plus unlimited mobile-mobile)

The Not-So-Great (and why 4/5 stars)
- Battery life. 7 calls and medium-heavy wifi usage drained battery within 6 hours.
- Keyboard is small and you have to keep rotating the screen to use it (if you view horizontally)
- Slippery! It looks beautiful but it is easy for this thing to slip right out of your hands if you aren't careful.
- Build Quality could be better. (top is loose when slid open)

That said Sprint has really upped their game with price and customer service. We had one phone have the dreaded "shut down when closing the lid" problem and they sent us a replacement next day air without any cost to us.

This really is the best phone I've ever owned and it allows me to be out of my office but still connected to everything I need to run my day-to-day operations. Highly recommended.

title: HP 6945 Phone (Unlocked)
text:
I don't like this Pocket PC. Everything works, but its so slow... I allways close unnecesary opened applications, but it still slow. It seems to me that HP have to work on using a new processor, something about double the actual speed of 416 Mhz. Here are some observations:

1. The phone works, just put your SIM card and use it, thats ok. The problem is that the software and response time never compares with my previous Sony Ericsson phones, my last one was a W600i. You need both hands to operate it, if you are driving... looking for a phone number in contacts, Call History or the Speed Dial, be careful, use your Pocket PC phone can easily kill you... of course you can use a voice activation software that in my case, Latin America, almost none of the automatic softwares works (accent I guess). If I'm dialing a number and the voice mail alert starts playing right before the recorder starts... it doesn't matter if you press the End button, buttons are so slow in response that you have no time to place a miss call...

2. The GPS works just fine, but not with the HP applications... there are no maps for my country (Panama)I used the GPS Tuner software and had to georeference some images from google earth.

3. The HP 6945 freezes a lot, it is very anoying having to restard so often. Some times it freezes when I'm receiving a call.

4. The square screen is not good because some of my applications don't work on it.

5. The camera is really slow to start, very limited functionality and bad quality photos... if you want to waste good moments... just go and take pictures with this mediocre camera.

6. The battery is very bad, you better keep on syncronizing very often or you'll end up with out batteries very soon. There a lot of excuses like don't use your Blue tooth to often, dont use your GPS because it'll suck your battery, pay 55$ for a new bulky battery, stuf like that.

7. I'm not planning to buy other HP Pocket PC in the future, I'm so frustrated with this one.

title: I hate this phone
text:
I was excited to get a One Plus because it has such great reviews. I bought mine unlocked from T-Mobile about 1.5 years ago, but I was starting to dislike it within a few months. What I don't like, in no particular order:
1. The placement of the volume buttons and the power switch are such that I'm constantly turning off my phone or taking screen shots when I try to change the volume with one hand.
2. No headphone jack. I didn't think I would mind because I don't use the phone to listen to music and it comes with an adapter anyway. But if I'm using the usb charging port for something that would plug into a headphone jack, I can't also charge the phone. Because...
3. Battery life. Fully charged phone lasts about 6 hours if I'm running more than one app, such as Google maps and FB.
4. I can't use the phone over wifi without complicated root-level configuring.
5. Constantly get screen freezing when typing in email, FB, and other apps. I have to minimize then
maximize the window to get it to unfreeze.

If I could afford it, I'd get a different phone. But I'm stuck with this for at least another year.

text: This is my 3rd Moto as I have increased generations and memory with each. My G3 was only 8GB and was upgraded to the G4/16GB Prime phone as soon as it was available. This time went to 64GB to put storage and performance issues behind me.  I loved the G4 and this G5 is even better. I love going to camera mode with the twist  of my wrist and flashlight mode with a hatchet chop. To me, the Amazon ads are non-intrusive and are well worth the $60 saving. Google transferred my apps as soon as I logged onto Google and I just moved the SD card from the G4 to the G5 to move photos and music. I did have a hassle with the nano SIM and the micro SD cards as the directions were far from clear, but a video on YouTube got me straight.  I love the fingerprint reader as a touch of my right or left forefinger unlocks my phone which is so much easier than entering my pin number on the G4.  The camera seems to focus faster and takes decent pictures.  Apps load quickly and this phone seems fast. Great phone and great price!

text:
When it worked it was a good phone/SMS/camera device.

Then it needed a screen repair about four months in. I wish I had run the diagnostics when it was returned to me by BLU repair. It just was not the same as new and it should have been, else BLU should have replaced it with a certified refurb if BLU actually preformed the diagnostics and if a it failed. The WIFI and Bluetooth connections were usually flaky and unreliable. I had similar problems with a BLU R1 HD.

At the end, it would not complete the boot up leaving the screen black. I did factory resets twice to try to fix. Factory resets are a major waste of time. There are remaining FAILS on the diagnostic. It's been up for three or four days now but I don't want to nurse it any longer and already have I a non-BLU replacement up and going.

Never used the fingerprint or face recognition, so I can comment on those.

It has a couple of good features like the hardware push home button and a sturdy dual-SIM tray.

Retired it from full use after 16 months. I'm watching youtube TV on it at the moment, over WIFI, and it's doing ok, until it doesn't.

How long did yours last?

title: Limited space on the phone limits this phone's usefulness
text:
I bought this phone to use on Wi-Fi only, which works great. I needed it for a software-development project I freelanced on, and I thought it'd be nice to have a spare Internet device around the house.

This thing has so little onboard memory that after I installed just a tiny handful of apps and let it update Facebook to the most current version, it ran out of space and could not take any more, and could not update any of the existing apps. So I reverted Facebook to what shipped on the phone and downloaded an app that let me move a couple things over to the SD card. Every couple days I need to clear the cache on my apps to free up space on the phone. It's kind of a pain.

If you want an inexpensive phone and don't mind the space limitations, this is a good choice. It's not as light and thin as an iPhone 6, but it feels good enough in the hand and works well.

If you're expecting to jam this thing up with your favorite apps, keep on looking, this phone will disappoint you.

This is the second time I've given Oneplus a chance because I really want to like the product, but there are just way too many bugs. Save yourself time, money, and most importantly stress. title: The best phone I've ever had.
text:
This phone is exceptional. I have gone through quite a few phones but mainly various iPhones and Samsungs. In the past few years, I have used Straight Talk service as I think the bigger networks are a pretty big rip-off. However, it is hard to get an affordable and decent unlocked phone for a decent price point.

A little about my tastes: I like Apple computers, but I am not a big fan of the iPhone anymore. They seem to have been confirmed as disposable pieces of garbage. I had a Samsung Galaxy 3 a few years ago that I loved but broke the screen on, and I followed that with Nexus 5 which was decent for a while but eventually kind of crapped out. After the Nexus, I went through a variety of refurbished phones (including an iPhone) and was in this cycle of terrible phones. My brother-in-law had the generation before Moto G Plus, and he said he loved it. So I looked into and have never looked back! First of all, the price point is amazing. Second of all, set up with Straight Talk is super easy. Third of all, this phone is sturdy! I have dropped it and use it a lot, and it is still holding up strong at the 6 month mark.

Both my brother-in-law (who works in software development), me, and my mother have this phone. So it's a great, affordable, but hardy solution for many different users. If you want to be unlocked but want a solid phone, this is the one.

title: J8 is a great phone for a good price.
text:
Each time Samsung gives me a wakeup call that there's no need to pay over $300 to have a good phone for our daily needs. Every thing I need to do today with any $300+ phone I can do with this J8. I have seen the A10 which is $100 cheaper than J8, also has fantastic features and doesn't differ much form any other. I am pretty sure in the next couple of years we will have G5 in any phone but the price will remain as budget as possible. Any way I am not worried with G5 because LTE/G4 still doing the job that I need.

The most I have spent on a phone was $600 when the Galaxy S3 came out (I bought 2, for me and my wife), but a couple of months later came the S4 for almost the same price, I was very disappointed. Ever since I promised myself to never buy phone over the range of $300, luckily the tech is growing and I can have low price for a good phone.

My wife is using a J7 and she never complained at all.

title: Basic rugged phone
text: The Ram 7 is a basic ruggedized phone, you can talk, text and take some low-res photos. It has limited MMS. it will play mp3s but as far as I can tell it will read only 1024 songs no matter how many are on the microSD card. It will play FM radio with the built-in antenna. The built-in speaker sound quality is about as good as a small transistor radio.  It is internet capable, but more suited to the internet of 1995 with no https capability. Battery life is excellent, you can go 1-2 weeks on a charge depending on use, e.g., music or radio listening. The keypad buttons are sturdy and so is the exterior. It's not as sturdy as a Getnørd Walrus, which was 2G phone, but the Ram 7 is 3G so that makes up for it. I've had to call customer service for a couple of issues and they were not very helpful, you are mostly on your own.

The second issue is making calls is annoying. I've had it connect calls, but about 40% of the time you can't hear what's in the other side (while they can still hear you). It's also dropped calls on me multiple times, which I can only guess is related to the above issue.

The phone has a sleek design and I do enjoy a good deal of it, but if it can't perform the most basic functions, it feels useless. Probably going to return it and find something else instead

It's such a pain to open things and close things all the time on the iphone, and Android just is not all that smooth.

Palm is still a small company, but they are very motivated, so they are coming out with updates and improvements every months and you get updates on the phone right away. I think Apple is great, but sometimes, it feels great to have a phone looks a little different than everyone else in the subway :)

I highly recommend this phone. But maybe it would be a good idea to wait for Verizon to release the phone in the next couple months. (their CEO says they will soon). By then, I think Pre will have a new updated version. That version will resolve some of the issues that you see mentioned in the rest of reviews here.

title: Look elsewhere for a mini-phone for the USA
text:
Not up to expectations, doe not work very well at all.
Size is nice, it is very slim and credit card sized.
The phones physical look and feel and build appear adequate. It was shipped timely, with a followup email from the company on status.
It does make calls on the TMobile gsm network when a sim is inserted. However, it does not really work very well for any basic cell phone functions. I set the language to English in the menu (thanks to instructions in an Amazon comment) but lots of Chinese Characters still show up on many basic functions. I could not get it to send text in English... every time I tried after a few English characters show up as you tap out the characters, it starts texting in Chinese and bogs down. Cannot figure out how to store any numbers in English on either the phone or the sim...
I am very good with technology... but this one is not useful at all.
I could not figure out how to get my Tmobile voicemail on this phone.
It is just not functional. Other than making calls you dial on the keypad, or receiving a call that rings... does not work for anything else. No storage of numbers, no texting, not up to non-smartphone standards at all.
I gave it a try based on the small size (which I like) and the price (OK), but it is not ready for prime time (at least in the US).

Don't buy this... look for another option if you are looking for a very small form phone to carry for mobility.

title: Nice portable gaming device, not as nice as a phone
text:
I've had the phone for about a month now, here are my impressions so far:

PROS:
* the screen colors are bright and images look nice and crisp, the resolution is pretty good.
* plays Game Boy advance games perfectly through an emulator, haven't tested the PS one emulator yet
* the gamepad feels nice and is perfect for RPG type games that don't require super fast precise responses

CONS:
* as a phone it's quite outdated, it's very sluggish when using skype or pretty much anything other than an emulator
* battery life is extremely short, even if the phone is just idling it hardly gets though 8 hours at times, had to buy a second battery and external charger to have a backup at hand.
* gamepad is not usable enough for fast paced action games, shoulder buttons are hard to reach and hard to hit precisely
* internal storage is fairly small and a lot of it comes used up by preinstalled games that you cant uninstall without rooting the phone.

Overall, I wish they'd make an updated version of this phone, with better specs it would make for an excellent phone and a perfect portable console for emulators, as it stands, it lack a lot as a phone by today's standards, only buy it if you really want to play a lot of emulated games on a decent gamepad and don't mind a slow phone.

The battery charges to 100%, camera works great, and most importantly was able to set up to MetroPCS/Metro by T-Mobile network: no issues receiving calls, voicemail, texts, or using Maps. The phone came with a screen protector and charger.

title: Intuitive Interface Sacrificed But Resilient and & 4G Capable
text:
Intuitive Interface Sacrificed But Resilience & 4G Capable via Network Settings and Service Provider

When in need of a “non-smart phone” that is tough, a “flip” model and at least 4G, the Pum Ram 8-4G is the ONLY model out there that appeared to qualify. The one or two other contenders offer 4G LTE (which, as I understand it, is sales talk for, “faster than 3G but not really 4G”). These are factors that led to my purchase of this phone.

I’ll first address the negatives: Reviews on Amazon and elsewhere, indicate that though this phone is advertised as 4G, it is actually 3G. One such review cited a conversation with his AT&T rep who, based on what was on their computer after entering the IMIE, indicated the phone was 3G. If true this would expose Plum to deceptive trade practice litigation (DTP). I doubted this. So before purchasing, I twice e-mail the company regarding the matter. The manufacturer replied: "3G version was discontinued in 2019. This version is 4G,” and, “Due to recent update in ATT system – any phone that is not 5G is being flagged as not compatible or 3G. Please inform the ATT rep that it is a 4G unlocked phone and they will make a note and you won’t have any issues. This issue is also affecting all prepaid services that uses ATT network like Consumer cellular, Cricket, H2o, Pure Talk, Tracfone, Straight Talk etc."

When I gave to my service provider (Patriot Mobile) the IMIE numbers (there are two because the phone accommodates two sim cards) they only noted that the phone was not active—duh—and confirmed with me that it was unlocked.

The service I have (via Patriot) is from T-Mobile. However, the screen of the Plum Ram 8-4G indicates “3G.” I e-mailed Plum for clarification. Their response: “Ignore the 3G sign—it is 4G.”

However, after looking through the phone’s numerous screens and options, under “Settings” I found “Network Settings” and “SIM1 network settings.” Under this I found “Network Selection” and when selected it searched for and found T-Mobile’s 4G and 3G Networks as well as AG&T’s 4G Network. There is also a selection Mode that will pick the Network automatically or manually. Based on other settings in this section (under “Network Information”) I can see that I am on the 3G Network. I was able to switch the phone to 4G, but the service didn’t connect. So I am thinking my SIM card and/or service account is restricting me to the 3G. I’ll pursue this further in order to figure out what is going on. But the end result of this information is that this Phone IS 4G capable and the access to that Network depends on either the SIM card or the service provider. Note: Even though I don’t have an AT&T account, I could actually get the phone to connect their 4G Network but only for Emergencies—and this is indicated when, instead of the main screen indicating “Wireless,” it indicates “Emergency.” I’m guessing that means for 9-1-1.

I’ve read reviews that there are no volume controls on the phone. Not true. Page 11 of the manual (which is egregiously under-developed) shows the volume control and the video on Amazon shows how it is used. However, even these are not entirely—or fully described. For example, there are no buttons on the outside of the phone, so if you want to control the ring volume you must either 1) use the center Menu/Ok button (with its up, down, left and right arrows) OR; 2) Adjust the volume via the User Profile. To adjust using the first method, you must be receiving a call and press the up or down Menu/Ok button. To adjust the ringer volume via method 2, Select “User Profile” from the screen menu and under the “General” Option (or one of the other four User Profiles), select “options,” then “customize” and then “Ring tone volume.” Even the most quite setting is more than enough.

So as is obvious, there are many things about this phone that are not intuitive or standard in other phones. You cannot, for example, put dashes in phone numbers that you save. If you save a phone number as a business number you cannot readily put it above the empty option for a cell number (although I think you might be able to make all entries do this via another menu option that I THINK I saw). The phone has a lap and split time stopwatch, but not a countdown stopwatch. It has a confusing “nWay” Stopwatch that displays four stopwatches at the same time, each controlled by the different direction buttons of the “Menu/Ok button.”

I’ve read that that the company doesn’t have a manual online. Not true. Go to the Plum Mobile website click the SUPPORT page. Alongside the Q&A section is a link for manuals. However as noted above, the manual is woefully brief as only the first 13 of 38 pages are the English instructions.

I’ve read there is an issue with regard to receiving messages. Before giving up, and per the manual (page 10) check the APN settings. Also, rather than calling Plum Support, trying e-mailing. They have been prompt in responding to my several messages.

Now, about the phone more generally: I expected some rubber coating and it has none. But a video review I saw of the phone showed it taking some harsh abuse (tossed into muddy water, thrown to the ground, Tossed 30 feet into the air and hitting the ground, thrown into a cement wall and bouncing to the ground and being rolled over by one tire of a car. In each instance the phone in the video appeared unscathed.

The actual phone does feel a little light and the exterior seems unsubstantial. In a tactile sense, the plastic feels “cheep” while looking “tough.” But there is that video and I’m not going to run it through the same paces. It is reportedly certified (IP-67/68) to the highest waterproof rating, meaning it is supposed to be watertight for 20 minutes to a depth of one meter (just a little over three feet). That, on top of being shock and dust resistant. The phone appears fairly easy to use, but as noted above it is not particularly intuitive. It offers that second sim card slot (presumable for a second number and/or for overseas use I believe). It also offers a micro card slot for expanding the memory up to a 32 gig micro card. There are also Internet settings (the above-referenced APN settings).

I’ve read reviews that indicate it is not easy to charge or easily be set in the charger. Not so. When placed the phone in the cradle for charging the phone merely sits lightly on the contacts—it doesn’t “snap in” or lock. But the two lights on the cradle reflect when the phone is charging. The phone display, when on, will reflect the charging status only momentarily, then goes dark. The lights on the charging cradle are what tell you when it is fully charged. If that doesn’t suit you, the cord that plugs into the cradle may, instead, be plugged directly into the side of the phone for charging.

The phone also has a built-in FM radio for which you can control the volume and I suspect that in adjusting the volume to that, you may also control either the earpiece or speaker volume. But that’s just a guess—I haven’t tested it.

My overall opinion… Well, I am going to assume the resilience of the phone is as advertise and on a scale of 1 to 10 (with five being average), give THAT aspect of the phone a 10.

My experience with the company support is about an 8.

My impression of the phone’s options, even with the internet option, is about 5 to 6 (again with 5 being average). I think the lack of a intuitive user interface and the loss of more familiar features, hurts this phone. And I don’t think if a user was happy with a previous “tough” flip phone, they will be happy with this phone. Even if it is as stout as claimed, it is a vastly different creature in terms how the user interacts with it.

I’m also a little concerned about the battery life but can only rate it at about 5 to 6 for now. I’m unsure of how much standby time the phone actually has or whether I can get a better longer-lasting battery.

The phone rates pretty high for video and photo options and enhancement: It has more than I expected and I’ll give it a 6 to 7.

And as stated herein-above, the phone IS capable of 4G. For that the thing deserves a pretty high mark.

So, all of that together, at this point, and on the 1 to 10 scale (with 5 being average) I think I am generously rating it at a 5 to 6. I think that as I become more use to this phone my rating will improve.

title: Issues with charging use and cold weather
text:
I purchased this phone so I wouldn't have to worry about it on my farm. It works fine in the summer. If it's maybe 40 degrees outside I can't keep it warm enough to use. It's on, it just doesn't register anything I'm doing on the screen. No photos, no videos unless I bring it in the house and warm it up. I've kept in a pocket inside my coat, warm next to me, still doesn't work. Maybe my hands are chilled. Not sure but it doesn't have to be that cold out. Defeats the purpose of having a phone to use if I get hurt moving livestock.

The phone won't work for most things when it's charging. I have to unplug it to use the fingerprint reader, try to text or type anything, look at email etc. . This is annoying but not a big deal.

I'm also looking for a wireless charger. I think the port is wearing out. It's a little picky, this is just due to buying a used phone.

Otherwise I like the phone. I've dropped it, no issues. I've splashed water on it, no problem. I really like the phone but this issue with the cold will keep from purchasing another when this one wears out.

title: Great phone but crap company that dictates how you use your minutes.
text: I purchased this phone for my son who wanted a phone that most looked like an iphone. The phone itself is great and looks really good. Our HUGE complaint is that when you buy a card of minutes and put on this phone the minutes are divided 3 ways, talk, text and data. As my son mostly texts and occasionally uses the data it works great for that. But right now he has over 250 min. of talk time on here that can not be used to text (which is 95% of what he wanted his phone for). I think that when we buy minutes for the phone, he should be able to use them however he wants. Almost all of his friends only use their phones to text and it is the easiest for us to communicate with him throughout the day as well. Had we known this ahead of time that even though I am paying for minutes but tracfone dictates how he can use them, I would NOT have purchased this phone and went with something different.

title: It is pretty zippy and lightweight
text: Liking it so far.  It is pretty zippy and lightweight.  I bought it for my wife.  For a $500 phone, face and fingerprint recognition are crazy fast.  The only problem is, face recognition doesn't work all the time.  Looks like it has some algorithm to capture the image within x seconds of picking it up after which it fails.  But not a big deal for my wife at least.  Their EMUI skin is not attractive in my opinion, but I have never been bothered too much by any skin, actually.  So not a big deal for me.  Speaker is fine, comparable to Galaxy S8 in my view.  Screen is bright, but I never keep it too bright to protect my eyes any ways.  Photos come out pretty good and can take fast photos.  The fact that this has audio jack plus the same processor as Mate 10 Pro and a $150 difference (Mate 10 Pro sells for $650 now) made this one my preferred device.  My biggest problem has been to find a good screen protector and case for this device.

title: Lacking a beatiful case
text:
I replaced my dropped G91 phone with this (Nold N2) phone. My G91 had slipped out of my pocket and fell 4 feet on a concrete floor; its screen was cracked even though the phone was in its case: the ugly black case that was shipped with the phone.

I was surprised and annoyed that a four-foot drop of the phone would have cracked its screen. So I decided the replacement phone will have to feature a Corning Gorilla Glass 5 or better. This phone sports the Gorilla Glass 5, so I hope it will survive a 4-feet-drop.

I do not like the shipped ugly black Blu's case that was shipped with it for two reasons: 1) The case is very hard and therefore does not protect the phone from a 4-feet drop to a hard surface. 2) The phone is beautiful--like a piece of art--but its beauty is completely masked when placed in the shipped ugly black case. Hence, I am now looking for a transparent shock-absorbent case for my new phone. Transparent because I want the phone's beauty to be visible to the world.

The phone excels in all other areas: good battery life, lots of memory, nice display, etc. So I will not elaborate on these features except to warn that it does not offer wireless charging and NFC.

I believe the purchase price of $199.00 makes it a very good budget: probably the best in terms of features vs price ratio.

title: Works on Verizon! Ads aren't annoying
text: Ive had this phone (the 64gb one) for over 2 months. As a former avid iPhone 6 user, it holds up pretty well! I was so hesitant to buy it partially because of all the reviews about the insane hassle Verizon puts you through to set up service. I got lucky by having a SIM card from my broken iPhone- it worked the second I inserted it! The fella at the Verizon store told me that I would have been "out of luck" if I didn't have a nano, non NFC SIM card that was already attached to my phone number. (Sounds from the other comments like buying and activating a SIM is possible tho.) Some calls broke up at first but I disabled "enhanced 4g LTE mode" and haven't had a problem since. I got the version with the ads and thankfully, they are ridiculously unobtrusive. They only go full screen if you have no notifications, aka almost never. Love the battery life- way better than the old iPhone. I like the camera well enough too. Attached are some photos I've taken with it. Also attached is a photo of the ad/ notification screen. The built in speaker is at least as loud as my bf's iPhone 6 but a bit tinny sounding in comparison (not too noticably). The only issues I have are 1: videos are pretty grainy and 2: some apps occasionally freeze up and quit unexpectedly. Not too big of a deal, but it happens a couple times a week. Also this will matter to like 0.01 of you but there are several glitches with Instagram stories. It auto rotates and crops out the sides of pictures I took with my phone sideways. Videos will sometimes fail to upload even with WiFi and you have to retry them. And when I do a few videos in a row, they post and look fine on other people's phones but often won't play when I try to rewatch my own story. That said- who cares? Sweet phone. Five stars.

title: Not compatible with Verizon 5G
text:
This is a classic example of false advertising. Unless I missed something, they do not inform you that this is not compatible with Verizon 5G Network. In fact there were threats of class action lawsuits over this device because Verizon launched it on an older 5G Network that's no longer part of their business model. They should explicitly explain this is only going to work on a 4G network oh, that way no one can complain. Otherwise the device was in excellent shape, and works well.

I included a screenshot, which shows that's connected to 4G. It will not connect to any 5G unless you go to one of just a handful of towers that are located in urban centers. The closest to me would be in Downtown LA which makes no sense at all. Why advertise and sell a 5G handheld device you know very well the issues with this chip and phone.

title: This phone is for the traveler or a person who just wants the basics.
text: This phone is a quad band GSM phone and will work virtually everywhere on the planet with a cellphone signal. I already own a smart phone for use at home and I needed something to make phone calls with while traveling in other countries. This phone has everything that I needed. It has a built in flashlight that I can turn on without hassle when I need it. It also plays mp3 files that can be loaded to the optional micro SD card (2gb max). It comes with clear instructions, a headset, and a charger. The greatest thing about the phone, to me, is that the phone, while it is small(about the length of a deck of cards) it can hold two sim cards simultaneously. This allows you to talk on two different networks with the same phone. That allows me to keep my high dollar phone at home, load a cheap pre-paid sim card from Ma Bell, or that T company here in the USA, and load a pre-paid sim card from my destination at the same time. One phone, two countries, no commitments or contracts. Life is good! Battery life is good. And the traveler friendly charger is rated for 100-240v. All you need is a plug adapter and voila, instant gratification. When and if this phone dies, I'm buying another. Highly recommend!

title: Not really a functional smartphone
text:
The BLU Advance 4.0 L2 phone is really not a functional smartphone, with only 4 GB of internal storage. If you need any extra apps, you will not really have enough internal memory to run them. You can get a micro sd card for additional storage which I did (and I also made the sd card the default storage location), but even transferring everything I could to the external storage, the internal storage has remained almost maxed out, and this sometimes causes troublesome messages to keep popping up telling me the email service has been stopped due to low available storage. The app I was working with that was particularly nearly useless with this phone was Bringg (though the app is really buggy for everyone I know, regardless).

In addition to that major problem, I must lock the phone whenever I actually use it for a phone, or my ear will start touching and opening the battery and settings controls while I'm talking on the phone, if I'm not using speakerphone. And I've had lots of problems with phone calls happening while the phone app turns off, meaning I have no control over the telephone connection that is ongoing. The telephone app on this thing is awful.

Android is really poor. I've used it on another device I have as well, and I hate it. And from what I can tell from friends with other operating systems, Windows phones are really poor, and iPhones are really poor. Bottom line: I'm chucking this phone and going back to my flip phone, now that the work I got this phone for has ended. My old flip phone can actually be used as a phone without any of the aggravation of these stupid "smartphones." The smartphone is too big and too troublesome to be a good phone, and too small to be a good computer or web browser.

title: The Answer to ALL my Problems
text:
OK, maybe not all my problems, but definitely all my phone problems. I was addicted to social media and time-wasting phone games; mostly solitaire. At a certain point, I felt like I was rotting my brain, so I decided to try a flip phone. This was partially awesome, as talking on a phone that was actually designed to be used AS A PHONE is so much more comfortable. But texting sucked, I couldn't really send or receive pictures on it, and it had no easily accessible navigation. So for the two years I had it, I also continued to lug around my old smartphone, like a damned albatross, using my flip phone's hot spot to do all the things I was trying to avoid. Well, one fateful day, I sat on the old smartphone and destroyed the screen, so it was time to try something new. I had initially settled on just getting a new smartphone, so I set about trying to choose one. But what had happened in the intervening 5 years or so since I had purchased the last one? Everything got even bigger. Basically phones are tablets now. I hate it. So I googled "small smartphone", and eventually stumbled upon this thing. At first I was skeptical, but the price was decent and the reviews were good, so I decided to give it a shot.

In short, I LOVE THIS PHONE.

Not only is it ADORABLE, it's easy to carry around - it even fits in the coin pocket of most jeans, easy to talk on, durable - with included case and screen protector, and it looks and sounds great. Signal quality seems better than my flip phone, which was pretty good. The battery life is way better than I hoped. It easily lasts all day for me with regular usage. The screen looks great and is very accurate and responsive. The 3-tap zoom feature is a nice touch. Typing on it takes a little getting used to, but overall works better than I expected. I still make a lot of errors but it's way faster than texting on the flip phone. It also has swype and autocomplete, so unless you have huge sausage fingers, it's very usable.

My only major complaint about the phone is that the GPS is consistently inaccurate, so if you rely on the "robot lady" to navigate for you, it's gonna be a problem. I generally use navigation interactively, keeping my map in "north up" view and following along as I go rather than just taking its direction, so for my purposes it's not that big of a deal if the "robot lady" thinks I'm on a parallel street and starts telling me to make nonsensical turns. But yeah, I'd say this might be a deal-breaker for someone who does rely on that turn-by-turn navigation.

Overall, this is a great little phone and it truly has changed my habits. I actually finished a book during my work breaks last month!

title: One serious design flaw RETURNING THE PHONE
text:
This phone is supposedly designed for seniors who have dementia issues.
Pluses: very easy to set up and very easy to use for making calls.

Lesser Minus: when a call is in session it says “ABORT” over the button used to hang up the phone. Dementia patients don’t get that word means hang up. Say “HANG UP” or “END” please.

Major minus: the button that turns the phone on and off is the same button you use to hang up the phone. If you hang up and hold that button a fraction of a second too long the phone is turned off. Seniors with dementia do not remember how to turn the phone back on. We have had the phone operating for 2 days and she has accidentally turned it off multiple times. I am giving it a few more days and I may return it. This is a serious design flaw.

EDIT: After only 3 days we are returning this phone. My mom has mid stage dementia. She starts every morning calling us. One call and she turns the phone off. This phone was very poorly designed. I do not recommend it.

I believe the first one was recondition so it was activated in less than10 minutes. The new one took 55 minutes because it was brand new and Google had not been satisfied on it. By that I mean as soon as it was turned on I could not access the home page as the Tracfone technition was getting it activated.  Google wanted your name and life history like your Google user name passwords., etc.  It made me register when I knew I was registered and when I did it voided the registration as I was already registered. I would recommend that before you call Tracfone to activate you turn the phone on and get all that Google stuff done. I look forward to using this phone as a second phone to my lndline. text: This is a great phone, I upgraded from my Pixel 3a, and the Nord N10 does everything better than the Pixel. I thought is might be too big, but it fits nicely in my hand. It has a nice clean Android install without bloatware with some nice customization options. The camera takes great photos, the battery lasts me all day, the display screen is beautiful (I turned down refresh down from 90 to 60Hz because I don't notice any difference and it saves battery), has a headphone jack, and the phone operates really smoothly. I don't play any OS intensive games so I can't comment on that. Other reviews have commented on cons that it doesn't have a OnePlus physical alert slider, but I never had one so I don't miss it. I've been looking for a good midrange phone and this is without a doubt the best currently available for $300. The only con I have found is sometimes the fingerprint reader is slow or unresponsive, but it's only a second away to enter the PIN. Great phone.

text: The phone arrived in great time and perfect, new condition.  Everything was in the box and exactly as promised.  I liked the phone--very light weight and seemingly easy to use. I plugged it in to charge the battery as instructed and the phone powered up quickly with a screen that was easy to see.  It would have been perfect for me--if I spoke fluent SPANISH!!  All of the menus and phone screens were in Spanish and I don't understand it at all!!  I searched online, found numerous suggested fixes to convert the phone to English and tried them all--but nothing worked.  Google Translator couldn't even identify some of the words on the screens for me!  I even inserted a brand new SIM card but everything was still in Spanish.  The instructions with the phone were very poor and very minimal and nothing addressed the default language and how to change it.  I'm petty savvy with electronics but this phone stumped me!  I have no complaints with the return policy--it was efficient and I received a prompt refund.  In conclusion, I really liked the phone design, appearance, weight for travel, etc. but the language barrier was a deal breaker for me.  I think the item description was remiss in not clearly stating that the phone would arrive with a Spanish language default and no instructions on how to change it!

title: A lot of potential, but not quite there
text:
After doing a bit of research I decided on this phone to replace an hold Honor 8 that I’ve been using with Metro PCS. My first impression is that the hardware was excellent, especially at this price point and the proprietary operating system was a bit buggy, but that wasn’t a deal breaker for me.

Pros:
Excellent battery life
Good cameras, especially at this price point
Fast finger print reader
Decent build quality

Cons:
Does not support many U.S. LTE bands (cross check with your carrier)
Screen brightness is good, but the screen is very reflective making it difficult to see in bright light
Screen appears to have a polarizing filter, meaning if you are wearing polarized sunglasses you will NOT be able to see the screen when holding the phone horizontally. This is very inconvenient, especially for taking horizontal photos on bright days.
Audio quality when using headphones is not as good as other phones I have owned
Intermittent issues with vibration alerts
Proprietary MIUI works well enough but it can be buggy and inconsistent at times

After using it for a few days I started to notice a few of the issues noted above that I unfortunately just can’t get past so I will be returning the phone. For me, the biggest issue is band compatibility for Metro PCS. I’m not very well versed in mobile lingo but I read many reviews that stated it worked well with Metro. I would say it works okay but I found that it did not work as well as my old Honor 8. After doing a bit more research I discovered that Metro operates it’s LTE service on six different bands. This phone only supports two of those six and the Honor supports three of the six. The one band that the Honor supports that this one doesn’t is band 12, which I understand helps with cell reception indoors and in some rural areas. I like the phone enough that I would be willing to accept the other flaws I mentioned but the poor reception compared to my old phone is a deal breaker for me. It’s an awesome phone if it works well on your network, but do your research and make sure it supports the bands you need.
