title: Beyond Basic, Bad Sound Quality, Drops Calls
text:
I just wanted a pocketable quad-band GSM phone that does well at making and taking calls--nothing else. No texting, no Bookface, no Internet, camera optional. Unfortunately, this phone proved unable to meet this simple requirement. Fortunately, Amazon stood behind its guarantee and gave me a full refund, shipping included.

This phone seemd to fit the bill. And with the Amazon $40 credit for opening their credit card, it was free. (By the way, this phone is the same as the T200 except for the dual sim slots.) I really, really wanted it to work. And for almost a week, I learned to accept its many baffling quirks.

The one "quirk" I could not accept is that it routinely drops calls when I talk to my dad, who uses a landline in a small town. (It also dropped a call several times to a friend who's on Verizon Wireless, but I chalked that up to a major rainstorm.) Dad noted, when I called him back on my wife's iPhone (also on AT&T), that the call quality was markedly better. So I'm returning this phone, even though I like its small size and simplicity.

PROs:

* This phone is TINY. It might be the smallest phone available now. About half an inch longer than a credit card. If you remember the tiny candy-bar phones people were using around 2000, it's just like those. Super light. Very pocketable, but the size means the navigation ring is also tiny.

* The speakerphone is loud on my end.

* Typical of GSM phones, the battery life is good. The phone lasted just about six days on its first charge, including a couple of long calls and many short ones, plus liberal use of the flashlight.

* That flashlight is decently bright and very handy. If you buy this phone, make sure to turn off the keypad lock when you first get the phone. Then hold down the middle button inside the navigation ring to turn on the flashlight.

* No camera means less to go wrong.

* Two SIM card slots. (You cannot rename them, but that's OK by me.) A good capability to have for overseas trips with a spouse or partner.

* I like the phone's appearance--solid matte black. It's not slippery at all, yet its rounded corners make it very unobtrusive in the pants pocket.

CONs:

* Dropped calls. I routinely get a frustrating "no network" warning, even when I'm calling from our house, which is smack inside a major metropolitan area. We have no problems getting AT&T on other phones. I think this phone's reception problems are due to the phone's lack of any 3G capability, such as EDGE/UMTS/HSDPA, etc. It can't be AT&T's network, because my wife's iPhone 3G (and even my bare-bones Samsung SGH-107) do just fine.

* Incredibly, there is no instant-hush button to quickly silence the phone if it rings. You can, however, program one of the nav-ring directions to go to User Profiles. And from there, you can go to "silent"--meaning a total of four clicks to shut the thing up. Alternatively, you can press # to put it on vibrate--or turn it off. This is a major omission.

* Bad sound quality for those on the other end--at least for some people.

* The speakerphone, though loud as can be on my end, left one caller saying there was a weird noise on his end. But other calls on speakerphone have been OK.

* The navigation ring is very narrow--so much so that it's clickable only via fingernail.

* Keypad buttons are separated only by horizontal creases--no actual grooves, and nothing vertically. So you can't dial by touch. (This does, however, seem like it would prevent crumbs or other gunk from getting under the keypad.) This phone is not for the visually impaired, the arthritic, or the clumsy. Or those with long fingernails.

* The icon for signal strength doesn't work on this phone, at least for AT&T. Maybe that's to be expected, as it's not one of their phones. The battery icon does work, though.

* There are only 9 speed dial numbers, and no. 1 is automatically voicemail if you're on AT&T.

* You can't do speed dial via pressing then number and then "send"; the only option is to hold the number down. Similarly, you can't hold down the "send" button to dial the last number called or received, as you can with LG and Samsung phones (and perhaps others). This is very annoying if you're used to doing number plus send.

* The call log doesn't separate missed/sent/received calls, instead listing them together, each type with a different icon.

* The FM radio works only with earphones (though this is commonly the case).

* There is no external volume on the side--you must use the navigation ring's up or down keys during a call.

* You can't turn on the speakerphone until a call has been made or received.

* I would prefer a generic, old-school, non-musical ringtone. But one of the three included has become strangely pleasing: a fast waltz in a minor key, of all things. The others are like something from a 1997 Belgrade karaoke bar. There isn't a non-musical ringtone, unfortunately.

* I hate the wallpaper--purple with some dumb DJ character. Blech. You can't change it unless you download your own wallpaper; this is the only one included on the phone.

* There is no voice dialing.

* No Bluetooth!

* The English manual is a comically bad translation. (Evidently, even Google Translate is banned in China.) It's positively incomprehensible in places. Worse, the page numbers in the table of contents are wrong; that's just lazy. And the SAR is not mentioned anywhere.

TIPS:

* I almost thought there were no speed dials, because they are for some reason not mentioned in the manual. And they're not where you'd expect them, under Address book. Reach them via Menu/Call Center/General call settings/4--speed dial.

* The battery cover is not intuitive, and the manual doesn't tell you how to open it. Use a fingernail to pry open from the end with the slot, and then do the same via the side. (I.e., pry it up but don't try to slide it down.)

* The manual tells you to charge the battery for 12 hours the first time; they must be stuck in 1995, because it's a Li-ion battery. There is NO need to do this for Li-ion batteries. (The quickstart menu says to charge it for 24 hours!)

*To do anything on the phone, you have to wake it up out of standby first, by pressing any key.

* FYI: The languages available on the phone are English, Spanish, and Portuguese. (The founders of Blu are Brazilian.)

CONCLUSION:

I had thought this phone would be great for a calls-only luddite like me. Alas, it was not. I was even accepting of the phone's many annoying quirks, thinking it was worth it to have a phone that is so small I wouldn't avoid carrying it. It does have some cool features (e.g., the flashlight, FM radio, and dual SIM slots). But there are some unforgivable interface omissions--no silent button? REALLY?--and functions are not mapped intuitively.

Most importantly, a phone has to be able to reliably make and take calls. That means not dropping them.

BLU Products needs to do some basic user testing before introducing products onto the market. Props to Amazon, though, for standing behind its customers.

title: Almost Everything I Want From A Smart Phone
text:
I misplaced my (Verizon) Treo 650 and eventually gave up and decided to replace it after whinging about with my daughter's old LG. Since the rest of the family is on AT&T, I looked at the iPhone but went back to another Treo. (The iPhone user interface is superb, but I found the keyboard unusable for emails/memos/text messages, and I don't often listen to music or watch videos on my phone, so those otherwise great features were not of interest to me. And AT&T had a great rebate.) So I acquired a crimson treo...maybe I'll have a harder time losing it!

If you've owned a Treo, this has all the advantages of the family, using the Palm OS, which I prefer to Windows Mobile. If you've not owned a smart phone before, they are a tremendous productivity booster, and I can say from personal experience what a setback it is to return to a regular cell phone. The 680 synched up quickly with my laptop. (I followed the instructions and re-installed HotSync, assuming I would be re-entering a lot of names, but it saved everything from my lost Treo.) I use email from Earthlink and Yahoo as well as corporate Outlook and it works seamlessly.

(There was one problem with Outlook and my prior 650 - Versamail could not handle the it's-time-to-change-your-password message and woudl lock up. I don't know if it's going to be an issue with the 680 or not, but a password change on the 650 took care of the problem. YMMV.)

Battery life has been a common complaint of early 680 users. There are two factors here. First, the battery is smaller to help make the phone slimmer, and I like the new form factor. I regularly just plug it into the car charger and it's not an issue. The other factor is the firmware - before version 1.09, there were some battery-draining bugs in the 680. All the Treo forums I've researched have indicated that the May upgrade corrects most of the battery issues. There are now extended batteries available as well, although they require a different cover and make the phone larger.

I have not looked at all of the negative reviews, but I think that most of them will be from before May 2007, when the AT&T version of the upgrade became available. So I would suggest that readers consign these to the dustbin of history -- it's not a huge problem anymore.

There are a couple of drawbacks to the 680 for the 650 user besides the smaller battery. There is no Wi-Fi card available for the 680, which would be useful in the future. The SD card has been moved to the side from the top, which makes it harder to accidentally pop out the card. The 680 SD cover seems flimsy, but will probably be OK if one is careful to replace it correctly.

So...if you want a lighter weight Treo than a 650, and can manage to charge the battery daily, the 680 should meet your needs. I am ecstatic to have a Treo again, and the 680 has yet to disappoint me. Highly recommended.

title: Great 4G phone at a Great Price
text:
This is my second Hydro Series phone from Boost Mobile with my first being a C5170 first generation Hydro. First off I have to say that there is no learning curve from upgrading from Ice Cream Sandwich to KitKat. So that was one headache I avoided like when I upgraded to ICS from Gingerbread.

The main reason I bought the Kyocera Hydro Icon was because I dropped my first generation Hydro from a rooftop and the volume buttons popped out, but I was wanting to upgrade for the 4G capability anyway. I live in Tulsa, Oklahoma which has great 4G coverage, at least when you are outdoors. I live in a basement apartment which faces away from the cell tower, and the lobal effects from that tower means I only get one or two bars of signal strength in my apartment. One thing that upset me about the Sprint/Boost Mobile 4G coverage maps is that they show total 4G coverage for a county that only has one or two 4G towers. So while visiting my father in rural Cherokee County I was left with a very weak 3G coverage that is set up for the Oklahoma Highway Patrol cruiser laptops. Other than that, I love this phone.

Pros:
A great phone if you cannot afford an iPhone or Galaxy.
Is wireless magnetic induction charging capable with PMA chargers, and the induction coil is already built into the rear case of the ICON. Amazon sells a very cheap Duracell Double PMA charger.
The Smart Sonic Receiver sounds a little tinny, but is very audible in noisy environments.
Has a few built in apps like a flashlight timer/stopwatch and an Accuweather widget so you don't have to worry about downloading unsecure apps.
The phone has an unlocked FM Radio chip and comes with the NextRadio app that doesn't eat up data. You will need a wired headset or headphones to act as an antenna for the FM Radio chip.
Unlockable SIM chip. I guess that may come in handy if you travel overseas.
Four gigabytes of internal storage, so you can fill your SD card with music and movies and not full of apps.
Water Resistant. Kyocera says waterproof, but I say waterproof does not come with a depth limit nor time limit

Cons:
Sprint/Boost Mobile bloatware. The worst offenders are Connection Optimizer, Mobile ID, Boost Zone and the Lumen Toolbar. You can disable Connection Optimizer and the Lumen Toolbar, but they re-enable themselves when you restart the phone. But at least the Lumen Toolbar is not compatible with Firefox Browser.

title: Overall good with only a few issues
text:
**** UPDATE: Still a great phone nearly a year later, but will no longer work in the U.S. due to VoIP and Enhanced LTE requirements. THIS PHONE IS NO LONGER COMPATIBLE FOR ACTIVATION ON AT&T OR T-MOBILE. If you are on AT&T now with a Redmi Note 8, it will work for a period of time, but eventually will not be able to handle voice calls. New ones cannot be activated at all.

ORIGINAL REVIEW: I waited until I have been using the phone for a couple of weeks to write this. I wasn't sure about buying an international phone for use in the US and from a company I was unfamiliar with in terms of hands-on experience. This phone turns out to be a quality product. I won't run down all the specs as you can read them for yourself.

One thing I felt the need to do was install a third party launcher first thing. I don't like the MIUI much and I am used to being able to remove any or all icons from any home screen. You cannot with the stock launcher on this phone. Worse, there is no easy access to the app drawer, leaving you with a more iPhone-like experience. I don't like that experience *** UPDATE - You can now remove home screen icons and there is a setting to enable the app drawer with the MIUI 12 update

Battery life is good. Cell signals have been solid. Sound is good. Camera is very good. Performance is very decent and the software is stable. One thing I really appreciate is the fact that it has a notification LED and I really like the way it is implemented. It is easy enough to see when blinking, but it's actually quite subtle at the same time. Not distracting or obnoxious. Very good balance there.

I have had no issues using this phone on the AT&T network in the US. Solid connections and data speeds that are at least as good as other US based phones I have used. If you are in the US and are thinking about this phone, I would recommend that you download a free app that shows you your current phones cell connection info. There are several such apps available. Those apps will tell you which LTE bands you are currently using so you can see if this phone has those bands. Check the LTE band info on your current phone for a few days in different locations to see all the bands that you might need. If you can match those up to this phone's bands, you should be all set. If not, then you should avoid this one.

There have been reports of advertisements on this phone. You can go into Security and Privacy and disable the ads or do like I did and use a 3rd party launcher like Nova or Evie etc. Also I don't use the preinstalled apps.

Overall this phone is worth the price if you like the out-of-box experience OR don't mind using third party launchers and doing some of your own personalizing.

title: I'd Rather Have a Different Phone
text: I got this phone because of the price for the features but I prefer my old phone despite this one being slightly more advanced. The finger recognition is in the WORST spot. Why put it on the on button? Every time I press it I end up unlocking my phone when I just want to see the time and it gets confused when I want to turn it off because it thinks I am trying to use my finger. It also comes on too often. I press the off button to turn it off and when it finally does it comes back on at the slightest touch. My old phone allowed you to double tap the screen in order to turn it on or off, but this one makes it stay off unless you press the dreaded power button. The battery life sucks. It charges way too slowly and drain fast. I just got this so this shouldn't be the case and my last phone lasted longer despite all the time I had it. I think the front camera could be better, but it is an android. The feature that tells the weather is not accurate by any means. The screenshot feature is not convenient and I am not sure what it's called but that feature that allows you to look at the recently used apps and swipe them is not convenient either. You have to be in another app to use and not not the home screen. Not sure why that is a thing. I could probably think of more things that annoy me about this, but all that was off the top of my head. It has good features like the audio, but it lacks so much that I had to focus on them.

text: I purchased the 535 dual sim because I'm planning a trip to the UK in the future and I wanted the flexibility of purchasing a SIM there and getting phone service while on vacation.  I had read good reviews of the phone so I was interested to try it out.  The larger screen size is a definite advantage over the smaller 520 and 521 phones I was accustomed to using.  The phone is responsive and setup as with all Nokia's is a snap.  The two deal breakers on this phone are the quality of the phone and cell phone reception.  I have become accustomed to making calls at my desk at work and at home with my older phones but with the 535, I'd have to go outside at work in order to receive or make a call.  The clarity of videos and stills was also noticeably inferior to what I am accustomed to shooting on my economy Nokias.  I had expected a step up from the 520 and 521 but I was disappointed.  Still the phone does have many features going for it but for me being able to conveniently make calls and record some images for documentation just would not work out.

text:
We bought this phone to use while we are sailing in the bahamas and it works great. We went to the BaTelCo office and bought a sim card and minutes and had them set up an online account so we could top-up via internet. The phone works great, stays charged quite a while, has a radio you can use without ear buds, and a light or "torch" which is great when we get back late.

title: Best phone for the price!
text: I have owned this phone for 3 days and can say it's a tremendous upgrade from the Samsung J3 phone with 8GB of storage and 2 GB or RAM. I spent an extra $50 and upgraded to the 5th generation model that includes 4GB of RAM instead of 2GB, plus 64GB of memory instead of 32GB. The memory doesn't matter because for $20 you can buy a 20GB micro card, but the 4GB RAM is significant because when I check RAM usage its always between 2 and 3 (never over 3), but if I only had 2GB this device would be bogged down significantly. Aside from that all the "Moto" hand gestures are really great. When I twist my wrist quickly twice the camera instantly turns on and ready to shoot before I look at the screen - Amazing. I missed so many pictures with my old Samsung waiting to open the camera app. All the unlock screen options are a bit over-whelming. I have face detection (yes there is a built in app for face detection), finger print pad, pattern from 12 fixed dots or type in a password. Whew. I use none of them... Bottom line is that this model phone is blazing fast, has a bright screen, has all the features of a $1,000 phone and more. Unless it breaks or begins to have problems, this is the best phone for the price.

title: Horrible Phone.
text:
I bought this phone to have as a backup for a BV9900 Pro, in case I broke it. I did eventually break it and had to use this phone.

Now this phone is absolutely horrible. Out of the thousands of dollars of things I purchased in 2023, this is the thing I regret buying most.

This phone reminds me of the $20 phones that Cricket used to sell in 2010. It is so slow that you have to be a Zen master to deal with the app or website load times. Its pretty much torture to use this phone and I cannot count the number of times I have restrained myself from throwing this phone against a wall or stomping it to bits.

The screen is so dim that you can barely use it outside with sunglasses. The screen also barely responds to clicks and this is ultra irritating because apps regularly take a few seconds to respond to clicks. So this means that if you buy this, you should get used to waiting 3 seconds after you click the screen to see if the phone actually responds or to see if the screen actually detected your finger clicking. Infuriating.

The battery is complete trash. Takes 12 hours for a full charge. If you wake up on a Saturday morning and use this phone for 3 hours, the battery will be under 40% and require about 8 hours of charging to get back to full.

Also the phone regularly turns itself back on when you turn it off so I recommend keeping the battery saver on constantly and also carrying a charging block. If you have a job that requires you to be available by phone, forget about it. If you travel a lot and need navigation to get around, forget about it. Horrible GPS and the battery dies quicker.

I've lost this phone in my house before a flight and tried to call it. Straight to voicemail, over and over. Missed my flight. I eventually found it and it never received any of the calls. Some people cannot call me on this phone no matter how many times they dial.

Im posting this from a new BL8800 Pro, which is like a bigger, nicer BV9900 Pro that does 5G. Had a bad customer experience purchasing each of the three Blackviews. If you are thinking of buying this, dont. Save your dollars and buy one of the Blackview FLIR equipped flagship phones instead, but expect bad customer service.

The only people I would recommend this to are 1) people switching from a ten year old phone and 2) people switching from a flip phone.

One star.

title: Complete Junk
text:
There is no other way to describe this phone. A disappointment because up until now, all of my LG phones have been good. This phone arrived locked. The default lock code is normally the last 4 digits of the phone number. That was of no value because the phone had not been activated and had no phone number. I spoke with people at TracFone and LG. We tried using different 4 number codes to unlock the phone with no success. We tried numerous ways to do a factory reset on the phone with no success. In the course of all this, the phone somehow called 911, even though it had not been activated. This caused problems with the local authorities. The Unlock button is right next to the Emergency button. A poor placement of these buttons. I can see this would be an ongoing problem with this phone. The last TracFone agent I spoke with told me I should return the phone as defective. Enough of this for sure.

An update... Since this fiasco, I have discovered: Even prior to the phone being activated, it does have a phone number. The number may be something like: 000 000 2436 . Before you do Anything else with this phone, write down the last 4 digits of the phone number. This is the Lock Code. The phone number can be found in the Prepaid menu or in Settings. If the phone locks for some reason, you will need this code to unlock it. Otherwise, the phone will become useless if it accidentally gets locked. This lock code will change once the phone is activated and a phone number is issued. The default lock code will be the last 4 digits of the phone number.

title: Great "Bang for the Buck!!"
text:
Good Transaction and phone so far. Its design makes it a VERY attractive device. It's a nice stylish entry level smartphone with an excellent display that looks similar to a Flagship/High Dollar phone quality wise. The battery life isn't that great for a smartphone in this day and time and the phone doesn't wirelessly charge. You need to use a certain Qi-compatible wireless charging pad, to charge this phone. I don't want to but a fourth wireless charging pad and I have to charge it daily. I sometimes need to close an app, text... when the device stalls while processing. That detracts from what could make this an excellent smartphone. There's not a lot of memory on this device. You definitely need to buy an additional memory card. I had to manually load the pictures on to my SD card to transfer them on to the G7 Fit.

The main reason to buying this is the "Bang for the Buck. If you can live with drawbacks like battery life, device running warm, and occasional processing taking longer than a higher end phones, then you will get a performance that few other entry level or midrange smartphones offer (My last phone was a Galaxy S10+. So I'm used to faster processing speeds ((But I'm comparing a $900+ phone to a $169.00 phone.)). Ultimately, the phone is best suited people who aren't on the phone constantly, watching lots of YouTube videos, gaming... and have access to a power source. It would be a GREAT kids entry level phone since it's shock and water resistant (A must for 8-12 year old's or careless teens), and a great "Bang for the Buck."

title: Bluetooth/Battery support is so-so, but otherwise nice phone
text:
The battery in this phone is tiny, so with regular use I charge it atleast every other day.

It does not function perfectly with my Motorola HS850 Bluetooth Headset, meaning I cannot use the voice-dial/redial features built into the headset as expected.

Otherwise, this phone does SMS messaging (so no more logging onto the web for text-messages), has a clean interface, and the sliding keypad allows for convenient text-viewing and call-answering/ending.

Its footprint is small, also, so it fits comfortable in the pocket or small purse.

Also, the antenna is built in, and the phone still maintains great reception.

The only beef is that the slide-out keypad is somewhat flimsy-feeling, since it is plastic, but it maintains well.

Overall, this phone serves its purpose very well, despite lacking a longer batterylife and better Bluetooth v1.2 support.

title: True Zorch! Three steps forward if you need them.
text:
First, my install was simple, no sync problems. Activation was simple; and I was up and running in under an hour. What slowed me down was attempting to install Vindigo and Zagot for MS Mobile. They don't work yet, and I miss their utility. I had none of the problems as described in sync-ing and I am very impressed how easy the system downloaded the audible player and audible books to the SD card.

Second. This is not a Palm, in that the features are not as clear, but there are in the order of ten times more features programs and settings that can help you. In sum, it is to your advantage the way having a modern laptop of any OS is more helpful than a TRS 80. So having started with a Treo 180; a Treo 300; a 600 and a 650 now I have this 700w, there is no question in my mind that what you get is much more power: Zorch as Prof. Soloway likes to say. And it is a lot of Zorch. I walk around listening to an audio book -- not on Bluetooth due to some reason -- email comes in, I can respond. A phone call arrives, the audible player knows to stop; I take the call; finish; the audible player continues the book. The same works with music.

Finally and most importantly there is a five to ten times increase in download speed. This means everything if you Google some information during a conversation or if you need to look something up while you read Ted Koppel's comments in the NYT Select section. Having page loads occur in a snap, email come in fast, having your search results returned in the middle of the conversation rather than after everyone has gone onto the next topic -- leaving you still attempting to find the historical or scientific fact -- is simply worth a whole lot. Speed kills, in the metaphorical sense.

Can we complain about MS design, sure? Do we get to waste another half day to a day learning a new toy, sure. Is there some pain? Sure! But when we are working do we get this significantly increased Zorch for our personal use. Yes Sir! Praise goes to the techno Gods for this is a truly amazing personal computational device.

title: My Verizon experience
text:
I just got the phone, so right now, this review is mostly just about my experience getting it to work on Verizon...
Highlights so this isn't a long read:
- Verizon guy didn't have a problem scanning the bar code on the box to add the phone to my account
- After power on with new sim card, phone showed signal and data connection
--While the data connection worked, I couldn't place or receive calls (got "call ended" as soon as I placed a call)
- With the new sim card in my old phone (using a nano->micro sim adapter) when I tried to make a call I got something like "This sim card is activated on a different phone/line"
- After putting the new sim card back in the Xcover Pro, everything looked the same (as far as signal bars and data connection), but I was now able to make and receive calls!
- Voicemail does work by dialing *86 or your whole phone number

So, while it was annoying/concerning everything didn't work flawlessly like a "normal" phone, it was great I didn't have any other problems. It was amusing when the Verizon guy asked me to give him the phone so he could put the sim card in, he went, "Whoa..." when I popped the back cover off. :)

My only comment on the phone itself an this time is: Wow, this thing is heavy! It weighs 1.1 ounces more than my old Galaxy S5 with a larger-than normal "extended "battery!

title: Too slow for the average user.
text:
EDIT: After living with this phone for a few months I'm dropping my rating to two stars.

Purchased this online directly from TracFone on sale for $30. Seemed like a good deal at the time...

Lasted about 4 or 5 months before the phone mic stopped working. Seems like low end ZTE phones suffer from this. I've heard it's from the mic's dust cover getting dislodged and covering the mic. Can't say for sure. Other issues are as follows, and persisted the whole time I owned the phone.

Screen:
Occasionally the screen will refuse to turn on. Buttons will light up but are unresponsive. This requires you to pull out the battery and restart the phone. Snap cases are a bad idea because you'll just break the clasps from having to remove it so often.

Some phone's proximity sensors are poorly calibrated, meaning you pull your face away from phone while making a call and the screen doesn't come back on. This means, yep, pulling out the battery to end the call. ZTE does have a calibration app to fix this though (worked for me).

Speed/Responsiveness:
Don't set your expectations too high. Only has a single core processor. If you buy this phone, get used to seeing "Unfortunately, <app name> has stopped." regularly. Loading apps is slow. Running multiple apps isn't advisable. You hit the home button and it takes five seconds to load.

Some websites will straight up freeze and become unresponsive in any mobile browser. Others take several seconds to register a swipe to scroll up or down.

Swipes frequently register as a tap, which means loading links when you don't mean to. A lot.

Playing video is a bit of a stretch. Embedded videos in Instagram would play fine, but anything over 240p on Youtube would stutter badly. If you're lucky you'd get audio but the video would freeze.

Data & WiFi Reception:
WiFi reception sucks. Really sucks. If the WiFi where you are is somewhat iffy, you're not getting a connection. Trying to use anybody's free WiFi is going to turn you into a bitter, angry person. 3G reception is just okay.

Call Reception:
Pretty good, actually. And the speaker is loud enough to make calls in noisier environments.

Battery:
Not bad. Not great. If I charge to full in the morning I can usually wait til evening to charge it again. That's with the screen on for at least a couple of hours reading articles, along with phone calls and texting.

Music:
One of the biggest disappointments. The stock music app will stop randomly, or it will start playing a random song from a different album even if shuffle isn't turned on (my phone seems to love Peter Gabriel's "Passion" album).

Google Play music suffers from the random stoppage on this phone as well. My old clamshell Motorola Razor could play music without freezing.

Seems to handle Spotify streaming okay though.

Additionally, it is REALLY picky about tagging. If anything aside from song name or track number is different from file to file on a single album, it will list them as coming from separate albums.

In conclusion, I just don't think the ZTE Valet is really up to providing what most people expect out of an smartphone. Yes, it's exceptionally cheap but that doesn't mean it's a great deal. You get what you pay for. The phone that replaced this was an LG Optimus Fuel that Tracfone was selling for $10 refurbished. MUCH better phone.

If all you do is text, call, and check emails, I'm sure the Valet would work fine. Anything else involves mild to moderate frustration.

Pros and Cons:

Great sound quality for both calls and replaying video and music.

NOT happy with:
Lack of flash for photos. (what WERE you thinking??)
Lack of sufficient memory for web browsing, using apps, downloads, etc. Phone will simply shut off whatever app you are using right in the middle of what you're doing. Why why why?? I could live without a flash, ok, but why did you cheap out on memory??
Also, has a pretty old version of Android, sufficient for my needs right now, but I'm running into situations were sites/apps simply won't work, won't connect, won't download etc. (error msg...your phone/version is not compatible, etc.) And, you can't upgrade to a newer version. Sucky.

I know this phone has been out for quite awhile, few years at least, but I didn't want to spend a bamillion dollars on a phone.

If I could find a phone with this footprint and the hard buttons, but with a flash and enough memory to perform and to perhaps upgrade a tiny bit, I would buy it in a microsecond.

After years of buying pricier phones, decided to try Motorola. This phone is my 3rd Moto. I kept upgrading when new model came out. I have had the phone for a year and 1 month now. I'm on T-Mobile, so not sure if it's their issue. My husband has same phone in blue, he sometimes has same issues with calls/texts. We both noticed after update our batteries do not last as long as they use to and phone runs poorly. I have lost faith in cellphones that actually last. These companies don't build them to last because they just want more money. So I'm at the point where I don't think it matters if you buy an outrageous $1000 phone or spend $200, they are all garbage in a year! I am now on the hunt for a new phone. Before these issues, the phone was good and did what I needed. I recommend it only if you go into the purchase knowing you will be back phone shopping in a year or less.

title: Be careful about buying Renewed phones.
text: This particular phone that I purchased was a renewed phone specifically for Verizon which is my carrier. It did not work and I sent it back the next day. The phone would not charge. It recognized that the charger was present, but had the message that it could not charge at this time. Also the phone would not connect to my Verizon network. The SIM card worked on my other Motorola phone but not this one. I spent hours trying to figure out what the problem was and all the phone wanted to do was run diagnostic checks which I had never seen before. Even after the check it still did not work. The phone arrived with 72% battery life and once I had gotten down to about 23% battery life I decided that the phone was just not capable of working. I returned it the next day. Renewed phones are a crap shoot. In some cases they may be a phone that someone had for a day or two and just didn't care for so they returned it, or they can be something where there was some real bad internal damage done and while it looks good on the outside it's a hot mess on the inside. You get what you pay for. I ended up just going to Verizon and bought the Moto 4 from them, it cost $150 more, but since I paid for it in full I am getting $5.38 off a month as a discount which over 24 months is just about $130 so the savings is almost the same and there are no headaches.

title: Great performance for the money!
text:
My iPhone died recently so my fiancé bought me this phone after his boss recommended it. I'm surprised to see how well it works, I use my phone a lot and so far it's been working great for me. The battery will last up to 2 days on one charge if I play games or browse the internet on it a lot; without playing games I can do about 3 days on a single charge. Not as many days as advertised but still better than current high end phones, for such a small price.

I had a micro sim card I used with my iPhone and all I had to do was pop the card into this phone to get access to most of the features on my phone plan. The only thing that isn't working right is text messaging, I can't receive pictures in texts and my voicemail-to-text feature doesn't work. I believe there's a fix for these problems, I just haven't got around to fixing it. Overall if you're wondering if you can use a sim card from a previous phone into this one the answer is YES! Just open up the back by carefully taking it off from the small dent in the back cover right above the volume buttons. It's very difficult to take off so you may have to very delicately use a knife or something else to get it off.

As far as hardware and software goes, Android performs well enough on this phone. I can play a lot of games on it and they run smoothly. The call quality is great on my end and I've been told it's great on the receiving end too. The default apps on the phone aren't great but with a few functional upgrades from the play store it becomes much easier to use. I won't be using the case that comes with the phone (mostly because it's really ugly lol) but it's nice that it came with one in case I need a backup case. I'm not using the screen protector that came with the phone either because I prefer my matte anti-fingerprint protector but again, it's nice that it came with one.

Overall it's a great phone and well worth the price! Obviously if you're looking for something that rivals the specs of the latest iPhone or Galaxy S this phone won't have the processing power you want but for this price it does everything I need it to.

title: Excellent phone, decent battery life
text:
Purchased this phone in August to replace a Sprint POS 4 function phone that I've had for a while. The phone is all around a great device. I'm divided on whether to write a lengthly review or just the bulleted pros cons list, but I'll got with the latter.

PROS:
- Very light
- Very thin
- Excellent 8 Mega-Pixel Camera w/ LED flash
- Comes with ~6.5GB internal phone memory
- Multi-tasking is smooth/seemless
- MP3 playback is excellent
- Web browsing is smooth
- Most all apps that you would need are free
- Battery life for talk is very good
- Touch screen is just right sensitivity wise. On screen keyboard, when turned sideways is pretty good

CONS
- Battery life while texting or browsing the web is pretty bad (reaches half life in a matter of 1-2 hrs)
- In call phone reception isn't the greatest, but I'm still trying to diagnose whether this is a coverage issue or the phone itself (as of now I could go either way)
- Comes with several annoying pre-installed apps that cannot be uninstalled. These apps also randomly run in the background. You can download a free app manager to kill these apps but they just auto launch again (probably a major player in the battery drain). This seems to be an issue with most Droid phones though, not just an Incredible issue.

title: If you wanna be unique and have an awesome phone, this would do it. Be aware people will ask What is that!?
text:
This is an amazing phone even if you compare it to other flagship phone from Samsung, LG, or HTC.
I love the phone body design, finger print, facial recognition, camera. I just want to point out that this phone takes an awesome pictures and the AI feature makes the pictures look stunning and very professional looking. The performance of this phone kills any Samsung galaxy phone I have ever used. The phone is super fast loads apps quickly.

I just want to point out an issue I had, where the Google maps will run slow and will crash. The solution to that problem is simple disable full screen for Google maps, or reduce the resolution of the screen to lower resolution setting. Anyway, this is clearly a problem from Google's part where did not take account into full screen app support specially for these new high resolution phones like this one.

title: Curved edges are a dumb idea!
text:
I have the 512GB version and I'm almost on the edge of returning it, but I'll try it for a few more days. The only really annoying problem I find with this phone is on the curved edge it has, making it so that everytime you type something, if your hand or fingers are misplaced then you will automatically touch something in the screen. My case just arrived, it's actually helped but without a case this phone is almost unusable. For such an expensive phone I would have expected any human with a brain would have done tests at Samsung to see if the curved edges actually make sense. I prefer a square edge screen to avoid that problem. But whatevs we'll see. Very disappointed with the design.

Edit: Few weeks later update - I was able to get a screen protector, that along with the case has solved or mostly solved the issue with the edge. I'm kind of liking the edge, however no company should ever sacrifice performance through design, and the issues shouldn't have to be solved with or without a screen protector or a case. The battery life could be improved, this phone uses a lot of power, 6,000 mAh could be ideal. The camera could be improved as well, I tried taking a picture of my license the other day and the phone was showing the details on the letters of the license perfectly fine on the screen, but once I took the picture the picture itself wouldn't show perfect details on the letters of the license, I tried in multiple ways with different lighting and the issue continued, I was eventually able to get an ideal license picture after about 20 mins, I believe this issue only happens with close up pictures. Upgraded from a Moto G7 Power the phone is obviously faster and a nice thing I noticed on the speedtest was the internet MBPS DL Speed: on my G7 Power Speedtest would cap at 100 MBPS or so and with the Note 20 Ultra it would cap at 400 MBPS or so. I'm also able to play games with the Note 20 Ultra which is a nice thing.

Hopefully Samsung reads this review and improves the phone for next time. I'm still going to keep the 2 Stars because to my understanding these are obvious issues that should have been fixed before shipping the phone. Not giving 1 Star because this phone is much better than my prior old phone.

Edit: Changed my stars from 2 to 1. The camera is terrible. It's blurry, it has problems focusing. The camera on my old Motorola G7 Power ($200 phone) is better than the Note 20 Ultra Camera ($1,400 phone). Ughhh, whatevs. Too late to be able to return it now.

title: I would advise against this model. The 2 I've had have screen issues.
text:
This phone worked great for about 6 months and then it became a nightmare! It started having screen issues after a software update or so it seems as there were no other changes that had been made to the phone. The screen would not come on bright enough to see what was on the phone. I then contacted Samsung customer service to try to figure out a fix. After trying several different things including clearing cache and even a factory reset it was determined I needed to take it to a repair store. Huh none exist that will mess with an X Cover Pro so it had to be sent to a Samsung facility in Texas. So after a week without my phone it was sent back and I was told there were no issues found. Well that is wonderful because upon unboxing my phone and attempting to turn on low and behold, "Same Issue". The screen was impossibility dim and it took several minutes of messing with it to get it to come up. (And yes adaptive brightness is turned off) So I was informed by another Samsung tech rep to "send it in again and have them look at it" the rep then said if they cannot figure anything out they will send me another phone of the same model. Well thats fair right. Or so I thought because after determining that they were unsure of what was wrong with the phone and I was owed a replacement they told me it would be 15 days before one would be sent out... Ok, my agitation is growing because after 2 days in shipping and another few days in the facility being looked at combined with the previous sending in I am now without the device for over a month.

But we haven't made it to the best part yet... The replacement does the same crap. After about a month it has started doing the same thing. The only thing that changed was another software update and it very well might just be coincidence. Although now I am not so gentle with the phone. I have found that when the issue happens if you smack the phone against your palm it will come on. Sometimes it takes once or twice sometimes more but Samsung wants me to play UPS tag with them again. Arrrrrg.
So if I may I would suggest to stay away from the X Cover Pro and find something a bit more common as it is great in theory but failed in use.

title: I Love it (See edit)
text:
EDIT:
Sep 27, 2015
I have completely thrown out my first initial review, as my first impressions were very quite harsh, too harsh to keep visible, I REALLY should have spent more time with this phone. The google play store is littered with much better UIs than the factory UI, currently using "Lucid Launcher" and I love it, it has made my experience probably 100x better than first impressions, I may not actually shoot it like i first wanted to. The phone and OS have become very quite easy to use through learning, trial and error, and full resets, not the best gaming device, get a tablet or more expensive large phone for upper tier gaming, but for simple games like driving and flying simulators, this is great. I do play ACR racing and it lags here and there, but it really heats up my phone, and it struggles on HD video playback also, especially in fast moving scenes, it'll skip 3 or 4 frames at the worst.

Checking all my banking (capital one, first kentucky, and paypal) have become a breeze with using their respective apps and has completely gotten rid of my guessing games I play with my banking, I'm horrible at keeping records of my spending, my wallet ATM book is still blank. This has made my life so much better, especially with banking, living paycheck to paycheck, you really need to keep an eye on it, and I've been VERY careful, I've already overdrafted once, i'm not gonna do that again. To stay on topic, I came from an LG 900G, and although this is a budget smartphone, it is an upgrade of up to, if not exceeding 1000 times, in my own perspective.

title: Pay as you go best seller!
text:
My best phone ever. Well, my son says I should have spent another $120 on a newer operating system but I think this 6.0 OS will be supported at least through the life of the phone's battery. I think Tracfone got it right this time by having the sim card already installed and not having to get it separately. I have had problems in the past with phone switch over but not this time. It was a breeze. Phone battery came 40% charged. I put in my extra 32GB sim card and the battery and let it charge while I pulled up my Tracfone account on a computer. You need to be at a wifi location where you know it's passcode. After you turn the phone on, it guides you through and uses the internet to set things up. Using wifi it pulled all my old phone apps and settings and Google drive files over from my old phone. I had stored my old pics and data onto a laptop ahead of time just in case.
The only thing I did on the Tracfone website was give the new phone's serial number and tell them I wanted to keep the same number. Left the phone on and waited. About 15 minutes later the phone chirped and dinged and I had a text saying my phone number was changed over. The phone through Samsung has a way to geo-locate your phone through their website. Google also allows you add a voice unlock after you set up the passcode.
The earpiece and speaker sound is good; pictures and video better than my old phone. Buttons on my phone are not stiff and work through the OEGO defender case just fine. I think I will like this OS better once I get used to it. There are useful apps and I spent the rest of the day playing with setup. Easy to use. Even one-handed thumb use is naturally easy. Much lighter weight and easier to hold than my old phone and same sized screen. Processor speed I would describe as instantaneous.
I think the J3 Luna is a great value and deserves its place as a best seller for the pay as you go phone user.

title: Nice fast phone with a couple of short comings
text:
I've come from using some of the biggest names in the cell phone industry. When I seen this phone, I read quite a few reviews and decided to try it. So here's my first impressions of the BLU F91 5G as a daily driver.

After unboxing the phone feels of nice quality it doesn't feel cheap. I really like the Blue color. After I was able to get everything loaded I was able to really play with this devices settings and check out it's performance. The screen is nice and makes this phone look more expensive than it really is. Only 60 hz refresh rate. Overall, the usual usage of social and media content is good. I also performed a network speed test on my TMobile network. I'm seeing about 250 download and about 40 upload, which isn't too bad. Web pages seem to load as quick as the big name brands. Call quality is nice and clear. I believe that this phone doesn't support wifi calling. So overall at $230 its pretty good.

Now, for the short comings.

One of my biggest gripes is the audio is a single speaker and it's not the loudest and the sound is a little thin. It's not terrible but could have been better. On my media player I was able to adjust the EQ to tailor in some better sound which helped a little bit. Stereo speakers here would've really helped this device. The other short coming of this device is the charging speed. While in use the phone takes FOREVER to top off from about 60% with the included 18 watt charging brick. BLU should've upped the charging speed to a minimum of 30 watt charge. Obviously when not in use it will charge faster. Wireless charging is also included with this phone. I like the fact that you can set it on the charging pad and got to bed, and it will be fully charged in the morning. Wifi calling would have been a nice addition. If Blu would have offered this device with these 3 other options, I believe they would've had a phone that wouldve been at the top of the midrange phones rivaling some flagship devices.

In conclusion, the Blu F91 5g is a budget phone that targets midrange phones costing 2 times as much. The hardware is pretty good for the $$$. I'm going to make my decision here in the next day or 2 to keep it or return it. I want to give the device a fair shake. I'll edit this post if anything else positive or negative come up with the phone.

Edit: My Blu f91 data stopped loading web pages. I went in and reset network settings and that fixed the issue. Then I had to reset network settings again. Then again the day after that. It seems to be a software or hardware issue, so I decided to return the device. It's a shame, because I had high hopes for the device and I really kinda liked it. Demoted to 1 star.

title: BLU Takes It Up A Notch
text:
Having tested one of BLU's earlier (Studio) cellphone models, I was curious to see how this new model fared. I can honestly say that this phone does not disappoint.

Unlike the previous BLU model I tested, the Energy X model has a very solid feel to it. Part of that seems to be due to an improved case that uses a higher grade of plastic. Part is due to a heavier, longer-lasting 4,000 mAh internal battery. Combine that with an even larger 5.5" screen and you have all the ingredients for a phone that looks, feels and operates far beyond any expectations one should have for a cellphone that sells for well under $200.

On the plus side, this model's expansive 5.5" display is bright, crisp and very highly responsive. It's quad core processor gives it more than enough juice to stream both audio and video. Resolution-wise, you will not get the same quality picture as an iPhone or a Samsung Galaxy, but it is quite adequate for viewing the usual content you would normally be watching on a 5.5" screen.

The phone's battery performance is great on standby, but drains a bit faster than other phones I have used when running applications. I suspect that the phone's ultra-bright, oversized screen is the main culprit when it comes to battery drain. Fortunately, the phone's internal battery charges up to 4,000 mAh, so you can go longer without recharging than with most phones. The phone's plain-vanilla Android OS is a joy to set up as compared to most phones. You will not find any of the bloatware common to phones you will get directly from your carrier, or even direct from most manufacturers like Samsung. No features are blocked or locked, that includes the ability to tether or operate your phone as a portable wi-fi hotspot.

With all that said, there are obviously some shortcomings with a phone this inexpensive. These mostly fall under the category of "frills" as far as I am concerned, but they may be more important to you. The most obvious shortcoming of this phone is its camera. If you want to record HD video or take high-resolution pictures, this is definitely not the phone for you. It's 8 MP front-facing camera operates slowly and produces sub-par pictures as compared to most modern smartphones. So, don't get your hopes up when it comes to taking pictures.

The second most obvious shortcoming is the phone's memory, or lack thereof. 8GB of internal memory and 1GB of RAM don't go a long way if you run a lot of memory intensive apps on your phone. You can add up to 64GB of memory using a micro SD card, but SD cards operate at slower speeds than RAM, so choose your apps (and where you store them) carefully. If you do add a micro SD card for extra memory, be sure to buy a Class 10 card. They may run you a few dollars more, but they seem to run much faster and more reliable than the cheaper Class 4 cards.

Another oddball "feature" is the phone's use of removable "cartridges" to store both the micro SD card and the SIM (actually, SIMS, since it holds up to two SIM cards). The phone comes with a tiny "key" you need to use to insert or remove the memory or SIM. You could just as easily use a paperclip, but the fact that these tiny cartridges could become so easily lost or broken while swapping memory or SIM cards is a bit worrisome. If you are the type of person who almost never accesses the SIM or SD card, this should not be an issue. If you swap these frequently, I would stay away from this model though.

The last downside I will mention is the phone's battery. While it has great battery life, the inability to swap batteries or quick-charge is a bit of a disappointment. I think that BLU went the wrong direction in making the battery non-swappable, but I'm guessing that accounts for how they kept the price of the phone so low.

Altogether, this is an impressive looking phone with an easy to read screen, tons of features and plenty of battery life. While it does not measure up to an iPhone or Samsung Galaxy when it comes to specs, what you do get for the price is pretty awesome. With an unlocked GSM smartphone with dual SIMS, quad core processor and 5.5" display for under $200 you can hardly go wrong.

I had the Samsung S9 for five years prior to this phone, and I kept the screen clean with alcohol wipes, but when I try it with this phone, it just smears more, never gets clean/clear, and the screen just seems like a different kind of glass than what is normally on phones.  Also, I can see a two inch long horizontal line of what looks like a streak of water under the screen about an inch from the top, and it's visible all the time, so for that reason, and the issue with the screen, I'm not sure yet if I will keep this phone.  I believe I have 90 days, or at least I hope that is the case.  Other than that, it works well and no issues so far.

text:
Plenty of other reviews will tell you all about this phone. I'm pretty happy with it -- enough so that I jumped ship from AT&T after 15 years with them once I heard they weren't going to support it.

However, I rate Amazon 1-star on service. I ordered this and was given an estimated shipping date that was over one month away. I found it elsewhere for the same $97 + contract price and the phone was delivered in three days.

title: Good phone, small areas of improvement needed, still great for price
text:
This was a gift for my dad. Here are my notes from using the phone and setting it up for him, and then having to troubleshoot over the phone with him:
1) Some color on the keys to differentiate between the buttons Similar to other phones, green on send and red on end buttons.
2) If when the menu was up, the selection you were on were more clear, that would be great.
3) Needs better instructions. Even a .pdf on the web.
4) Louder would be better (for my hearing impaired dad).

Pros
1) Small form
2) Battery lasts a long time for him (non texter, few calls)
3) Pretty simple interface, but still a small learning curve that could be helped with written instructions
4) Great cheap price

Really the price is hard to be beat and the above recommendations would make this a 5 Star cheap phone. At the price point, I got what I expected!

title: Works great on Sprint
text: I've had previous generations of the Moto E, first and second, and this is by far the best yet. This phone in previous years would have cost closer to $200 likely. It is far and away the best budget smartphone you can get. I'm using it on Sprint and it works flawlessly. No, it is not going to replace a flagship phone by Samsung or LG or one of Motorola's flagships, but it isn't meant for that. The camera is not going to blow anyone away, it is really there as a utility and takes occasionally decent shots, but if you're a photographer don't harbor any illusions that this is meant for you. It is worth it if you are looking for the very latest version of Android (something not even today's flagships can claim) and don't need blazing fast speeds to do hardcore mobile gaming, nor if you need a screen with an outrageous and completely unnecessary QHD resolution.

title: A phone for the Me's of the world!
text:
I love this phone. The battery life is perfect for me as I forget to charge my phone sometimes and I won't miss my alarm. The fingerprint reader is magic since you can save multiple fingerprints I can unlock it with either hand or with a weird grip.
The durability is really important and makes me feel comfortable actually using my phone (I'm a carpenter). I got this after I kept breaking phones and, in protest, went months without one. I buckled since I have family and business but I'm happy.
The sound is pretty good, adaptive screen brightness is interesting and more convenient than I thought it'd be, display is crisp. As with these sweet unlocked phones, all I did was put in the SIM card and it started going!
Sometimes the WiFi connection is touchy and will start using data without letting me know, which is annoying but tolerable. There are a few bloatware apps I wish I could get rid of, but it's negligible. I wish there were more replacement parts available as to me that goes hand in hand with rugged phones. I have not used the dual SIM but like the concept.
This was an off-the-cuff bullet point review but it sums up how I feel about this phone. I'd buy it again.

title: Avoid
text:
First, I want to mention that this is review is not a reflection of the seller in any way. I purchased the phone through T-Mobile which the only carrier for this phone. None of the reviews I saw mentioned the troubles I've discovered, so I wanted to ensure this information was put out to other potential buyers, though I suspect there won't be many more given that T-Mobile seems to have stopped selling this phone.

Toughness: I've had the phone for around 9 months and have had no problems, except one - the front screen broke. This is not the touch-screen, but the screen that is on the top of the closed phone. It has a *glass* cover over it. For a phone built with construction workers in mind, using a glass screen is one massive face-palm of a mistake.

Battery: I don't use my phone excessively - one of the reasons I wanted a simple flip phone to begin with - so I can't say everyone will be happy, but it seems like it has decent life. I usually only charge it once every few days, but, again, that's with minimal use.

Calling / Texting: Work fine, except for the problems listed below (not being able to use the physical buttons and touch screen being too small).

Touch Screen / Buttons: The other big reason I wanted a flip phone was because I didn't want it to do much more than text and call, but the thought of possibly using google maps with this phone was enticing.
1) The physical buttons can't reliably be used. A single press often results in multiple entries; if I press the "6" button, there's a very good chance it will input "66".
2) The touch screen is too small to be used reliably. I often have to poke the same spot several times to achieve what I want.
3) Google maps is entirely unusable with a screen so small. All the extra buttons Google Maps adds to the interface means you only get about 1 third of the actual screen size, which is already very small.

title: Best value device. I love it
text:
I am who you would consider a pro user. I make apps for both iOS and Android and fully understand both the inner and outer workings of electronic devices such as smart phones. This phone is hands down the best device you can get for the price at the time of this review.
It doesn't have the best screen, camera or chipset but you'd be hard pressed to find another phone that offers close to what this one offers given the price. So what are you looking for in a smart phone? I would say a great screen, solid battery life, NFC for mobile payments, Good cameras, Quality design and Intuitive operation system and smooth performance. This phone checks all the boxes. The screen resolution is 1080+ meaning it's just slightly higher in resolution than your standards FHD so text and images will appear bright, sharp and vibrant. The screen also supports a 120hz refresh rate just like those $1,000+ phones. The battery is BIG with over 5000mah battery cell this phone will last you 2 days on normal usage and 1 day if you're like me, a power user. But doesn't matter it will charge to 100% in little over 1 hr. Are you accustomed to mobile pay? Don't worry Google pay works here too. Design wise; it's a pretty standard design not ugly but I am not too much a fan of the camera layout on the back. The back is also plastic but feels good. And to be honest personally I prefer a plastic back as it's more durable than glass. The screen is covered with gorilla glass 6 which has excellent drop resistance. I've dropped mine about 3 times now and not a single scratch was found but still I would recommend keeping the plastic case that comes in the box on it until you purchase another one. Something else to point out is that this phone comes with a ir blaster so you can use it to control your TV and so on. Lastly, we have the camera and chipset. Camera is solid my sister as the s22 ultra and shots are identically in proper lighting. The s22 ultra shines when it comes on to HDR and detail though but to be honest I wouldn't care which camera I grabbed to go shoot because the difference isn't mind blowing. In the video depart this phone keeps up by offering 4k 30fps and other shooting modes like slow mo 240fps 1080p and some cool camera apps that make you shoot awesome B-rolls. For extras the phone as dual loud speakers. Side mounted finger print scanner. Can use two sims or 1 sim plus sd card upto about 512g *I think. Haptic feedback is good but not iphone level. Front camera is idk I don't use it. Volume buttons are clicky but not the best feeling. Supports the headphone jack. And runs on MIUI for POCO which is a good skin that tries to be like iOS current version 12.5 not sure if this phone will receive the new MIUI 13 update. Which is based on Android 12. The chipset is the snapdragon 860 and mine as 8 gigabytes of ram. Basically the phone is very fast and will play any game available at the highest settings. All that for under $300 come on no way an iPhone or a Samsung flagship as to cost over a thousand dollars. I recommend this phone.

title: A very specific phone for a very specific use case
text:
First off... I was trying to find an unlocked feature phone for under $100 that would run a Ting V1 SIM card (AKA Ting's MVNO spin of the Verizon network) in December 2020. This was the ONLY phone I could find that fit that bill. Hopefully that changes before long... but it's worth noting that it DID take the Ting V1 SIM and rocked it quite well. It would probably also work for StraightTalk and other Verizon resellers. This is no small thing...

However... the feature phone was for my 72 y.o. mother. For that use case, it TOTALLY didn't work out. At all. The phone runs a cut-down version of Android rebranded "MyOS". My mom is a major league luddite and COULD NOT work out how to use the Contacts stored in her phone. (Didn't help that I was trying to do this with her socially distanced, but a few masked meetings and carefully written out instruction sheets *still* didn't help.) It was far too easy for her to accidentally start EDITING a contact instead of calling one, which was SUCH crap design. Further, while it is a version of Android, I couldn't [1] disable entire apps (as my mom DESPISES texting and always insists I disable voicemail, texting, AND data on every phone), [2] install new apps, [3] use low-level hacking facilities like 'adb', nor [4] rearrange the layout of the launcher screen. Getting my mother to get used to drilling down through the lock screen over to the Contacts app, down through the list, and down to the specific phone number was asking too much. Further, the phone allows you to interact with the notifications area. Let me repeat that... a flip phone with a top line notifications area. That is just a fail. That damned notifications area confused the crap out of Mom. And it's mapped right to one of the top two navigation buttons. 🤦‍♂️ Far better would have been if they'd mapped "Contacts" instead of "Notification". And I must say, in my own limited time with the phone, while I COULD use it, I really didn't enjoy the experience. The bottom line is that you really need to be quite familiar with Android already to use this phone effectively, but you're still going to need to adjust to all the very weird ways Android was then adapted to be the core of a feature phone. I'm going to try to replace this phone with a Jethro SC490; it's also based on Android, but the adaptation to a feature phone seems to have gone WAY better; unfortunately, I'll need to swap Mom to an Ting X3 SIM, which will crap out when she's visiting my brother out of town. But there was simply no way to get her a phone on a Ting V1 SIM that she could actually use. The old 3G phones are now dead; this could replace them, but only if you're willing to fight with it a little and already know what you're doing.

So, the use case here is for somebody who wants an unlocked feature phone that can run on the Verizon network; may appreciate the ability to link to Google services, Facebook, and WhatsApp (all things I avoid); and would find a chopped down Android charming in spite of its quirks. I'm thinking this is for preteens on a short leash, middle aged people trying to reduce their screen addiction (but still want the ungodsly hell of Facebook?), or for anybody who really wants something without a touch screen that can still run Facebook or WhatsApp. It's an oddball device. It'll probably have more of a market when it finally drops under $30. Currently, at nearly $80 with tax, I honestly found it overpriced.

title: The facts of this phone
text:
This reviewer is a current owner of this phone and has service through the bright spot at target but, would caution buying this phone for following reasons
1. Reviewer has received email from bright spot indicating that they are shutting down bright spot as of first of 2016 and customers will be switched over to T-mobile
2) this conversion will take several steps - this reviewer went through process of step 1 and it was a 45 minute sign up to merely give address for T-Mobile SIM card to be sent. Remaining steps will require contacting bright spot to have phone unlocked which can't be done while on phone but , rather request has to be put in and somewhere between 2 and 14 days you will receive an email providing code to unlock phone, Then you will be sent a t mobile SIM card and t mobile will have to activate,
3) this phone operates on a system that apparently few other providers use - this reviewer checked with Verizon and AT and T and both indicated this phone( even unlocked) would not work on their systems.

The phone itself is a nice phone and if T-Mobile is the provider of choice might be a good selection but otherwise a pass.

title: Unlocked phone review

title: No significant complaints, so far...
text:
This is my first smartphone... albeit a lower-end one. I love it.

I've seen some complaints about the touchscreen being a bit resistive. I have long -- but blunt -- fingers, and no fingernails to speak of. I found it /was/ resistive, calibrated for actual touch, alone. I have a narrow stylus, and decided to re-calibrate it for use with that -- and haven't had a single issue, since.

Only other thing I've noticed -- and this could just be my particular phone, and not an issue with the model, itself -- is that it can be titchy about the temperature. Living in the Pacific NorthWet, winters here can be a bit... bi-polar, to say the least, and we'd been having a very odd, very cold late fall/early winter. If I keep my phone in my pocket (particularly one close-ish to my body), I have no problems. If I keep it in an outer coat pocket -- let alone use it outside for more than 10 mins without actually being on a call -- in 35 degrees or lower, the screen locks up, entirely. Though, with the former, it's only after coming in from intense cold if the apartment is stiflingly hot that does it.

It stands to reason... they're heat /and/ pressure sensitive. But, it's not really been an actual problem. More like a minor annoyance. All I need to do is put it briefly into sleep mode (just a few seconds), and it's fine, once it comes back out.

Other than those two things, there's just the general poor service coming from using Sprint towers, and some browser instability... which are not directly related to the phone, itself.

All in all, the Chorus has been a pretty good phone for one so inexpensive (I only paid $30, for mine ^_^ ).

text:

Add'l features will be added to the existing razer camera app - possibly 60fps 4k recording in Q1 '18...to be rolled out with Android 8.0. Visit Razer Insider for confirmation and future updates. title: Curb your enthusiasm and expections.
text:
Let me start by saying, with all of its shortcomings I'm about to say, I am comparing this to the Iphone SE from 2016. This phone is relevant and in many ways better than Iphone SE, but loses in some areas.

The camera vs. Iphone SE, if you have light, and time to focus, sure it rivals the Iphone SE. Iphone SE however does great in most situations and can capture motion, Iphone SE is just a better camera, thats all there is to it. I'd say the photos can lose up seventy percent of its focus even on paper text sheets if you do not focus correctly on the paperwork! That said, it seems to function ok with sunlight.

This leads to the second thing that makes Iphone SE superior, the screen itself. We should curb expectations and remember this is a 150$ phone, so there are going to be shortcuts. So the screen is quite crisp and response, and it can even play mild games like League of Legends WildRift at acceptable quality. It just falls so hard and fails so bad in sunlight! The screen simply cannot get bright enough in direct sunlight. This really kills the ability to read unless you can find some shade. This just sucks.

The amazing part is battery life, Its been 5 months now, and its solid, like heavy and long lasting. The phone truly can sit idle for days. Can be used for an alittle bit each day and be charged in 4-5 days. If your face is glued to the phone, then go seek help!

That leads to the other problem with the phone, IT really is too heavy. The phone is definitely more durable to abuse then iphone SE, but the weight of the phone itself means that this point is null, one bad angle drop on an edge and its all over. Mine is cracked after a three foot drop. Still seems to be fairly water proof with crack somehow, but now I cannot say in good faith its still a good idea to push this phones limit.

Loading apps on this quad core is not always faster than the Iphone SE, but its certainly more reliable, does not crash often, does not overheat in sunlight due to its natural thermal mass. It vs iphone SE hands down has supieror signal strength, getting coverage where Iphone SE thinks is a deadspot. This phone at the end of the day, is a fantastic phone, and appears to be better at the primary task at hand.

I think this would be a great phone for a young adult with tight budget, or for older people who just needs primary task of being a phone as clear objective without garbage loaded up on the phone. I am happy to use this phone for another year or two and believe this is a good deal.

That said, durability and camera quality may be misleading. And as someone coming from a company that lied and nerfed their batteries life for their iphones, even with this supposed slow charger, this is a huge step up from dedicated charging lifestyle at every potential part of the day.

title: Probably great...but it doesn't work on Verizon as advertised.
text: Seems like a very nice phone for the price. The 6GB of RAM shows with how smoothly it runs, the screen looks great, and, while I would prefer it to have an actual headphone port, other than that, the form factor is nice. Unfortunately, I bought it to use on Verizon, since it was advertised as working on Verizon as well as other carriers, and apparently BLU did not put an antenna into the phone capable of actually picking up a usable Verizon signal. It does NOT give an error that indicates the SIM card is invalid or anything like that, so I think it's set up with the software necessary to recognize a Verizon SIM. There are just no bars. Putting the exact same SIM into my old phone in the same exact location in my house yields several bars. The BLU VIVO XI+ gets none. The antenna probably just isn't the right hardware to actually pick up a Verizon signal.

Touchscreen is fine, keyboard is pretty basic. Would be nice to have "send" and "end call" buttons on the keypad, rather than having to access them through the touch screen. FM radio was fine--not super audio, but decent for the price of this phone.
