title: Close, but no cigar
text:
I was excited to get the Unihertz Titan Slim as T-Mobile no longer supports the BlackBerry Key 2 phone. The Titan Slim is the closest thing to the Key 2, but be warned:

The Titan Slim is anything but slim. It is a fat hunk of phone, double the thickness of the BlackBerry. The only thing slim about it is the screen is not as wide as the BlackBerry.

At the bottom of the screen, where nearly every other phone on the market would let you select Back, Home, and Open Apps, there is nothing but 1/4 inch of black glass. To go back, you have to either use the Back button which is on the top row of the keyboard, right next to the Home Button/fingerprint reader, which means if you miss the Back button and accidentally hit the Home Button, the screen collapses. The other way is to set up the screen so a flick from the right or left of the screen acts as the Back button. The problem with this is you will invariably flick when you don't mean to flick.

But let's get to the real problem: the kludgy keyboard. If you are like me and have touch capacitance issues, a keyboard is a must (In fact, I'm surprised the Americans with Disabilities Act doesn't help people with touch capacitance issues, but that's something for Congress to figure out). The Titan Slim keyboard sucks. I mean, it really sucks!

The SHIFT button is at the top left of the keyboard in a location that makes no sense. The ALT button is at the top right which makes selecting ( . , or any ALT icon on the right side of the keyboard difficult). The space bar is placed in the middle of the bottom row between the letters ZXCV and BNM. Here's the problem with this: after years of using keyboards with the space bar below these letters, every time you try to type N, you'll hit B and every time you try to type M, you'll press N. With all the wasted space on the bottom of the screen, Unihertz should have put the following keys at the bottom, under the letters: SHIFT, SYM, SPACE, ALT, RETURN. That would make this phone usable for work, but as it is, you're better off doing any serious typing via your computer by hooking up the computer and phone via software like Wondershare MirrorGo (itself, slow).

Next issue: No returns. As stated on the Unihertz site, if you buy the phone, you cannot return it unless you cancel your order while they are processing your order. This is ridiculous.

The facial recognition looks for you whenever movement is sensed and I've noticed leaving the phone on a table or car's cup holder or in your pocket will activate the facial recognition which then gets repeated false readings and you then have to use your pass code to unlock the phone. For some reason, pressing the power button does darken the screen, but it doesn't stop facial recognition from continuing to look for a face.

The good things about the Titan Slim, and yes, there are a few: battery life so far is excellent with a full-day's charge easily obtained. The small screen is clear and easy to read. The audio is good, not great, merely good. The phone comes with a rubber side and back case, which provides good grip. I attached a Lovehandle Phone Grip to the case and it makes holding the thick phone pretty good, but dang this phone is thick. It's so thick it won't sit in the phone cradle that works great with anything from BlackBerry, Samsung, Apple, Nokia, and Google. How thick is it? A BlackBerry Key 2 is 3/16 inch thick; the Titan Slim is 1/2 inch--that's 8/16--thick. It should have been named the Titan Tank.

One last thing: be prepared to be laughed at when you set the Titan Slim down on a table. Most everybody I have seen since getting the phone calls it a "brick" or "something from the 80s". They literally think it's a joke and can't believe I'd carry such a thick phone around.

I sure miss BlackBerry and had high hopes OnwardMobility was going to introduce a BlackBerry 5G with keyboard but that company is out of business and it appears BlackBerry (RIM) sold off the core BlackBerry technology--which was the most secure for corporate users--Huawei has acquired 90 patents from Blackberry.

title: My Moto X Pure Edition was great, but had issues with bluetooth and picture messages
text:
What an incredible value! After having a string of reliable phones, I've bounced between a few in the last year-plus. My Moto X Pure Edition was great, but had issues with bluetooth and picture messages, and the Nexus 5X that followed had a charging port that failed twice.

So, based on the positive reputation of the G series and the strong early reviews, I decided to take a chance on the G5+.

Performance seemed a little bumpy at first, but as the phone got things cached it became astoundingly fast, especially at this price point. I'm sure having 4GB of RAM has something to do with that, and it was definitely worth the extra money. By that same token, the 64GB internal storage is very impressive for a phone at this price point, especially when it also supports SD cards.

Oh, and a note on battery life - It's incredible. I work in a profession that prevents me from using my phone much, but even if I have 1-2 hours screen time I still end the day (16 hours off charge) with 70% or more. If I'm working long hours, I'm convinced I could get 4 days out of this thing. Left off the charger overnight for 8 hours, it only loses 2-3% charge. On non-work days, when I'm on it a lot more, I've only barely managed to put it below 50%. Truly worry-free, and the included Turbo Power charger works as advertised.

The fingerprint sensor is very good as well. It's on the bottom bezel of the phone, which isn't necessarily ideal - I loved the sensor on the back of the Nexus 5X - but it's fast, works as an on-off switch, and can be used to replace on-screen controls - swipe left to go back, swipe right to show recent apps, and tap to go to the home screen. Long press to lock. I played with this a bit, and it seems to work reliably as intended.

Honestly, the worst features are the slightly-slick metal body and the new moto logo on the upper bezel, which looks silly. Motorola has built a reputation of making phones unadorned with branding of any sort, short of their logo on the back, and this bit just reminds me of ugly Verizon Droid brandings of the past.

I long for the curved backs of the X series, but it's a minor complaint. If you need a phone that is quick and responsive, has a great-looking screen, runs Android 7.0, you could break the bank. Or, you could buy the Moto G5+ for $299.

title: Centro Rocks and Sprint Service is Doable
text:
This phone is excellent--you wanted smaller, you're going to get less battery life and a bit of a cramped keyboard--take it or leave it. It's fast, it does everything you ask it to, and I've loaded over 120 applications on mine without issues (except for my cheap 2gb micro sd card not mounting--easily taken care of using Safeguard software).

I was a Sanyo loyalist. But I had always wanted a smart phone. Walked through wal mart one day and said, "No I'm just browsing," when the guy, who I had bought my last cell from a year earlier (katana II), asked if he could help me. Then I saw the price tag: $48. I was all over it (2 year extension required).

Regarding customer service--Sprint doesn't rank at the top, but you WILL get what you ask for if you are patient. If you want immediate answers from some really sharp technical people, use their e-mail support option. I've been with Sprint for 5 years and have never had problems with service, up and down the east coast, not to mention they gave me a 14% discount on my plan just for being a veteran (only applies to monthly recurring charge, or MRC, not add-ons).

I don't necessarily doubt that these 1-star reviews are legitimate, but it surprises me, considering I used to sell Sprint and Verizon cell phones and we rarely had complaints about Sprint. My advice to the people that are freaking out is this--if your phone isn't functioning properly, and you know it isn't something you did, see if it's in warranty and deal with Palm directly. If it is something Sprint did (perhaps loading a facebook app, for example) then you need to get in touch with sprint. If you don't like the result, use the e-mail support option. If you don't like that result, call and demand a supervisor, and write his/her name down in case you are disconnected (it all goes into the computer on their end). You WILL get what you need. Best of luck!

title: Very Solid Phone, until it suddenly stopped working
text:
First off this phone is very big, bulky and heavy. I expected that when I ordered this phone and I think my expectations were exceeded! However, this is the reason this phone is also solid and built to last. It's still able to fit in the front pocket of my Levis 501s but it's tight.

I played with the phone all weekend, putting it on my wireless charger and connecting USB to my truck a few times and never did the battery dip below upper 80%. There's very little bloatware so this straight Android Oreo OS flows very smooth, switching between games, social media and my Nest Cams with ease. The screen is clear and bright and very responsive. I think the coolest feature is the fingerprint reader on the middle of the right side of the phone. Even with the screen off and the phone locked, the fingerprint reader unlocks the phone in less than a second. There's a dedicated quick launch button below the fingerprint sensor, however I haven't figured out how set that up yet. Seems like the button would be prone to pocket pushes/ false pushes since they are pretty easy to press.

My biggest complaint and the reason this gets 4 stars instead of 5, is the camera. I'm upgrading to this phone from the Samsung S6 Active which I thought had a great camera. On paper the BV9500 should be much better, however, the few pics I've taken were grainy and not very clear. I hope there's something I can do to improve the camera quality because I was planing on using this phone long term. A crappy camera might be a deal breaker though.

Overall, I'm initially pleased and I'd recommend this phone to someone looking for a rugged phone with superb battery life, excellent performance with a subpar camera.

*Update*
Well on March 8th 2019, four months after I got it, in the middle of typing a text message, the screen stopped reacting to touch. I did a reboot and since I can't input the security pattern, I'm basically stuck with a brick. Of course the return window has just closed, I'm hoping the vendor will step up and make it right. This phone has been gently used so this failure was unprovoked.

title: Good basic smartphone but won't allow for many apps
text:
It's a good phone and works well if you want a basic smartphone. It lasted me a couple years but towards the end got very slow and would freeze. By the end, it wouldn't let me save new contacts anymore which is when I realized I really needed a new phone.

The storage space was definitely the biggest drawback. I had very few apps but the storage was almost maxed out meaning the phone was slow. I had an external SD card for pictures and music thankfully but since you can't transfer many apps to the card it didn't help much. It says it has 8gb but really 4gb is already taken up by the system memory. That being said if you want a smartphone, don't want to spend a lot of money and would only use it for basic functions, it's a great phone. It's easy to surf the web, has good call quality and takes good pictures. Just don't expect to play games and stream a bunch of videos and choose your downloaded apps wisely!

title: Goodbye MDA, It's been an experience
text:
We've been together for two years. We both knew our relationship was dysfunctional and temporary, but it took this long for me to find something new and better. For two grueling years I put up with all of my MDA's quirks, crashes, and severe lack of performance.

I was initially impressed by the MDA's long list of features, but in practice my MDA has been anything but useful. Sure this device can do anything, but it does absolutely nothing well. Windows occasionally froze in the middle of phone calls, apps crash, the screen took too long to readjust when I slid out the keyboard, the speakerphone with its loud yet poor quality sound, and dialing phone numbers was much more difficult than it should have been. I had to educate myself in the inner workings of the Windows Mobile platform, overclocking and editing registry settings, just to be able to use the device.

The only reason I stayed in this abusive relationship was because I couldn't find anything with equal features. The last thing I wanted to do was downgrade to a cheap razr, even if it meant putting up with so much daily frustration. Today marks the end of our relationship. I found something stable, sleeker, more powerful, more capable and better designed: The Blackberry Curve 8320.

Goodbye MDA. We've had an interesting run. I may never know my new blackberry as intricately as I knew you. Thank god I won't have to in order to get some work done.

title: I wish they did more testing...
text:
The hardware works, I haven't had any problems with that yet. The software, however, is terrible in some places, or just doesn't work in others.

First annoyance: the touch screen. There's a button on the left side of the phone that "locks" the screen. This means that the screen dims and changes to a different page, showing you the time and including an unlock button at the bottom left. After about 4 seconds, the screen turns off. If, at any time, for any reason, the phone receives an alert (hey! that message you just sent was sent!), the touch screen is touched by your pockets (it always happens), or one of the potruding buttons are pushed, the phone either delays the screen shutoff, turns back on the screen, or completely unlocks your phone, calling your mother as soon as it can. I fix this by sending a message, waiting for it to tell me I sent a message, locking the phone, staring at it until the screen goes off, and gently sliding my phone in my pocket like the phone was made of paper.

Second annoyance: the messaging system. There's a few quirks with this, but only one of them really gets me. I text special characters, such as a "<" or ">" to make pictures, as some people do. If I'm texted and want to reply with one of these, well, I can't. The "Sym" button does not work. Yes, the pantech laser has a button that DOES NOT WORK. The thing is, instead of just typing a reply, I have to open the message within the conversation we've been having, click "Options" and hit "reply". Then I can use the button. Or, if I'm really in a rush, I can use the touchscreen to browse the symbols (past the common ones like "," or "." because they're important!) several pages in to find my one character, and then keep typing. It basically makes replying about 7 times longer than it needs to be.

You can read the other reviews for the other shortfalls this phone has. I just wish Pantech would be responsible with their products and send out an update to fix this!

title: It lasted almost two years
text:
Update 9/14/20
I really enjoyed this phone. I thought it would last much longer than it did since I always had it in a holster and rarely ever dropped it. Suddenly on 9/3/20 the phone started displaying white vertical lines. I could still use the phone but I knew its days were numbered. My last Asus phone lasted about two years also. I immediately purchased a new phone and started configuring it. On 9/14/20 the zenfone 4 phone became unusable as the white lines got worse and the screen images started shaking. This phone didn't even last two years. At least my old zenfone 2 is still usable.

Update 3/12/19
ASUS support reached out to me and, after determining that I qualified for a replacement, sent me another Zenfone 4. It is refurbished but it looked brand new and I have not experienced a problem with it yet. I am changing my rating to 4 stars.

Original review:
I owned a zenfone 2 for three years without any issues. The phone still works but I wanted an upgrade. I purchased the zenfone 4 after Thanksgiving 2018 and I may need to return it in less than a month. I am very disappointed. The phone is fast and the battery life is outstanding. The speaker is good and the Bluetooth has a better range than my zenfone 2. The problem that I started experiencing is that apps stopped opening sporadically. Whichever app that I was using would close immediately on its own and the phone switches to the home screen. I actually select an app, it starts to open but closes instead. This goes on and on until I give up and put the phone away for a while. I researched this, applied all of the updates which now has my phone at Android 8 but the problem still occurs. I contacted ASUS and their only recommendation was to reset the phone which is something that I will only do as a last recourse. I read about other doing it and the problem didn't go away. I'm going to try a few things before returning the phone.

title: Fantastic value for the price
text:
Update 5-15-2019: As of this posting this phone WILL NOT work on Total Wireless. All of the necessary bands are there but Total Wireless does not support it. This might change in the future. The phone DOES work on official Verizon service with a Verizon SIM without an issue, as long as the SIM is already activated. As I use the phone more I come across various software glitches, translation mistakes and other oddities in menus. None of them have made the phone unusable or less for it's value.

First off it should be known that this is NOT a $1000 phone. If you go into this expecting that you will be disappointed. What this phone is, is a $220 winner. I was hesitant to purchase this phone from a relatively unknown brand, at least to me. I did a lot of research and came across them by accident and boy oh boy am I glad that I did. I have been an avid user of the Moto G line for several years, but the newest Moto G 7 did not impress me. I have been wanting NFC in a budget line device for several years, and year after year Moto has let me down. This is a solid mid range phone for less than the price of the Moto G 7. It is built very well and looks far more expensive than it is, it will impress.

The phone came with US fast charger, USB cord, simple silicone case, and screen protector already installed. The screen is beautiful and bright taking up the most of the front of the device. The blacks are very dark almost tricking you into thinking it is OLED, it isn't. The screen was bright enough for use in the sun. The adaptive brightness works well where it really didn't on my last phone. The fingerprint reader on the back is sometimes finicky, but I have started using the face unlock without much of a problem. It could be how I am holding it. It would make more sense for it to be lower on the phone. I have smaller hands and a larger phone is always a challenge for me. The camera is not a $1000 camera, but it takes respectful pictures in good light. I have not tried it in low light yet, but I assume that the pictures will be washed out and underexposed which should be expected. The daylight photos were crisp and the depth sensor was doing it's job. The software experience is mostly stock Android which makes it snappy and responsive. There are a few software additions and subtractions thrown in by Umidigi. The phone only has a single down firing speaker which was sort of quiet for my liking. If you hold the phone just right you can direct it back at your ear which helps a lot. The sound is somewhat hollow and echoey as well. The earpiece was quiet by comparison to some other phones which may make it a bit hard to hear in a loud environment. The processor, for being a couple of generations old, is very snappy and shows little lag. Out of the box half of the ram was being used which is something typical with new Android phones, so 6 GB should be the standard. There is some stutter and lag from time to time, but hey its a $220 phone. It is perfectly fine for the price point and daily use. I can verify that this phone works flawlessly on Verizon, but did not have to call them to activate. I just popped an unlocked SIM in the phone. WIFI calling worked fine for me on Verizon and call quality was no issue. Battery life is fantastic. Playing with the settings and restoring an update of my old phone took about 20% of the life over the course of 4 or 5 hours.

If I had to list a con it would be that sometimes I notice the screen flicker when adjusting to ambient light, but I really don't care for the price. You have to stare and know it is there to see it.

I would not hesitate to pick the phone up again and will for sure look at Umidigi in the future when looking for a good deal. Nice work!

title: People, it's a basic messaging phone, NOT AN iPHONE
text:
Its a good little phone. If you are buying this phone thinking it has the latest and greatest technology then yes of course you will be disappointed. Its simple, user friendly, and REALLY LOUD (for those that are hard of hearing this would be a great choice). The vibrate feature is strong and the Menu layout is simple. The Software update was nice and quick (less than 10min) and it gets the job done. Only downside i could say about this phone is that it is VERY small which means the keys are VERY close together. So big handed people beware.

Seriously just be realistic in what you are buying. If you think you can spend $30 and get a top notch phone, you are out of your mind. You get what you pay for, and for $30 this is a darn good buy.

title: Good, Light Duty, Feature Phone
text:
I spent about 30 minutes with Tracfone customer service before buying this phone. The Tracfone Web site does not offer much guidance about whether or not this phone will work where I live, but the service rep eventually determined it would. Registering the phone took about 5 to 10 minutes. The minutes and time increased over the listed face value, though not triple. The minutes more than tripled, while the duration less than tripled.

The screen is readable. The touch screen is pretty good. Thanks to other reviewers I found the QWERTY keyboard. Data comes via WIFI, and a WPA2 connection. The browser would not log into my e-mail account. Other Web sites were "interesting." The optional Opera 7 mini browser did a much better job, both with page rendering, but also with things like bookmark storage, and supplying a full QWERTY keyboard.

Other things take some getting used to. Answering the phone proved difficult. Tapping the answer button doesn't work. No, you have to swipe it. The phone itself works. Texting is fine when you do the extra two taps to get the QWERTY keyboard.

Above all, when working with Tracfone, you get a fairly cheap, light duty, feature phone that taps into what would otherwise be an expensive phone network (Verizon's).

title: defect on battery status ruins this phone for me at just over a year
text:
I had this phone for a little over a year and I have to say I'm already about to replace it with a new phone due to the buggy battery mainly, they also had it crash twice because of errors with their appstore which had no uses at all, and is not able to be uninstalled as of this moment, Countless times I had to soft reset this phone just because the battery was draining at 2-3% a minute, and while you could argue its because of age or use, my samsung s6 edge lasts longer then this phone, and I had it for nearly 3 years before the micro usb port broke and I decided that rather then fixing it as it was only then starting to show its age and also a major crack in the screen id buy a new phone. at this point, I would EXPECT a 900 dollar phone (when I bought it.) to at least last over 2 years. I am about to contact their warrenty department and if my replacement (at this point it better be replaced, the waterproof cover on the usb type c door just fell off, GLUED ON NO LESS!) is any better then this one then I MIGHT consider changing this review, overall with the lack of companys even letting this phone on their network, it was a fight to get cricket (at&t's mvmo) to even let me use it without buying a new phone, forget about t-mobile, they refuse to even allow it on there.
pros
- flir works as advertised, shouldn't be a pro but theres alot of people who advertise having a heat scanner and its just blue and red looks.
- phone is nigh indestructible
- phone specs are decent at least when it was produced
- when the battery works, i get on average currently about a day and a half on a single charge.
cons
- battery status controller malfunctions on a weekly basis, this requires painfully trying to discharge it and hoping it finds out its actual amount of charge
- camera is subpar
- appstore crashes the phone and you cant remove it
- HEAVY! like seriously, this phone is a brick in weight, you can litterally hurt someone if you throw this at them, also if you watch videos while laying down, grip firmly as you might drop it on you.
- speakers aren't the best, not a huge deal as it still has a 3.5mm audio jack but none the less
- usb type c cover was litterally glued onto a piece of rubber, which with water overtime probably helps lose its ip68 rating just by using it as intended
- no support for bluetooth 5.0, at least not on my device
- the actual specs aren't great for the price, you are paying to have flir integrated, thats it.
- putting android 9.0 on this device was a mistake as its been causing the most issues with compatibility imho.
overall i put this at a 2 out of 10, this device is as advertised but beyond that its a manufacturing and engineering nightmare.
(note i bought it through a different reseller who also gave me a free battery and headphones, i cannot recommend cat to anyone as of right now due to its low quality QC)

title: Avoid
text:
First, I want to mention that this is review is not a reflection of the seller in any way. I purchased the phone through T-Mobile which the only carrier for this phone. None of the reviews I saw mentioned the troubles I've discovered, so I wanted to ensure this information was put out to other potential buyers, though I suspect there won't be many more given that T-Mobile seems to have stopped selling this phone.

Toughness: I've had the phone for around 9 months and have had no problems, except one - the front screen broke. This is not the touch-screen, but the screen that is on the top of the closed phone. It has a *glass* cover over it. For a phone built with construction workers in mind, using a glass screen is one massive face-palm of a mistake.

Battery: I don't use my phone excessively - one of the reasons I wanted a simple flip phone to begin with - so I can't say everyone will be happy, but it seems like it has decent life. I usually only charge it once every few days, but, again, that's with minimal use.

Calling / Texting: Work fine, except for the problems listed below (not being able to use the physical buttons and touch screen being too small).

Touch Screen / Buttons: The other big reason I wanted a flip phone was because I didn't want it to do much more than text and call, but the thought of possibly using google maps with this phone was enticing.
1) The physical buttons can't reliably be used. A single press often results in multiple entries; if I press the "6" button, there's a very good chance it will input "66".
2) The touch screen is too small to be used reliably. I often have to poke the same spot several times to achieve what I want.
3) Google maps is entirely unusable with a screen so small. All the extra buttons Google Maps adds to the interface means you only get about 1 third of the actual screen size, which is already very small.

title: Case, Battery, and Ram are problems.  The item description needs to be corrected.
text:
After a week with this phone, there's no doubt that the battery life is insufficient. Turns out its a different battery from the other E5 Play phones. It is a 'JE30'. I can't find the batteries on Amazon, hence no backup battery source.

Other reviewers have mentioned the problem finding a case for this phone (E5 Play DL1920-19). I'm on my third ordered case, with no luck yet finding one that will fit. As others have noted, the RAM is only 1gb. There are features on this phone that I like, but I've decided I have to return the phone. The false item details in the description, such as the overstated RAM are bad enough, but the lack of a case for protection and insufficient battery with no backup simply make the phone unreliable. Really disappointing.

I got this phone to replace my E4 that has gotten a cracked screen. This model of E5 is something entirely different; even different from the 'E5 Play' that the description says it is. Read the reviews; not the item description.

title: Slow internet on AT&T networks
text: An OK phone.  However, you will need to phone AT&T to have your voicemail enabled.  Also, when out an about outside of a wifi network you will have very slow connection times as AT&T regard this as an edge device.  AT&T send me the following information explaining why internet connectivity is so bad on this phone.  "I am seeing that the device does not work with AT&T Specific frequencies. The LTE service. I have checked google to see what specifications this device actually has and not seeing anything for the specifications of this device. I believe it works with 2100 frequencies with is not a frequency AT&T uses. This is why the the device does not get the LTE service."  -AT&T rep.  Therefore if you really need fast internet you won't get it on AT&T with this phone.  I thought I was saving money but I didn't realize that I was going to have to pay a slow data traffic price for it.  Apart from that the phone works great.

title: touchscreen is junk after 5 months
text: Gave this to my 11 year old in December '17 so we could talk/text while she is with her dad and vice versa. The set up through Tracfone was somewhat confusing and frustrating, but once activated it was fine. I was happy w/ the phone itself until last week. After five months, the touchscreen only works if you press VERY firmly on each letter or number, and sometimes not even then. My daughter has been extremely careful with it, it has a protective case, there are no obvious dead areas on the screen, it doesn't get used very often, etc.. the touch screen just isn't working, rendering the whole phone useless. I don't see any type of warranty, and for the price of the phone, I didn't really expect one; I was just hoping it would at least be functional for a year or so. Bummer.

title: Love the phone, but the one I received was not unlocked.
text:
I've owned other huawei phones in the past, and I have AT&T, but when I bought a new sim card to fit this, they put it in and then said "uhhh.... this isn't unlocked" and I asked them to double check because the listing says it was. After tinkering with it for around 20 minutes, they said "I'm sorry, I can tell this isn't unlocked, you'll have to return it." So here I am... returning a phone I was actually super excited about. Just in case it makes a difference I purchased mine from the seller Buyerush and it was amazon prime shipping. I'm probably going to attempt to buy a different color of the same phone that way hopefully the next 2 I receive will be unlocked and useable. This hasn't been a wonderful experience.

My bad review is not because the phone is bad, I think I will love the phone- but it seems I, and possibly several others who have left reviews didn't get an unlocked phone- and that's not ok, so this listing might be innacurate, which could come down to an issue with it filed incorrectly in the amazon warehouse as being unlocked.

title: Great except for Camera
text: At this price everything about this phone is great except for the camera. I didn't expect a great 8mp camera but I did expect it to perform as well as my aging Galaxy S3 8mp camera. It is worse. Colors, clarity and low light level performance is poor for a 2017 vintage phone camera. However this is not a big deal for me... I always carry a Nikon or Sony point & shoot camera with me. I rarely use the phone camera except when I really can't wait to share a photo. Set up was easy on ATT. I did have to go into the store to get a nano sim card but it worked fine and everything connected to ATT network with no problems. I also expanded the 16gb internal memory with a 32gb microSD card.... use the procedure to format it as internal on MOTO web site. The wifi receiving range is better than my old S3 and the battery life is very good. Overall this is a good value  phone for you if you are new to smart phones or don't need a lot of power to run games. However if you want to take a lot of good quality photos to share, then bump up your budget and get something with a better camera like the G5 plus.

title: Armored Phone with Great Features
text:
I ordered this as a spare phone to take with me to places I do not want to take my S21. This phone is way better than I imagined, it could be my primary phone. First off the phone feels solid and fits well in my hand. Fit and finish are world class. The phone comes with a standard Android 11 with no bloateware and a few customizations. The screen is IPS but is very clear and readable in a variety of conditions. The processor is responsive and is good for some gaming, according to my 9 year old that "borrowed" it to test the gaming.
I bought the 64 GB version which has plenty of space for apps, the X9 also allows for a micro SD expansion. The X9 is dual Sim compatible if you need 2 numbers. The X9 offers a headphone jack (not common any more) which is nice for listening when you have only wired options. The only down side I found is the lack of USB C charging, the phone has standard micro USB charging. This is a plus for compatability, since even the most hard-core fruit based phone housholds have some of these cables around. I found that I did not notice the micro charger much since the battery capacity is massive, I have owned the phone 3 days and only plugged it in when I first set it up.
The X9 is the ultimate outdoor adventure phone, gets wet - no problem, drop it - no problem, no power - no problem, too cold -no problem (for the phone) want to do underwater photography-no problem (there is even an app for that included). This is the main selling point of the X9 as I originally thought but I found myself grabbing this phone over my primary Galaxy devices because I liked the look and feel of the X9.
Quirks and features:
Dual SIM
Real headphone jack
Customizable function button
5Ghz /2 Ghz wifi
Metal accent bars
Micro SD expansion
Dual SIM
IP68 /IP69K Intrusion protection (I had to Google that spec, it can get pressure washed)
Included tempered glass screen protector
Internal steel frame
Plugged ports
Face recognition (fast and accurate)
Dual rear camera 13 Mp
Good speakers/ speakerphone (not always common on a ruggedized phone)
Underwater and glove modes
Included charger and cable

Conclusion:
This is a really great armored / ruggedized phone that can be your primary phone. It fits nicely in your hand, your pocket, your swim trunks, or your life vest. This phone will survive almost anything and if it doesn't, it cost less than the tax on a new S or Fruit phone.

title: Essential

I read alot on XDA about the essential concerning this problem and basically its no way around it. But still this is a nice phone, reminds me of my Nexus 5 but a newer model.

title: ADS EVERYWHERE
text: Unless you know your way around Android UI, you will be bombarded with advertisements in all of the stock apps on MIUI. The phone UI itself is insufferable, as it constantly no longer recognizes I have headphones plugged in, took an hour to get an apps drawer on the device, and refuses to no longer show ads after I disabled ad services through the settings. Overall, if you can afford to save for something better to come along, do so. Even today with the included case, I turned the phone over to see that one of my four camera lenses is smashed in! It's not worth it.

title: Durable and not bulky smart phone
text: I've dropped this phone from over 1 story at a work site and all that happened was the force of the impact made the battery come out and it left a little scuff mark on the edge of the phone. Aside from that, everything in it still works fine. Also it's a pretty slim phone that you can easily carry around in your pockets. The camera is nice, I've used it for a few shots in a short film I'm putting together. The only complaints I have are: the touch sensitivity can be kinda lacking, sometimes I have the touch screen doesn't register in certain spots, so I have to press a few times or harder. Also it would be nice if I could figure out how to turn off the tint on the screen, idk if it's a permanent blue light filter, but it throws me off sometimes. Lastly, I really hate how samsung tries to encourage you to use it's Bixby feature, which gets in the way of other task that are more important, like turning off the phone.. now you have to press and hold two buttons at the same time (power and down volume) to prompt the phone to turn off, restart, or go in airplane mode. However if you accidentally press and hold just the power button, it activates Bixby, pretty annoying and invasive, imo. I would still recommend, or if you have more money, maybe look into the Cat phones, I think they're american made too!

title: this LG E900 phone and WindowsPhone 7 are amazing !
text:
Estoy encantado con este equipo, es realmente excelente, la construcción metálica es muy buena, no es un juguete como lucen otros celulares, no sabía que LG fabricaba esta calidad de equipos.

Lo uso en Argentina hace un par de semanas y cada dia me sorprende mas, la conectividad con wi fi es de lo mejor que he visto, solo el Nokia N8 es tan eficiente en este sentido.

También me ha sorprendido la cantidad de aplicaciones que he podido bajar, no se por qué han comentado que este sistema operativo tiene pocas aplicaciones, estuve dos horas mirando y bajando aplicaciones ! por supuesto que como en cualquier equipo muchas son inútiles o tonterias, pero algunas son excelentes, no recuerdo haber encontrado tanto en Android.

Debo decir también que ayer conecté el equipo a la computadora y me encontré con la grata sorpresa de que estaba disponible la version 7.5 Mango y pude instalarla sin ningún problema, aunque advierto a quien quiera hacerlo que debe tener paciencia porque demora mucho, más de lo que uno se imagina, un par de veces dudé si estaba trabajando o se había colgado, pero es así, hay que dejarlo y el proceso se completa perfectamente.

La pantalla del LG E900 es excelente, es un placer reproducir fotos y videos o ver YouTube para lo cual supongo que debe tener un procesador muy rápido porque no tiene demoras.

Con esta versión 7.5 ahora se puede incorporar tonos de llamadas de mp3 o wma, pero no es tan fácil como en Android que se hace directamente con el equipo sino que hay que preparar antes el archivo, conectarse en la compu al Zune, en fin, algo complicado pero se puede hacer, en la version 7 no se podía, tal vez deban simplificar esto en el futuro.

También debo decir que este sistema operativo WindowsPhone 7.5 cada vez me gusta mas, al principio parece
poco "divertido" si uno lo compara con el Android o el del iPhone, pero a medida que se usa se aprecia la increible claridad y facilidad de uso del sistema, el diseño gráfico es perfecto, limpio, moderno, se nota un gran estudio de diseño gráfico atrás de esto.

Volviendo al equipo hay que destacar la calidad de la pantalla del LG 900 de 3.7', el multi touch es comparable al iPhone sin ninguna duda, una maravilla, algo que no sucede en el famoso Nokia N8 cuyo touch deja mucho que desear (hago esta comparación porque también tengo el N8, es muy bueno pero prefiero el LG, sorry Nokia pero ya no saben que hacer con ese Symbian por mas que lo decoren es antiguo, claro que si a usted le gusta el Symbian el hardware del N8 es maravilloso, y la cámara lo mejor que se ha creado en celulares tanto para fotos como para filmar es increible, y creo que puedo opinar porque soy fotógrafo y jamás me han interesado las camaritas de los celulares hasta que conocí este Nokia N8, pero, el Symbian... uff, felicito a Nokia por la decisión de adoptar WindowsPhone en sus nuevos equipos, nadie duda de la calidad de Nokia pero vienen patinando hace tiempo con el viejo sistema operativo).

En cuanto a la cámara del LG es de 5Mp y no la he probado demasiado, creo que anda muy bién y es muy fácil de configurar, cambiar el formato, etc., pero no puedo opinar mucho aún.

Finalmente hay que destacar que este LG tiene muy buén precio en relación a su tremenda calidad, y hablando de esto menciono que no tuve ningún problema con esta compra en Amazon y WirelessEverything, el envio super rápido y free !

title: Great budget phone, still hoping for an OS update
text: Great budget phone. I used to have the Essential PH-1 (128GB, 4GB RAM), but I actually like this phone better. The battery life is significantly better, and so far, I haven't had any issues with lagging. The facial and fingerprint recognition works very well. It comes with 2 cases and a screen protector, which are great additions to the package. The only negatives I can think of are that the phone comes with some apps that cannot be uninstalled, and there hasn't been a push for the latest Android OS. The phone is currently running Android 8. The stock camera app isn't that great, but you can find something else in the Play store.

title: Excellent althought not necessarily the best.
text:
Now that I've had this phone for a month I wanted to pass along some of my feelings on it.
Screen: great any time you aren't in direct bright sunlight. Lcd vs oled whatever it's a good screen
Sound: music sounds great (relatively), call quality is like 6/10 though. Earpiece is somehow on the wrong side of the phone?!
Camera: like 9/10, maybe not the best out there, but only barely worse than the best. I love the camera and the built in app is good.
Speed: quick, no issues here.
Battery: one of the best. Somehow less than my Huawei Mate 9, but still very good. Could use some firmware efficiency upgrades to make it better.
Connectivity: okay. Bluetooth has intermittent issues where it cuts out randomly and I have to pause and start to get it to work. Seems to only happen in some apps. 4G is okay, but doesn't support some important TMobile bands.

I'd buy it again, but see what's important to you before buying this over some other also great phones.

title: Fun, but less functional
text:
So, I thought this phone would be perfect for me. In a way it is, but it also isn't. As a background: I usually break phones, even despite my efforts to keep them intact. I landscape, go hiking, and am outdoors most of the time. I was drawn to a smaller phone because I'm annoyed by how large they are. But this one, it is tiny. I am a slender woman and my fingers hit the wrong button 3/10 times. This can get annoying, especially when I just want to check the weather or do something simple that I thought this phone would be perfect for. And if you have nails, forget it!

The photos are poor quality, and if you do post or send them to people, expect them to be blurry. When I receive a photo, I usually email it to my computer so I can actually see what I am looking at. I am not a person who likes to be on my phone, but the size has really made it difficult. Even texting is a huge challenge. Do I spend less time on the phone? Maybe? but really as everything, you get used to it and adapt. And I am left wanting something more streamlined that offers me the ability to send a picture of flowers, birds, insects and mountains.

The big issue is after only a few months the rubber started to detach from the body. Then, a few days later it dropped from my lap and the screen shattered (!) (Previously, I had been tossing my phone around and it would fall with no problem). I contacted unihertz and because I bought it through amazon, they were unwilling to offer a refund. So I am stuck with a broken super durable tiny phone that is now more difficult to use due to the cracked small screen.

I love the concept, and I do love how unique and fun it is. EVERYONE always asks, what is that, and is shocked when I reply, my phone. I enjoy how portable and durable it is (besides mine being defective). I loved it at the beginning, but after a few months of using it, I am now over it and wish there was a phone size between this and the now "compact" 4.7" screens.

title: I don't write a lot of reviews...
text:
But this phone is IMMACULATE ... if I didn't know it was a refurbished I would never have known. Everything works with Verizon just like it supposed to and for $425 I can't imagine there is a greater value out there.

I needed dual SIMS for two lines and options are quite limited, didn't want another Samsung (had big problems with them displaying a dual SIM A53 at Best Buy, but the one one you buy is NOT the one on display) and wanted mmWave capable. But didn't want a Google phone either... and I didn't want to spend north of $1,000.

This phone does EVERYTHING I could want - two lines one phone PLUS up to a terabite SD card (a lot of phones are 2nd SIM OR SD memory card - but not both). 5G mmWave (Verizon "Ultra Wide Band)... PLUS, I do LOVE having the Note pen, the cameras are off the hook (up to 8K VIDEO!), screen resolution is AWESOME.

Couldn't be happier with what I got at any price, and like I said condition being refurbished is far better than anything I could have hoped - it is indistinguishable from brand new. Al for $425!!!

title: Charging issues
text:
After the first 6-8 months of use, the rapid charging feature entirely ceased to work and I have extreme difficulty getting the device to charge at all. I have to spend a full 30-60 seconds wiggling the cable to get it to charge, then a single bump in the night will leave the phone disconnected. I have woken far too many times to find my phone never charged and lost the use of my phone by midday. Replacing the wall charger and cable with a new OnePlus brand product did not resolve the problem.

I have also recently found that I cannot bring my device over to Verizon.

Update: I've been waiting a week for OnePlus customer support to get back to me on repairing the phone. When they finally give me shipping info, they say it will take 7-10 days to repair it and I'll be charged a fee. All to fix an issue that cropped up after 6 months of use. Steer clear of OnePlus.

title: Great deal. Good value for the money.
text:
They unit I bought was a reconditioned T-Mobile version. It has the T-Mobile boot screen and some T-Mobile voice mail apps but other than that it is remarkably devoid of carrier installed apps.

Migrating from my old phone, Samsung Galaxy S8, using the OnePlus migration app was only partially successful. I think OnePlus can make a lot of improvements there. There was a lot of manual cleanup and reconfiguration to be done by me.

The fingerprint reader is not as comfortable or conveniently located as my previous phone, which had it on the back rather than in the screen.

Initially, the Bluetooth system didn't work with my car and only played the audio but didn't communicate track information. Then, just a few weeks ago, on a phone reboot, the operating system updated (unannounced I have to say, what's up with that OnePlus?) and for a while (about 30 minutes and multiple reboots) the phone didn't even recognize the SIM card.

Luckily, after leaving the phone powered off for a while, the SIM was recognized and, to my pleasant surprise, the Bluetooth system works much better now, communicating track information to my car. It still doesn't show status information, like battery charge level, from my portable speaker like my previous phone did.

All in all, I like the phone. It has good solid 5G performance, has a nice large screen and good cameras. It's too bad it doesn't have an SD card reader.

One bit I'd like to pick is that the sensitivity of the Back, Home, and Open Apps buttons are very sensitive to the point that tapping the spacebar while typing a message hides the message app and shows the Home screen, for instance. Perhaps these three buttons should be hidden when the keyboard is up.

I think purchasing this reconditioned phone was a good deal and saved me a lot compared to buying a current flagship phone from OnePlus or any other manufacturer.

title: Apple iPhone 4S, Does it Live up to the Hype?
text:
I entered the smartphone world back in 2008 staring with the Apple iPhone 3G. Coming over from my old Sprint flip-phone, the iPhone 3G was a major upgrade and blew my mind with how much it could do. It was amazing that cell phones had advanced into a sort of mini-PC.

Fast forward to the present-day and I have now used and experimented with various smartphones, different cellphone companies, and smartphones OS's (iOS, Android, Windows, etc). I also run my own small cell phone shop and get to play with these devices on a daily basis. Back in the iPhone 3G days, there were only a few smartphone options to choose from. Today there are literally hundreds of devices across several carriers. All with different functions and designs. I'm going to cover how the iPhone 4S stacks up to the competition, what the competition is, what the 4S can do, and what improvements it makes over its predecessor, the iPhone 4.

HARDWARE
The iPhone 4S is almost identical in hardware design to the iPhone 4. It features the same rectangular shape with the flat gorilla glass back and front screen. The front and rear camera are in the same position. The only visible difference on the outside of the phone is that the volume controls are slightly moved on the 4S. The real difference in the hardware is on the inside. The iPhone 4S uses a dual-core "A5" processor. This makes it significantly faster than the iPhone 4. The processor is the raw power that apps need in order to operate fast and fluidly without slowdown or hiccups. With basic use, users probably won't notice much difference from the iPhone 4's speed. The extra power boost mainly shows its worth when playing some of the more high-end iOS games and apps.

CAMERA
In addition to the new processor, the iPhone 4S has an improved 8 megapixel camera. It also now has the ability to capture full 1080p HD Video. Unless you're a professional photographer, you will be blown away with how great the 4S is at taking pictures. It is on par with most of the dedicated point-and-shoot cameras that are currently on the market. Images are clear, crisp, and very colorful. I even sold my 10MP Canon point-and-shoot after using the 4S for a few weeks. When comparing pictures taken with the iPhone 4 side by side to the 4S, the difference is like night and day. As for the 1080P videos, they're also very beautiful. Just like the photos, the videos rival dedicated point-and-shoot devices and look absolutely gorgeous on the iPhone's retina display screen. The only drawback to these 1080p videos is that they can take up large amounts of memory. So if you plan on shooting a large amount of video, you may need to consider getting the 32GB or 64GB iPhone 4S.

SIGNAL RECEPTION AND DATA SPEEDS
The iPhone 4S has been expanded to include a 3rd US carrier Sprint. This brings your total choices to Verizon, AT&T, and Sprint.
Signal reception and data speeds will vary by carrier and location, so I'll give you some basic information about what to expect on average. Signal reception is greatly improved compared to the iPhone 4. The antenna problem from the iPhone 4 has been removed and the 4S uses separate antennas for incoming and outgoing calls in order to increase overall reception. AT&T is a GSM carrier while Sprint and Verizon are CDMA carriers. Verizon has the overall largest and most expansive voice coverage of the three, closely followed by AT&T, with Sprint in third. The 4S Data speeds will largely vary by carrier and location. Being a GSM carrier, AT&T is the only iPhone carrier capable of using the 4S's improved HSPA+ data speeds. AT&T users will notice their iPhones showing "4G" in the top left corner rather than 3G. Though this is faster than standard 3G, do not confuse it with the much faster 4G LTE network. The iPhone 4S is not yet capable of using that network. Verizon is second in 3G data speeds, with Sprint bringing up the rear. Again, these are average speeds from across the nation. Individual results may vary depending on your location. It is also important to note that Sprint is the only carrier that still offers unlimited data. This may be an important factor in choosing a carrier for some.

BATTERY LIFE
iPhone owners have come to expect excellent battery life from their devices. Previous iPhones have ranked among the most impressive in terms of battery life compared to rival Android devices. In the past each new iteration of the iPhone had better battery life than the previous device. With the 4S however, the overall battery life is about the same as the iPhone 4. Apple claims this is mainly because of the dual-core processor used by the 4S as well as the more demanding iOS 5 software that is included with the iPhone 4S. Due to this, there were some widespread complaints about the iPhone 4S battery life initially. Apple has since addressed the issue with their iOS 5.1 update. The iPhone 4S now ranks among the top smartphones in overall battery life. I can easily get through a full day on one full charge of average use.

SOFTWARE
Usually when comparing the iPhone to other phones, it comes down to the software. There is a big ongoing debate among techies between the iPhone's operating system "iOS" and Google's "Android" operating system. It's comparable to the famous PC vs Mac debate. Rather than type a whole page comparing the two, I'll just cover a few basics. The main difference between the two is choice. Customize or not customize. iOS is more fluid and crisp out of the box. All iPhones/iPods/iPads use this standard OS. Less powerful iOS devices are often able to move as fast or faster than more powerful Android counterparts. However, major modifications and customizations of Apple's iOS are not possible. The standard 4x4 row of icons is what you will get. Android offers tons of customization options. This is great for advanced tech users, but can be overwhelming to novice smartphone users or those not really interested in editing and customizing a lot to get the device to do what they need it to do. I usually recommend iOS to customers new to smartphones due to its more simple and easy to use interface. If you like customizing and making your the software on your phone look different from everyone else, I recommend an Android device.
The other major software difference between iOS and Android is the Apps. The Apple app store still has by far the most support and overall apps from developers. Most developers create an app for the iPhone first and port it later on to Android, or sometimes not at all. From personal experiences with both, I can say that many times the iPhone version of an app usually runs better or has more features.

SIRI Personal Assistant
Unless you've been under a rock for the past few months, you've heard of the iPhone 4S's SIRI personal assistant software. Apple touts it as a feature that allows you to speak voice commands to your iPhone and SIRI will do whatever you ask it to do. Well it can do some things, but not quite everything. SIRI is great for finding places for you. You can say simple things like "I'm hungry" and SIRI will open the Maps App and show you the location of all restaurants in the nearby area. You can also do things like tell it to play a certain song or artist from the music stored on your iPhone or ask it the Weather forecast for any given day. SIRI can also be pretty entertaining when asked random conversational questions. Questions such as "How old are you?" will cause SIRI to respond "Does this concern you?", "I didn't think so". Or saying silly things such as "SIRI I love you" will cause it to say "I'll bet you say that to all your Apple products". Overall it's a pretty nice added feature, but not a major selling point at this time. It's limitation is that it currently is only integrated with the standard apps that Apple provides on the iPhone. Once it is integrated with more of the third-part apps, I can see it becoming a seriously useful feature.

Overall I would definitely recommend the iPhone 4S. From the sleek hardware design, the beautiful camera, and the very large Apple App store, it's my top phone at the moment. The iPhone 4S has the battery life to last most people a full day and in terms of overall speed and ease of use, it is currently among the best available. The only people who I would not recommend the 4S to are current iPhone 4 owners. With all of the iPhone 4S's improvements, I don't feel like they're significant enough to spend more money to upgrade from your iPhone 4. You will be better off waiting for whatever iPhone Apple releases later this year. However if you're looking to purchase your first smartphone, tired of your old Blackberry or Android device, or just have an older iPhone 3GS or 3G, I would strongly recommend getting the iPhone 4S if possible. Using a smartphone has never been easier.

title: A little laggy but there are a few tips to make it faster.  :)
text:
So I've been looking at YouTube reviews of this phone and the lag aspect made me nervous. It does have a bit of a lag to it on stock, but if you install Nova launcher and set the settings to performance vs animations, then go into system settings>developers mode and turn off all animations as well as only allow 2-3 background processes at a time, the phone gets pretty snappy. Then go ahead and install SwiftKey keyboard which makes things run even smoother and turn off vibration for key strokes.

Lastly, buying a big SD card and installing as many apps as you can on it will help with the small storage space this phone has.

I was thinking of sending it back until I did all these things, now I love it and am happy with it as a budget phone.

Update: charged the phone all night last night, and used it all day today, sometimes pretty heavily. I just had to put it on the charger at 16% battery, at 10:30 pm. I can see it lasting for days if only used to make calls and send texts, but not as a heavy user. But heck, even getting a full day's worth out of a phone without having to charge it is great in my book. Battery life may even improve once I'm not in the "setting my phone up" phase.

I've also included a photo I took with the camera on this. It's not as good a camera as my old iPhone 4S But it's not terrible either. The pink around the edges is a little frame thing you can select.

Update #2:

So far it's still pretty good but I am missing the camera on my iPhone 4S. I mainly take pictures of my kids and none of them come out as clear as they did even using an older iPhone camera. It's a bit frustrating.

Update #3:

I returned this phone. Lollipop update was nowhere in sight, attempting to contact BLU to ask about it got generic replies saying G there is no update for this phone at the time. Who knows if it'll ever get lollipop, as far as I know, it hasn't (as of 8/11/15) and it was supposed to get it back in June.

Also the camera on this phone is horrible. I'm a mom who likes to take pictures of my kids and the camera on this was just NOT good. Any movement resulted in tons of blur.

Lastly, the battery... Yes I do miss not having to plug my phone in all day but the battery made the phone so heavy that I literally got cramps in my fingers from holding it. Adding any kind of case other than a thin rubber one just made it much heavier. I ended up buying a 'love handle' (Google it lol) and attaching it to the back of a hybrid case I had bought for it, but it was still heavy and cumbersome. I kept it in a pocket of my scrubs at work and it would drag my pants down slowly as I walked so I always had to hike my pants up.

I switched to a Moto G (2nd generation) and I am much happier with it (hello lollipop update!). I just have to remember to charge it while driving to and from work, since you can't get a day of use out of it without charging, like you can with the BLU energy.

title: Good value WP7 smartphone
text:
I have lived with the DVP 16gb for about 6 months now, shortly after I first purchased it I received the Nodo update and then Mango. I have heard difficult experiences with the DVP before the Nodo/Mango combo, I have not experienced any major problems with the exception of the following:

- With Mango, the compass on the DVP does not work. This is well documented and you can Google it too. You may or may not care about this. There are some examples where this might matter. For example, when using gps and moving slowly in one direction, the gps can get confused and u-turn the direction it thinks you're going, and u-turn again, in a sense, spinning, until you pick up speed and the direction is obvious.

- The camera is abysmal. It is almost impossible to get a non-blurred shot indoors even if you think there is adequate light.

As a point of reference to what I'm comparing the above problems to, my last phone was the ancient Nokia 5800 and a Sony Arc S (aka LT18i). Curiously, the video recording is surprisingly sharp, especially compared to its picture taking. I still give the phone 4 stars based on the following positive points:

- outstanding no-data-plan gps lock performance: combined with the Navigon gps app, I was pleasantly surprised that without a data plan, gps lock consistently took only a few seconds. This has turned my DVP into a reliable gps unit with offline maps and addresses.
- stability: I've had only 2 crashes in 6 months, and about 10 freezes which required a restart, but that could be due to the apps I was downloading and playing with. Overall, I have the impression its reliable and stable.
- decent build quality: the slider mechanism is the point of focus in long-term wear and tear, and it seems to be holding up well. It has developed a slightly looser play, or jiggle, if you apply horizontal pressure, but nothing serious. The screen is still responsive and no dead pixels yet. The phone is encased with Otterbox and I have dropped it a few times on hard surfaces with no problems.
- value: I had pretty low expectations for how much I purchased it for. A 4.1 inch screen with a hardware keyboard, no major problems, and a reliable gps unit, so far it has been a great value.

Now for the cons (considering it is lower-end phone with a price to match):

- abysmal camera. Really. 5MP might as well be 0.5MP with all the blur. The quality is so low that I can't even use it for contact pictures because it's that blurry.
- big size and weight. The Sony Arc S feels like half its size and weight, and it's uncomfortable when I put this in my inside jacket pocket. Battery performance feels like average (so it's not a heavy-duty battery weighing the DVP down, it's probably the slider mechanism). The Otterbox case doesn't help either, but its construction is top-notch and fits the DVP tightly.
- below-average mono-speaker performance (although it looks like 2 speakers on the bottom of the phone, only one is used as the speaker). You may not care about this if you primarily use earphones or don't use speakerphone often.
- too-sensitive search button (bottom right touch button)

In regards to Mango, coming from Symbian (S60 5th) and Android (Gingerbread), I'm losing flexibility, both in file access capabilities and app choices. Mango + DVP has proven to be more stable though than Gingerbread + Sony Arc S, as the latter has already had a few random restarts. And it is worlds more stable than Symbian + Nokia 5800. Overally, I'm very happy with its value and that I can use it as a reliable gps unit.

title: Started failing in under 3 months

title: Good phone with WiFi issues and Lag
text:
I have been using this phone for over a month now. Initially, I was very pleased with the specs especially for that price point. However, after a few months of using it, I have come to find some issues with it. First, I experience lags while using it. I often have to wait for a few moments after opening an app before it comes up or for the next screen to display. Secondly, the Wifi reception is very weak. It seems I have to be VERY close to the router or source of the Wifi to get a signal. Very often, it doesn't even connect at all when I am not far from the router. For example, my bedroom is 2 floors away from the router but I usually do not get a signal in my room and whenever I do, it is very weak. All my other devices(laptop and even a low-end tablet) get a strong signal. This is really a letdown for me because it is difficult to connect to WiFi at home and on campus where I usually am. If WiFi connectivity is very important to you and you won't always be very close to a router, I won't recommend this device for you.

That being said, the display is good (large screen and high resolution), the camera rating is high and it has a lot of storage space.

I would have given it 5 stars if it didn't lag and have the WiFi problem.

title: Cellphone without phone functionality
text:
My phone needs are very simple: make calls. That's it! That's all I want from a cellphone. And yet somehow, Motorola/Lenovo failed on this very basic function. I've had this for 3 months and during that time, on two occasions now, the phone has mysteriously decided to stop connecting to the cellular (or wifi) network. No rhyme or reason to it. I've gone through online posts, help desks, phone resets, had AT&T replace the SIM, but not no avail. The first time this happened was in August, after roughly one month of ownership. Randomly stopped connecting, and two days later randomly worked again. I'm on day two of this latest stint but I suspect I'm going to have to write this off as a "buyer beware" and spring for a new phone from a different company.
The foundation of a cellphone is the ability to make calls. Not the apps, not the GPS, not the texting; just make phone calls. If a product is unable to do that, what good is all of the other bells and whistles? The processor was fast enough, the RAM was enough, the hd capacity was enough. It's a baseline phone but it did all that superfluous stuff that people seem to need these days well-enough for its price. What it completely fails to do, however, is reliably stay connected to the cellular network and without that, it's little more than a $100 brick of plastic. Look elsewhere for your basic phone needs because Motorola/Lenovo can't deliver.

title: Umidigi One
text:
I like the house (body) of the phone, the graphic quality is good. For the size (height) I was a bit disappointed. For a 5.9" i was expecting a slightly bigger phone. I have had a 5.9" and 6.0" and my old 5.9" is taller and larger than the umidigi.
DISAPPOINTMENTS:
1) The flash light is crappy
2) The volume of the media, ringtone and alarm cannot stay on at the same time...its either or...like seriously!!!
3) When it said dual sim, like all the other phones, dual sim means two and and a seperate micro SD card slot, but with the Umidigi, its either two (2) sims or one sim ad SD card slot. I don't know what they were thinking.

4) The speakers are not as loud as described online. you can barely hear it. When placing a call the tone is very low. same for music and other media applications.

5) The phone over heats when you say on a call too long.
6) The keypad lags when typing sometimes.
7) the camera has no flash, like seriously? the video has, but not the camera(front/back).

The bottom line is..The idea is there, but the delivery is very far from the ideal product.

title: Built tough and great for tough jobs
text:
I'm an aircraft mechanic. I've forgotten how many phones I've gone through with broken screens, poor battery life, dropping, crushing, exposure to grease/oil/skydrol/jet fuel. This puppy is tough. And works better than advertised. Of not, the ad and description said not VoWiFi capable, but it is. I don't know if it's a software update or what, but it is VOIP. Downloads are fast, and everything that I had on my Samsung works on my Blackview. It's a little heavier than most similar sized phones and the battery is not replaceable, but so far that hasn't been an issue. Heavy feels solid in my hand. Built in protection means I don't have to find a case that stands up to the stuff it gets exposed to.
I highly recommend this phone - and the X1 watch I ordered with it.

title: Outstanding phone for the price. Works on Cricket.
text:
I'm coming from an LG Stylo 4 which was a good budget phone. But this G8 Plus is a huge improvement. I purchased it at $200, but would satisfied even if it was $300.
Battery: Possibly one of the best features of this phone. My Stylo 4 battery life was very good. With the G8 plus, light use I can get through the day and maybe drop to 75%. Honestly, I don't think I've gone below 50% with moderate use during a day. It does have quick charge, but I don't think it has wireless charging.
Speaker: Big improvement. Comparable to some cheaper blue tooth speakers. Great for a phone.
Speed: very good most of the time (again, huge improvement over my Stylo 4). Probably not as good as your higher end iphones/androids but most will be satisfied.
Cell reception: No issues. At least as good as my previous phone on Cricket (uses AT&T towers).
WiFi/bluetooth: No connection problems with me.
Fingerprint scanner: Gets it right probably 90% of the time. As good or better than other fingerprint phones. I haven't tried the facial recognition method and I'm not really interested it it.
Cameras: Lots of features and quality with main camera. Front camera is also decent. This camera was another huge improvement over my Stylo 4. It's probably not as good as some high end phones, but it's not far behind either.
Storage: Decent amount of on board storage and can add micro SD card which I did. I've had no issues with my SD card.
Screen: Good image quality. The max brightness is a weak point. In very bright locations I can see the screen, but I wish it was brighter. This is a small step down from my Stylo 4.
Screen sensitivity: Generally good, but I have a screen protector on it. Sometimes I have to retap but the protector may be a factor. If there is any sensitivity reduction it's small.
OS: Currently at Android 9 (as of 2/20/20) even though 10 has been out for several months. Not a big deal for me, but if you have to have the latest OS then stick with Google phones.

Overall this is an outstanding phone for the price. I thought it wasn't available in the US. Apparently it is, but not officially so you might not have a warranty. Buying through Amazon effectively gives you a short term warranty via the return window. This phone competes with some $500+ phones. It was a quick transition from my old phone (had function to easily directly transfer data). The phone has other neat quick gesture features to access the flash light and camera in addition to other things.

title: Misleading, but still a good option.
text:
The phone I received was in fact the ME770, which LG seems to think never existed. The phone was from Mexico, which I can tell based on the fact that the whole thing was set up for the major Mexican carrier MovieTel with the browser launch menu button being the Spanish word Emocion. Another thing is that despite what the review states and what other reviews have mentioned, this phone DOES NOT HAVE SPEAKER PHONE as stated in the description.

I decided to keep the phone even though this was the case. Here's why.

This phone is replacing my Motorola L6 phone. The ME770 is basically an upgrade of everything I loved about the L6 except the lack of speakerphone of course.

The good: 2mp camera is decent but slow. Still, colors are adequate and flash is ok. Has Edge browser capabilities. Nice screen for the price. TINY size, which I personally. The metal case feels nice in the hand, and is very attractive. Very good reception.

The bad: Again, No Speaker Phone. Unlike my old L6 the glass of this phone will scratch easily. Did not come with usb data cable. Uses priority LG adapter for charging and data.

This phone is great for people who want a small attractive but capable phone for not much money.

title: Good Phone W/Weak Battery
text:
This is my second 8100 (1st one died as I left it in the washer) but to this date, this is the best Sprint PCS phone that I have used. This was recommended to me by the salesman at the Sprint store over a year ago. Here is the quick list:

Pros:

1) Signal: Rarely do I ever experience any drop calls with this phone compared to my last 2 Samsungs.

2) Display: Very clear and vibrant.

3) Quality: As soon as you pick up the phone you feel the quality that it is made. It does not have the Cheap feel on some of the Nokia and Samsung phones. My first one was made in Japan and this one is from Malaysia. Sanyo just makes quality phones.

Dislikes

1) Battery Life: The standard battery is weak. It rarely lasted more than 2 days when it was brand new and now its about 1 day for me. And I have 2 batteries. I purchased an extended battery on Ebay for about $10 and it works great.

2) Poor camera under low light: But what do you expect with a cell phone right?

Overall, its a nice phone I only wish Sprint would carry more Sanyos and Motorolas and stop carrying the terrible Nokias and Samsungs.

title: Currently best in its price range
text:
I purchased this phone for my mom. She's not a big techie and just wanted the best she could get in the sub $300 range. Further, it had to be compatible with Verizon which limits a lot of the import phones out there. I feel like the Moto G5 Plus fit the bill perfectly.
First, we selected the 64gb version mainly because it comes with 4gb of ram as opposed to the 32gb version that only comes with 2gb. I felt like the extended ram would make the phones useful life as well as limit multitasking lag.

First impression: I was worried the bezel would look big and imposing by today's standards but in person it isn't bad looking at all. Its no Galaxy S8 but coming in at almost $550 cheaper I cant complain. The default launcher is a bit clunky and the icon and background choice make the screen look washed out and boring. They say first impressions are everything and if Motorola wants to win an easy point here the initial power on should greet you with something that showcases their product. This is easily remedied however with a quick visit to the google play store. My personal choice is the paid version of Nova launcher but I've also found the free Evie launcher to be a great modern looking alternative. Just a personal preference but I'd also switch out the icon theme to a modern look with either Pixel Icon Pack or Rondo. Both are circular themes that fit in well with current modern design trends.

Once the phone was setup I found everything to be fast and responsive. This is one of the only "bargain phones" I came across to include the latest Android 7.1 N. Overall, its a great user experience.

Other points of interest:
Camera: I've read it uses the same sony image sensor as the Samsung Galaxy S7 and so far it seems to be one of the strongest selling points. I haven't run it through its paces but the initial results are amazing especially for the price point.

Finger print sensor: Quick as any I've ever used. Any delay defeats the purpose in my book and this sensor does the job well. An interesting feature that can be enabled is the ability to use the fingerprint sensor to navigate with swipes. While this might not sound useful I was amazed at how intuitive and easy it was to use. Its a feature I now wish other manufactures would implement.

Lastly AD's: I hate ads. I'm the type who will pay the premium on apps I use to remove ads as I prefer a clean uncluttered work-space. The Amazon ad discount was probably the single biggest pause I had on this purchase. After using the phone I feel those fears have been eased. The ads only appear on the lock screen and I really feel like they were so unobtrusive that I couldn't justify paying more to just remove them. When I use my phone I may use my lock screen to check the time but otherwise I'm in so quickly the ads are effectively gone.

While the phone wasn't a personal purchase I couldn't help but feel like I would be happy using this as my daily driver. You get a lot of bang for the buck especially with the Amazon Prime discount.
I'd say if you want:
1) an unlocked phone that works on all US carriers
2) has the latest operating system
3) a fast processor
4) great camera
5) plenty of memory (64gb plus SD card expandable)
6) plenty of ram
7) and finally a great price
then this would be the one to choose.

title: I like it with few reservations, so far...
text:
I have had my MDA for only about one week. So far no complaints. Becoming use to its way of doing things does require a bit of patience. It's not as easy to use as a PC, but the Windows Mobile V5.0 OS does in many ways make the MDA seem very familiar. After several hours of use it is becoming second nature and intuitive.

I had no problem installing the Opera browser to replace/augment Internet Explorer. I have had absolutely no problems syncing to my Toshiba laptop via USB. It worked the first try right out of the box. Gmail also works perfectly.

The MDA offers a "Connections" screen that provides central access to all available means of connection. This menu is instantly accessible by pushing a button on the exterior-top-left-side of the MDA. Branching from the connections screen is another screen that effortlessly scans for all available WiFi networks. From my location it found six or eight available non-T-Mobile WiFi networks.

I have not yet experienced any power problems. The exterior buttons are designed to prevent inadvertent button mistakes. The menus offer several options to turn off any features that may not presently be in use such as WiFi, and Bluetooth. There are also options to blank the screen and further throttle-back the device for periods of inactivity. Amateur Radio operators (Hams) always carry a spare battery. It's a good idea for any portable device that absolutely must function. Batteries do fail. The MDA battery is roughly the size of a pat of butter.

The camera produces a worthy snapshot. Better than nothing if I should happen to spot some creatures from outer-space. I am happy with this device.

An associate pointed me to this brand and I was thrilled with the dual sim idea! No more dragging 2 phones around. (one work, one personal) It will ring to whatever number calls in and I can easily tell it what number to use when texting or calling out. Slick!

Text to speech seems to work better on this one, too, although I still can't use it anymore when I'm on a call. (my old LG would do that lol) So it's a chore to answer a text message if I'm on a call.

I read online the fingerprint reader is inconvenient, but I love it where it is... you're going to push that button anyway so the reader there unlocks the phone instantly. And it takes multiple fingerprints, so even easier to unlock one handed.

I don't game on my phone, so I have no idea of how it runs games, but so far, for half the money of the samsung, I have a phone that I truly enjoy. =-)
