title: Will work on Verizon
text:
I've had this phone for a few months using it with straight talk and so far I like it just as well as the note 9 that it replaced after an accident. Also yes this phone will work on Verizon. I don't know why it's not common knowledge at this point but Verizon made a press release last year stating that back in January they started phasing out their cdma network. All new Verizon phones are gsm now and cdma will not work at all after dec 31 2020. Just letting people know, you can look it up if you don't believe me but i assure you its true. Now to the review.

Screen is great, camera is decent. The battery life isn't too bad and gets me through a whole day of streaming music at work, watching YouTube and browsing the internet and leaves me around 20-30 percent at the end of a typical day. Fast charging is good and can charge the phone from dead to 100 in about an hour and a half. The international model here that I ordered does infact come with 8gbs ram and 128gbs storage and is plenty fast for my needs. In the box was the fast charger, usb c cable, wired ear buds, extra tips for the s pen with the removal tool, sim tool and a clear gel case. The only real issue I've had with the phone is the fingerprint sensor not being reliable but the work around I found that works is to add the finger I use the most for unlocking my phone twice when setting it up and haven't had an issue since. I've not used the facial recognition so can't give any feedback there. Overall I'm pleased and have reordered this phone for gifts this xmas.

title: Customer Service is atrocious, no unlocked bootloader so no support when Huawei stops
text:
If you're looking at this phone. Don't.

Here are my reasons why:
1. No unlocked bootloader - this allows you to get updates if Huawei every abandons them

2. There is no advanced RMA process - so if your phone breaks, you have to go 2 weeks without a phone till they fix it. If the replacement has an issue, same process. I did this for over 5 months before I gave up with my Nexus 6P last year.

3. The CIA, FBI and NSA have both released statements asking you NOT to buy Huawei because the Chinese Governments install backdoors in the phones firmware (base level code) to send your data back to China.

If you're looking for an amazing phone in this price range, buy a Google Pixel 2 XL directly from Google. You will have an amazing customer service experience, unlocked bootloader and no spying, which you can ensure if you really wanted to by installing something like Copperhead OS.

title: AT&T Customer -- Forget this Phome
text: Still incompatible with AT&T's 4GLTE network. Unihertz's advertising is false. Rather than doing the right thing -- which is obtaining and assiging unique IMEIs for the Titan -- Unihertz took an unfortunate and improper short cut. Specifically, Unihertz assigned IMEIs reserved for other phones it sells, like its Jelly Pro, and attached those IMEIs to the Titan. Unihertz has little-to-no legitimate or unique IMEIs for the Titan which are recognized by AT&T (because Unihertz never obtained hem properly in the first place). Because of Unihertz's actions and/or inactions, as described herein, AT&T always designates the Titan as a 3G phone -- but AT&T is eliminating its 3G network in 2022. So, basically, the Titan will be useless and a waste of money and time, merely because Unihertz did not obtain properly the necessary IMEIs for the Titan. This is upsetting and reprehensible.+

title: NOPE: 20-month UPDATE
text:
I no longer wanted to upgrade/renew carrier contracts with payments for flagship phones. As nice as Samsung S phones are I just don't need a $100+/mo bill. So when it was time to finally replace my S6 I looked into the latest unlocked options and found this Moto G7 Play to fit the bill for features, function, and price. I am super happy to have a paid-for phone with a $35/mo prepaid account! The star off the overall rating is for the camera - it's crap, at least compared to the S6. I thought the 13MP camera of the G7 would vastly outperform the 8MP of the S6 - nope, so lesson learned about phone cameras. I'm glad I kept the Samsung to pull out for times that I want good photos! Otherwise I am quite happy with this phone. Storage capacity is expandable to 512 GB with a micro SD card, and hopefully the 128 GB I put in mine will outlast the phone. Screen is slightly larger than the S6 which is just right - I didn't get the straight G7 as it's like an inch longer and would feel weird. Battery life is awesome, but of course the real test will be how it holds up over time. The USB 3.0 connection is nice and the quick charge is legit - usually takes no more than an hour to go from my typical low of 10-15% to full.
UPDATE 9-2020: Taking a star off at this point and stating that I doubt I will buy this level Moto phone again. After 16 months it is becoming obvious that you get what you pay for and that is not going to be a 3-year phone here. Battery is still "OK" but has noticeably diminished, and in the frustratingly diminished department there is processing speed. Admittedly I get lazy about killing my background apps but even so this phone has become S-L-O-W, especially camera processing which is making one of the worst aspects this phone had when it was new often intolerable. No worries about outliving the 128g storage, anyway - I doubt I'll have this phone after Christmas.
UPDATE 11-2020: Sooo slow and HATE new update - horizontal "page back" swipe totally interferes with horiz. scrolling on most apps. The upward "home" swipe scrolls my text convo list about 2 pages down if you are not careful and don't do it s-l-o-w-l-y (guess it's a theme with this phone). Back to Samsung!

text: I purchased this phone on 12/15/21 to replace a failing S10.  I have always owned the flagship Samsung phones, so I was very hesitant before buying this, but the reviews convinced me to give it a try.  I am definitely happy with my decision. I switched my Verizon sim to the new phone and have never had an issue.  The phone is fast and reliable.  I mostly use it for talk, text, Quickbooks app, Calendar and Maps.  The battery is a true 2 day battery under most circumstance.  I do not game much on it, but gaming does use more battery power. The size is comfortable and seems light weight.  Screen resolution is fine and the fingerprint unlock feature actually works! It works really well. Never got the S10 fingerprint to work at all.  I saved about half of what a flagship phone cost and I can tell no difference in performance and features, other that the Moto does not have wireless charging.  I would highly recommend this phone.

title: Battery will not charge
text:
Since I threw away the packaging, I guess I won't be sending this damaged phone back - i'm very disappointed indeed... tossing it into the recycle bin.

This phone really looks like a great item, the battery had enough charge, out of the package, to allow me time to transfer my tracfone minutes, air time, and phone number... i even updated my air time for another year... then a battery low notification... the phone shut down... the battery will not charge, the charger connection wobbles around and i spent hours trying to get it to work. I even tried the following, on-line information, with no results:

Please follow the steps below to reset your phone. This procedure is called "soft reset", so data from your phone will not be deleted.

1. Turn off your phone
2. Remove battery and SIM card (if you have SIM card in your phone)
3. Wait 5 minutes
4. Replace SIM card and battery
5. Press and hold Power button for 20 seconds.
6. Plug the phone into the charger

If that doesn't work, please try the procedure below:

1. Turn off the phone
2. Remove battery
3. Plug the phone into the charger (without battery)
4. Wait 5 minutes
5. Replace battery in the phone while still on charge
6. Press and hold Power button for 30 seconds.

title: Phone loses ability to stream HD video. Mediocre refurbished battery life.

I have tried resetting the phone and calling LG for support, to no avail. LG customer support suggested that the downgrade to L3 certification might be the fault of the seller/refurbisher.  Unfortunately, since 94 days passed since I bought the phone, I am unable to return it for replacement. I will be trading it in at a Verizon store for a discount on a properly functioning phone. Serves me right for buying renewed.

title: most thing is OK but the voice dial feature
text:
I bought this phone about a month ago and found it is very good. I like the camera and it can also record short video clips! I bought a bluetooth headset for my v710 so that I can talk with hand free.
The main issue is about the voice dial. When I try to call some of my friends with Chinese or Indian name, it is really difficult to be recognized. I have to try again and again to guess what the phone will pronounce them. Although the voice dial feature is "non-specific person speech recognition" so that we don't need to train the recognizor, why not also proivdes some method for the user to hear the target name pronounciation? In the other words, if the user cannot train the recognizer, why not let the recognizer train the user? I still have several friends which I don't know how my v710 will pronounce their names , so that I cannot call them by voice dial.

Another issue is about the life of the battery. It can only last two days after fully charged. Considering it has double color screens, I can somewhat accept this although it is really troublesome to charge the phone every two days.

title: and it works fine. I contacted Motorola Support and she walked me ...
text: I ordered a "Like New" Moto G5 Plus from Amazon Warehouse deals.  It arrived on a Friday and I was excited, until I inserted the SIM card from my old Moto XT1060 into the new phone.  The new phone did not recognize the SIM card at all.  It said "No SIM card."  I reinstalled the SIM in my old phone, and it works fine.  I contacted Motorola Support and she walked me through several steps including a Factory Reboot of the phone.  It still wouldn't recognize the SIM. The Tech Support person told me I should return the phone to the place where I bought it. So today is Monday and I'm returning the phone to Amazon after only 3 days.  I've checked some online Android forums and it appears that there are many other people who had the exact same problem with their Moto G5 Plus not detecting or recognizing the SIM card.  I definitely need a new phone but want something that's going to work.

title: All Talk - No Action
text:
Having used this phone for the last 3 months, I think I have it figured out. It Sucks !!!

Pros:

1. Has Bluetooth - Basic, but at least it has it

2. Brilliant color screen - pretty good screen

3. Adequate memory - stores tons of contacts & can add additional trans-flash memory

4. reception: better than other Motorola phones

Cons:

1. Bluetooth - Basic Bluetooth... all you can do is connect to a hands-free device. You sync your contacts, emails, calendar etc to your PC but you need to buy the PhoneTools software from Motorola. You cannot use it as a modem to connect to the internet for your laptop using Bluetooth - you have to buy a data cable for that.

2. Camera - Supposedly a 1.2 Mega pixel camera... it takes pics worse than my 2 year old Samsung camera. Very bad picture quality.

3. Antenna - you would expect for the price of the phone you get a good antenna, but the extendable antenna pops out very easily and I have already bent it in my pocket several times. Extendable antennae are past, all the new phones have fixed antennae.

4. Battery - My battery discharges in 3 hours now, even if I don't use it. Mine could be a defective battery.

5. Build quality - right from day one I have noticed when I open the clamshell it makes scratches on the case... now remember, the case it black & it gets very visible.... This is really unacceptable.

I expected more from Motorola, but I am really disappointed. Bought it when it was first released since it was the latest & greatest... ouch.... what a mistake, I should have believed the other reviews. I guess Motorola knows about these flaws that why it came up with a newer model - V810/E815 pretty much immediately. Not sure how good the newer models are, but make sure you read the reviews before you buy them.

title: HORRIBLE PHONE, HORRIBLE SELLER: Buy Something ELSE From SomeONE Else
text:
This phone DOES NOT HAVE A USER MANUAL.

Don't let 'em lie to ya -- that li'l scrap of paper included is a "quick-start guide" -- which we all know consists of nothing more than tiny pictures to half@$$ depict how to put the battery in the phone. And don't bother trying to locate a manual on the manufacturer's website -- it ain't there, either. Oh, wait -- but the li'l scrap of paper is featured!!! Well, just have a look -- it has 14 pages, so it must be worth something, no? NO !!! All but 3 pages are the same info printed in languages other than English >.< Precursors of this phone have REAL, genuine, honest-to-goodness user manuals, and they're posted on that site. But guess what? Not THIS one.

I emailed the seller to inquire about it my inability to locate a manual right away. After several days of no response from these guys, I gave up and began snooping on my own. And as I mentioned: Nada.

And this silly piece of you-know-what is NOT self-explanatory, as every flip phone I've owned in the past has been. The few functions that I've been able to figure out on my own aren't even located where they should be in the phone's layout -- interface stinks bigtime, and we're not even talking about data!!! Somebody worked really hard at taking a simple flip phone and turning it into a complicated POS needlessly. And everything takes multiple strokes, presses and messing around as well as a bunch of time and aggravation to execute.

Further, as someone else pointed out, there aren't even buttons on the phone's exterior. Further, it drops calls, the reception is lousy -- cuts in and out during conversations.

I think, however, that beyond my complete frustration and profound hatred of this despicable device -- my disdain for it is surpassed only by my fury at, and extreme distaste for -- a non-responsive, irresponsible seller.

title: Buyer beware:  No security patches or updates of any kind.
text: I purchased this phone some 6 months ago.  3 months after purchasing came the "stagefright" vulnerability.  I checked my phone for updates, found none available... gave it a couple weeks, and then contacted Posh.  They informed me that they were looking into it.  Two months later, and no updates.  I contacted them, again.  Their reply was that they were in the pre-development stage with Lollipop.  Note:  this is no longer the most recent version of Android.  So, basically, what you can learn from this is that if your smartphone needs updates, you won't be getting them from Posh.  Expect zero security patches from this company.  For that reason, alone, I do not recommend this phone to anyone.  If it wasn't for that, I'd give it 5-stars.  As it is, I feel 3-stars for zero security patches on a smartphone is more than generous.

title: Bulky Mid-Priced Phone
text: I have had this phone for a very short time, so updates to this review will be in order. Firstly, this is a USB C device, so do yourself a favor and buy some USB to USB C adaptors when you purchase this if you don't already own any USB C wires.  None of the cords I have placed around my home for convenient charging work with this phone because they are all micro USB.  And before I forget, also buy at least a cheap soft case for this phone at the same time you buy this phone.  It is SLIPPERY and will slide off of any surface you place it on no matter which side you lay it on.  Be aware that this phone is almost a full inch longer than a LGMoto 5G Plus and a lot heavier (read the specs in the listings carefully.)  With small hands like mine, it's impossible to use this phone one-handed.  I tried in vain to find a smaller phone that had the features I wanted.  Why are they all so big now?  If I wanted to carry around my tablet, I would!  Having said all that, this is like a poor man's Samsung.  It offers a lot of features for a mid priced phone with less wow-factor.  It also comes with too much bloatware which you can't really uninstall. The camera is laden with features and customizations and is a bit daunting to use once you turn off auto.  However, I took some excellent video of an urban hawk having breakfast in my yard this morning, and with minimal fuss or tweaking on my part. The fingerprint sensor is fussy and it takes two or three tries before it works for me.  The phone comes with Google Assistant but so far I haven't been able to do anything really useful with that feature so don't really see the point for me, but for those of you who have Smart everythings, this would be a great feature.

title: Will NOT connect to AT&T 4G/LTE..which means no MMS messages
text:
i have had several International versions of Samsung phones and have never had an issue with connecting to the AT&T network; however, this phone ell only send ad receive simple text messages. SO that means no picture or video messages or long text messages.

After an hour on the phone with AT&T, I was advised that this phone drops service down to 2G when sending MMS messages...which makes no sense to me since I can still game, video chat and stream music with no problem.

I then tried to contact Samsung through Twitter and was told that since this phone was an international version, they were not able to help me by simply providing the correct APN settings so I can us MMS services. Instead they dismissed me and gave me some other Samsung website site for tech support.

IF I can not get Samsung or the sellers of this phone to provide the correct APN for MMS messaging, I will be returning the phone to the sellers for a full refund. And if I receive any trouble receiving the sellers, I will just have the problem resolved by my financial institution since what was advertised was not actually what was sold.

title: Amazing phone except for camera quality
text:
I bought this about a month ago myself for my first phone and it's great! I'll break down the basic aspects of this phone.

Prepaid:
It's prepaid which is what I wanted so I wouldn't have to agree to contracts. With using up the money (on data) to make it last longer all I have to do is turn the data off when I finish replying to a message or not checking anything then when I know I should be getting a reply or some kind of other notification I turn the data back on and repeat the process. By doing it this way I spend only about $.01 each time I turn it on then back off again (I have all background data off for my apps which I highly recommend you do). Here is a tip: if you use only prepaid cards texts using the system's default costs $.20 per text sent and received (not worth it); install a free texting app (I use TextNow) and use data on that to get around the $.20 per text sent and received and pay about $.01 "per text" when you turn data on and off. Also as a note about redeemin... Read more

Fully remmaned devices that are good as new, they even have a label identifying who tested and certified the device with date and IMEI to ensure it's the right unit. This company offers so many remmaned products at below market prices. The device was shipped in two protective layers of packing materials. Even included the wall plug for charging, more and more companies and devices have stopped including this.

Highly recommend the Revvl 5G, it should be noted this model is superior to the Revvly V+ 5G. Even if this isn't the phone for you. title: Great for porting!
text:
I got this phone for one reason only -- I was porting a land line to Google Voice.

After confirming that my land number was eligible to be ported to an AT&T Gophone, I order the phone and the cheapest prepaid plan I could. During the activation process I ported my land line number. Once that worked I called AT&T to get my actual account number (they don't tell you unless you ask, you usually use the phone number to access your account.) With that in hand it was simple to port the number to my Google Voice account. While I was waiting for the porting to be completed from AT&T to Google Voice, I simply set the phone to forward calls to my Google Voice number, which rings on my real cell phone.

This phone is cheap cheap cheap, but for what I used it for it was perfect.

title: Good price, great phone

However, the face scan feature can be annoying if you just want to pause, play, or skip songs on the lock screen or just seeing what notification you just received.

If you don't already have a modern phone and don't want to blow your bank account, then this phone is a perfect choice.

title: Bye bye Motorola
text:
So for the past 5 years, all of my phones have been Motorola. Started with the g4 and then my x4 (which I loved). Both lasted me two years and worked well for heavy use. I had such a good experience that I even bought my family members Motorola phones over the years.

Well no longer. This phone has made me lose all of my love for the brand. I bought in April and by July the charging port was broken and battery could barely last a work day. Customer service couldn't tell me if limited warranty would cover it unless I sent it to them. The past two phones survived drops daily with no cracks on the screen but this phone barely lasted a few months before breaking completely after dropping it only a couple feet off the ground. Software would mess up a lot as well, phone would shut off for no reason at times. The phone was amazing those first 3 months but not worth it for that.

So yeah, good bye Motorola, glad I can use the money I was setting aside for the Razr on something different.

title: Awesome little phone
text:
First, the most amazing thing about the phone is its size! This is the smallest phone I have ever seen, and the fact that it includes a camera, bluetooth, and pda functionality is simply stunning. Reception was awesome with T-Mobile. Even in my apartment where Sprint and AT&T barely work, everything was solid during an hour long conversation and the person could hear me loud and clear. They could even hear me putting away dishes! I really liked the joystick-based navigation, which made browsing through menus easy and precise. The camera was average, about the same as Sanyo 8100.
There are a few negatives that keep this phone just short of a 5 star rating. Probably the biggest is lack of speakerphone, which I found surprising for a $200 phone. I guess they're assuming you'll go for the wireless headset, but for me, speakerphone is a convenience I just can't do without. I felt the phone was almost too small at first, difficult to keep in your hand and easy to press the wrong buttons, but was able to adjust in a few days. The biggest problem for me though was the lack of the standard "call" and "end" keys. Placing and ending calls was easy enough to figure out, but getting out of the internet requires bringing up the "more" menu and selecting exit. I kept having to remind myself of this procedure. I should note I didn't get to work with the pda features much or try syncing with my computer, as installing the software required Microsoft Outlook, which I don't have.
All and all, a great little phone. If you want something small and light and don't mind not having a speakerphone, I would definately recommend.

title: nothing but trouble
text:
I have read the other reviews and I seem to have the same problems with this phone. Within a month of buying this phone brand-new, it started shutting itself off. This a major problem since this is my only phone. It also freezes a lot and you have to take out the battery to re-start it. I drop calls all the time and have a funny noise that sounds sort of like an atomic bomb in the background of most conversations. I also hear myself a lot through this phone. The weird antenna thing has started to seperate and very recently, within the last month, my screen has gone out so I can't see what I am dialing. I have only owned this phone for a year, this combined with the fact that these problems are consistent between owners of the phone is the reason why I gave it one star.

Now, people ask me why I didn't get a new one since the problems started within a few weeks of buying it. I called Cingular and they admitted that it sounded like I bought a phone with a 'software problem.' You think? Then they told me that they were going to mail me a refurbished one in place of the one I bought. I paid FULL PRICE for a brand-new phone that turned out to be a broken piece of crap and the only thing they offered is to send me a refurbished phone, a.k.a. someone else's broken piece of crap. Way to keep your customers guys, I have been with Cingular for three years. Needless to say, I am getting a new phone soon and I am shopping for a new wireless carrier and doing a lot of research before I buy a phone.

title: I like it more than my smartphone!
text:
I got this phone 2 days early!

OK. First off, I must elucidate some facts. This phone has some history behind it. The original Sidekick LX 2009(PV300) was discontinued initially in 2010. It was re-released in two forms: The Mobilicity Mobiflip(Sharp PV300G) in late 2010 and the Cincinnati Bell Sharp Jump (PV300GC/PV300GR)in 2011.

I received the PV300GR. This is not the ORIGNAL(nor does it come in the original black box), yet, it is a modified version that doesn't include the Catalog, AIM/Yahoo/Live IM clients, the browser, or the Email client. Instead, there is a generic IM application(I guess you could use any handle/service you want), Opera Mini(an EXCELLENT browser); the Catalog and Email client have no replacements.

The misconception arises with people saying this phone can't access the Internet. The truth is: The original Sidekick can't, nor can the Mobiflip because they lack the option to change the network APN. The Sharp Jump does have this option, meaning you can change the APN, thus you can get online.(There is a caveat: The 3G bands are 1700/2100, so you can only get 3G with T-Mobile, or any MVNO that uses T-Mobile like Simple Mobile and Straight Talk. Otherwise, you'll revert to GRPS/EDGE for data, like I do on AT&T.) This also goes for Multimedia Messaging, so long as you know and change the MMS gateways.

As a phone, it functions very well. I can hear callers clearly, and they have no problem hearing me. However, to me, it seems that there is a slight echo whenever I speak. Also, the ringer is not terribly loud. It's enough if you're close to it, but you probably won't hear it if it's two rooms away.

As a messaging device, it's awesome. The keyboard is very spacious, but a little shallow: the buttons don't have a lot of give. The text messaging and multimedia messaging inboxes are seperate, and that's nice. There's no threaded messaging in these applications, nor is there a lot of space in either(100 messages on device and 30 on SIM for texting; 2MB total for Multimedia messaging). There is an auto delete function for both, so that's a means of management for heavy texters.

As a browser, it's OK. Obviously, browsing would be better on a smartphone, but Opera Mini does a commendable job of rendering pages through Opera's compression servers(helps save money for those who browse per kilobyte). Text entry is a snap with the keyboard.

This device also has a 3.5mm headphone jack along with a microSDHC slot(I think it'll take up to 32GB; I have a 16GB card and it works fine). The media player functions great. You can access it wherever you may be on the phone by pressing the Jump and Done buttons at the same time. However, getting video to play on the device is a troublesome task. It says it supports MP4 and 3GP, but all the files I've thrown at it were not supported. I'll have to try a different video codec and report back...

The customization options are fair enough. You can choose one of four themes for the main screen(I found means of sideloading themes, but that doesn't work for this phone. A slight bummer.) You have plenty of choice for ringtones, but to set them, you must go into the Phone, Text Messaging, and Multimedia Messaging applications to set each kind of alert. You can import ringtones from Multimedia messages(once you set it up), but they don't have the custom light patterns like the default ringtones. Instead, the moodlights flash to the bassline and the trackball cycles the color spectrum.

The camera will do in a pinch, just not inside. If you are inside trying to take a photo, make sure to have some lights on to begin with. I haven't messed with shooting video, but seeing as it only shoots up to QVGA, I personally wouldn't bother.

Overall, I have to give this phone a 5/5. It's a great device for those that just message a lot, or need the basics. You want apps, go get a smartphone(Honestly, you really won't be missing much... heh.) I'll monitor the comments for anyone who also happens to receive the Sharp PV300GR and who want help to set up the settings for the Internet and Multimedia Messaging.

UPDATE: 8/7/12:I've figured out how to place Themes and Videos on the device.
Videos are best encoded in 3GP format, at a resolution of 480*272 with the H.263 video codec and the AAC audio codec. You can just paste them anywhere on the drive.
Themes are created as such(NOTE: YOU NEED A MEMORY CARD FOR THIS):
1. Plug your phone into your PC with the USB cable.
2. Access the phone's drive and create a new folder called Themes.
3. For each Theme, you must have all defined elements noted in a text file, titled theme. A simple one can be made as such:

string Name(en_US) (Place the theme name here, must be the same name as the folder)
bitmap ring-background (Place the name of the photo you want as the background here, including the file type, ie: neon.jpg or neon.png. I HIGHLY recommend using a 854x480 photo)
bitmap ring-folder-background (Can be the same as above, or a different photo. Again, follow the same rules for bitmap ring-background.)

4. Place the theme.txt file and the photos in the same folder. Title the folder the same as the theme name.(If you set the string Name(en_US) as Neon, then the folder MUST ALSO be titled Neon.)
5. Place the folder in the Themes folder.
6. Unplug your phone from the PC and give it a few moments to read your card. From the main screen, press Menu and go down to Themes. Your theme should show up below the built in four.

UPDATE 11/9/12: I am using this phone with Simple Mobile, and I have 3G(!) internet access.
Their APN is simply(heh) simple. No password or username.

title: IMPORTANT:  AT&T Will Not Help Configure This Phone to Work With Their Network
text:
The phone itself seems very decent. However, it is NOT compatible with AT&T's data network. We took it to AT&T today and the rep explained that many of the phones not manufactured by U.S. companies can't connect to their data network. She verified that call/text works, but said that the phone could not find the data tower. The issue has to do with frequency. Also, the UMIDIGI is not supported by AT&T, therefore their tech support will not help troubleshoot. UMIDIGI and any other non-U.S. company that manufactures cell phones (we are having this same issue with a V-Mobile) should consider approaching AT&T about being placed on their supported-phones list so that AT&T can help troubleshoot. They should also verify frequency compatibility. UMIDIGI has sent us an email stating it is compatible, but AT&T says it's not.
________________________________________________
8/20 I am changing my review due to an email response I received from UMIDIGI tech support. It reads:

Dear Sara,

I can assure you, the UMIDIGI A1 Pro is perfectly compatible with all mobile data networks used by AT&T. Please watch the following video.
https://youtu.be/XJCztxhSm54
However, you might need to edit the APN settings to be able to get connected to the data network. The At&T representative should've been aware of that. Please contact AT&T for the proper APN settings, then follow the steps below.
1. Go to Settings → Network & Internet More → Cellular networks → Access Point Names
2. Select an existing template from the list or create a new one by tapping the + icon in the top right corner.
3. As the APN enter the URL that is used by your service provider. (sometimes it's just a word, not a URL)
4. Change other parameters (Username, Password etc.) if needed.
5. Tap the 3-dot menu button in the top right corner and select Save.
Now you are ready to use your mobile net if you have set the correct data.

Yours sincerely,
------------------
BENEDEK TOTH
Community Site Administrator
Senior Technical Consultant
Senior Marketing Consultant

Email: ben@91umi.com
www.umidigi.com
______________________________

It's too bad it came a little late and we had already shipped back the phones. As I state previously, the phones seem pretty decent. This might be excellent information for UMIDIGI to include with their product.

title: WORST PHONE EVER - 0 STARS
text:
Do not buy this phone. This is my third (and last) Treo Palm in the last eight months. The phone will be fine for a while (except for dropping calls at least once a day and not getting reception inside my house) and then, after a few months, the many design flaws and problems assert themselves:
* On my current phone, the battery and/or phone overheated constantly to the point where I could smell something burning.
* The error message says the free data storage space is low and some data could not be saved. I looked for a way to delete some data off the phone, but I can't find a way to do it (not user friendly).
* The phone would never hot sync the calendar data.
* Another phone would freeze up, and I would have to reset it constantly. It then crashed and continually reset itself over and over again. I had to take the battery out. There was no way to retrieve any data from this phone.
* Another phone also always froze, and the email stopped working.

Worse than the phone, however, was Verizon customer "service." I went to the store, and after standing in a long line, I was told to call customer service to get a new phone sent (if you ever do get this phone, BE SURE to get the warranty plan that sends you a new phone every time the Treo craters, because it will - often). About five or six days later the phone arrived. I called customer service, explaining that my hot sync didn't work, and they said, no problem, take it to the store to have them transfer the data. I took the new and old phone to the store, stood in another long line, and they said they could only transfer the contact info, but not the calendar (another Treo design flaw). They said to call customer service to get the calendar to sync.

When I got home, I spent three hours on the phone with a tech. After I told her I wanted to hot sync the phone, and that I had crucial calendar data backed up on my laptop's Palm desktop, she had me download new software and delete the old software. This ended up deleting all my laptop's backup data (including medical history, work billing information, and other important calendar info) - and restoration of the old software only ended up corrupting it - and the hot sync deleted EVERY BIT OF CALENDAR DATA off of my old Treo! No problem, she said, all that data is backed up on Outlook. I looked in Outlook, and my 700P does NOT back up to Outlook - another design flaw. (The Windows-based 700W does, and it's probably better than the 700P for this reason. She probably assumed all Treos backed up to Outlook.) Because my hot sync never worked, and because the tech support deleted all my data, I now have no record of any past or upcoming appointments.

I went to the store to replace it with a Blackberry, but the Treo data won't transfer to it, and the Blackberry wouldn't hold my 1,200 business contacts, so I'm stuck. If I can't retrieve the data from my computer or backup, it may be worth the $175 contract termination fee to switch to a different provider in order to keep the Treo and its contact data. In the meantime, wish I could find a great phone that's a good PDA and email device too....

title: Great phone, once some minor adjustments are made.
text:
I'm personally using this phone on T-mobile. That said, this is not the greatest phone for rural use - mainly due to the lack of band 71 support. For those having signal issues, look up how to enable VOLTE, then make sure your phone is only connecting to NR/LTE - I would paste links in here, but they would be removed anyway. The articles are out there, and they work. You'll have to remember to enable VOLTE as this phone wants to default to connecting to 3G to make voice calls. That's why Cricket and AT&T won't support this phone because they're both scrapping their 3G networks sometime next year. It seems counterintuitive that making it so the phone WON'T connect to the 3G network would give you a better, more stable connection- but it does. Xiaomi really NEEDS to offer some products with band 71 support (and n71).. I'll be the first one in line when they do, cause their phones are currently the best value for the money.

Oh, and Dolby Atmos! Makes all the difference in the world when streaming through connected bluetooth devices, like cars and headphones. Bravo!

title: Pantech Pursuit
text:
I received this phone several months ago as a Christmas gift/replacement for my (very) outdated old flip phone. My initial reaction was that the Pantech Pursuit was quite a nice little phone; fairly stylish, slide-out QWERTY keyboard, nicely designed, and up-to-date. After a few weeks of use however, I quickly realized that that was where the positive qualities end. So what makes this phone such a bomb? Let me tell you.

*Poor Call Quality
Now I don't know if it's due to the poor reception issues that seem to plague this phone (I often have "0" bars of service inside my own house, and I live in an average suburban area), or because the touch screen is so sensitive (perhaps my cheek inadvertently hits the 'end call' button when the phone is up against my face), but making calls with this device is a real test of my patience. After dialing the number, all the phone will do is ring a few times (or sometimes not at all), before simply going back to the home screen. I try again, with the same result. And again. And again. This morning, it took me six attempts to call my dentist's office to schedule an appointment. Absolutely unacceptable. There is simply no excuse for a phone being unable to perform the very task it was invented for.

*Poor Texting Abilities
Let's face it: texting seems to be the fastest growing preferred means of communication nowadays. And especially for those in the working world (or even just those of us who like to keep in touch quickly and efficiently), communication is extremely important. This phone, put simply, is worthless for this means. Very often, my text messages do not go through. I simply receive a message saying "Sending to so-and-so failed, saved to outbox". What use is this to me? I don't want my messages saved, I want them SENT, like a phone is SUPPOSED to do. I have to turn the phone off and back on, and that usually (but not always) gets it to send the message through. Extremely tedious and annoying, especially when I have to do this multiple times per day. I'm not talking only a handful of messages not going through, I'm talking somewhere around 50%.
An additional note on this subject is that this phone's memory capacity is also exceptionally poor; it only holds about 170 text messages in your inbox. Which means if you are anything like me, or the majority of people these days, you will be deleting messages constantly.

*Poor Internet Capability
When I pay extra for a data plan, I expect that data plan to include full, capable internet abilities. This phone however, falls far short. The internet is slow...and I mean slow as in dial-up slow, and often, pages will not load at all. Many don't display properly, and all are extremely hard to navigate. There's no way to make pages bigger. I cannot check my e-mail, conduct transactions (such as via amazon), or even browse my favorite websites. Put simply, the Internet capability (or lack thereof) on this device is so poor, it's almost not even worth having.

*Poor Camera Quality
The camera on this phone is simply and utterly worthless. You cannot take a photo of anything or anyone unless the subject is as still as a frozen statue. If you are trying to take a self-picture, and you move only a hair, it will be nothing but a blur. Images are very low quality, grainy, and there is nothing you can do about it. Kodak moments will simply just have to come and go, because with this phone, there is no way to capture them. This is simply the worst excuse for a camera that I have ever seen in a phone.

*Dysfunctional Touch Screen
As another reviewer put it, the touch screen often can't seem to decide whether it wants to be too sensitive, or completely unresponsive altogether. It seems to have no trouble ending my calls with the slightest accidental touch of the 'end call' button, yet when I'm trying to navigate through the menu screens, it does nothing at all. Compared with my iPod touch (the screen of which is always exceptionally responsive), which I'd owned before, this was a major, major letdown.

*Useless Applications
Trying to navigate through the menus on this phone is a nightmare. As if the dreadful touch screen wasn't bad enough, there are dozens of useless applications to plow through on top of it. Trying to list them all would be pointless, it would be easier to list the ones I DO use than to count out all the ones I don't. This wouldn't be such a problem if there was some way to get rid of all the ones that are just space wasters. Maybe then it would free up space for things I DO need, like some extra MEMORY for my text messages like they should have had in the first place.
On a side note, the phone is really not customizable at all. There are only a few (like about five) tacky background selections, none of which are particularly appealing.

*Lack of Game/App Capabilities
The "games" that come with this phone are a joke. They're all useless, thirty-second demos, none of which are entertaining. And unlike with the iPhone, where you can easily access many thousands of apps and games, including a wide array of free ones, there is no such capability with this phone. So if you're one of those people that also likes your phone to double as a mini game center and keep you entertained on long trips, plane rides, or simply during downtime, you're out of luck with this one.

In conclusion, to say that I am disappointed with this phone would be a massive understatement. It fell far below even my lowest expectations of what a phone should be, and I would never recommend this model to anyone. I have had all I can take, and will be either upgrading to an iPhone, or opting for the early termination fee and going on a different plan, with a different phone. I will not tolerate this piece of garbage for another year and a half. Take my advice, do not purchase this phone.

title: How to put in the SD card
text:
Here is a trick to save time and frustration installing an SD card in this phone.

DO NOT SLIDE the SD card under the silver metal retaining clip as instructed, you will bend the contacts. Instead, use a slight downward pressure on the clip and SLIDE it toward the center of the phone. When loose raise the clip and seat the SD card into position. Then reverse the process by sliding the retaining clip toward the outside of the phone until it snaps in place. Put the battery back in and snap back the case and you are good to go.

title: Would Be A Wonderful Phone if It Had More Storage
text:
8GB is just not enough for a phone. This phone has lots of lovely features but by the time you've installed Instagram and Facebook, you don't have any memory left. Yes you can plug in an SD card and store photos. (I've got plenty of space for photos and the camera's decent, sometimes better than decent!) --But! The problem is you can't install any more apps or ever update any of your apps. You're in friggin' app limbo and it's a raw deal.

Plus, this thing is powerless by itself to stop the onslaught of Xfinity Wireless's aggressive effort to get into your phone. If you happen to have an Xfinity account, you're gonna love it but otherwise, you're going to need to find an app that blocks Xfinity. Good luck installing it cuz you have no space.

I'd give this a much lower rating but honestly I really like the camera, and the build quality. The haptic feedback and water resistance is really nice. This phone's survived some nasty spills on concrete without even the screen cracking. Maybe if you can install expanded storage or a more lightweight operating system, you can get some great use out of this device but as-is, just ugh.

An Amazon winner - great performing HD portal for its screen performance and the best voice calling clarity and ininterruptible performance I've ever had. The Honor 9x is a great successor for my still performing Honor 6X... the 9X that advances in all the ways!

I'm on Cricket, and it uses the AT&T network for great coverage and the phone's battery endurance with network coverage has never let me down for only a $35 prepaid charge for my credit card each month!... Voice, text, and more data than I need because of WiFi and the share of web surfing I do at home!

What's everyone else doing? Who is the gamer that might notice a difference from my experiences, perfect for three years and now I expect the 9x to get me at least another three! Remarkable screen brightness with clarity and touch response easily acceptable (even remarkable) in every situation but for perhaps the direct sunlight.

Getting 90 days returnable Amazon refurb let's me make sure that it is the best thing for me. With a case and Japanese film glass protection I have a great chance of getting the three plus years AGAIN.

These don't always come available so I consider myself lucky to have this one... Very much satisfied.

title: UPDATE 3/18/20 FEELS LIKE A NEW PHONE AGAIN!
text:
***DISCLAIMER I DID NOT BUY THIS OFF AMAZON BUT ON ASUS'S WEBSITE***

Quick summary of old review: Bought phone, used for 2 months and then the flip camera died and was left hanging (pic provided). Nothing would fix it, not even if you were to calibrate it, tap it twice or anything. The motor was dead in such a short period of time.

The customer service that I reached from their website was originally helpful, I did mess up by not realizing their shipping label ($15) expires after 5 days of opening. When I wanted to print it I couldn't. I tried to contact CS again to buy the label from them, because I was having a hard time (said RMA was already created and I couldn't buy it directly from the website). I needed a new RMA. A rep then asked me if I could send them some video/pics because the issue I was complaining about could be a physical issue/defect/whatever and that he could show the pics to the engineers. The answer I received was to reformat my phone or reset my phone (useless). I was going back and forth with them for almost like 1.5 months and that made me unable to get my camera fixed and I wanted to use the camera to take pictures for my trip in February. The camera was a huge selling point for me and that fell short so soon. I was extremely displeased with everything until I saw a comment from Lane who had left a comment on my review but I didn't see it in time. :'(

Edit 3/5/20:
I am upping the stars for my review because of Lane, who contacted me in the comments. I had an extremely hard time with the customer service team that I contacted through their website, but Lane was amazing. Response time, professionalism and everything made me feel way more confident with Asus as a company and the products they offer. I didn't give a 5 star yet because I am going to wait for my fixed phone and will update once I receive it.

3/18/20: I just got my phone back today and the camera is no longer hanging out! Turns out the motor was faulty and they fixed it for me. I did notice it got stuck at the same spot when I tried to take a selfie but then the camera just automatically retracted after a few seconds because it detected abnormal movement! I swear my heart dropped when I saw it but felt relieved seeing that it wasn't permanent. I hope it is not going to become permanently loose again (the horror!). But other than that it is a fully functioning phone again! FINALLY!

Thank you Lane for lending me a hand! I am really impressed and this expeirence made me more confident about owning this product knowing that ASUS does care about their customers. I had an issue with the repair center initially and Lane helped me out tremendously and made sure that my phone got repaired as soon as possible. I am so happy! :)

title: Painfully slow, barely works as a phone, do NOT recommend!
text:
Landfill from factory, it's that bad! Phone is so painfully slow, have no idea why a product like this is made.

Nearly every operation is 2-3 second delay. Attempting to unlock phone is an exercise in frustration... or far more patience than I have. Good luck opening settings like wifi or bluetooth, launching an app... like the camera. Response is so delayed, you'll think the touch wasn't recognized and try again, often making it worse. And what's most unforgivable, attempting to answer a call with sluggishness is an absolutely crap shoot. On several occasions I've been UNABLE to answer a call, simply because the phone doesn't have the power to ring and recognize button press.

And to be clear, the utter lack of performance isn't due to extra apps or simply a bad phone. Entirely factory, no added apps, fully Samung ' updated', and I've recent deployed 25(!!) examples of this <can't think of something review appropriate to enter here> for my company... Sorely regretting going with this budget 'option'.

I can't more strongly recommend going with any other model (and brand). My 5 year old Google Pixel 3 is days faster.

title: Many PROs and few Cons.
text:
I've had a P990i for almost a year, I was looking for a cellphone with PDA capabilities faster, smaller and cheaper than my previous phone and after trying many PDA phones like treo, blackberry and nokia phones I leant towards the HP IPAQ Voice Messenger because of:
1. PRICE, I bought mine at ebay.com (used like new) for only $150, original HP leather bag included + box and all original accesories sealed.
2. PERFORMANCE, the overall phone's performance is remarkable, It is a lot faster than the P990i and surfing on the web via wifi is smooth. All pages open easily even email accounts, I have four differente email accounts and all of them open quite a bit fast with no jams.
3. WINDOWS MOBILE 6, Forget the wait for opening excel, word and pp files, with WM6 everything works fine and quick, unlike symbian OS phones which take too much time to load a file.
4. BLUETOOTH, even though the phone comes with the 1.1 version, I guess is fast enought to transfer mp3 and jpg files.
5. VOICE COMMANDER, I dont know yours but mine works flawlessly.
6. BATTERY LIFE, Its very good, from three to four days in normal use.

In spite of the Pros I fin also some Cons to be considered:
1. NO GPS. Nokia and HTSC phones and some others come with GPS, I guess the next generation of HP IPAQ phones should add GPS capabilities.
2. 1.3MPs CAMERA. why not 2 or higher resolution, my guess is they are using the same sensor found on their web "laptop" cameras.
3. POOR SCREEN RESOLUTION, to my eyes the screen looks bright and clear, but according to the spec the screen has one of the poorest resoltuion seen on a cellphone.

title: Great phone
text:
I have a quality MFT camera for photos and a portable high resolution audio device for quality audio (flac); smart phones can't match the quality of either and I try not to mix various functions into a single device as the various functions suffer as a consequence compared to their discrete brethren. I use a phone as a phone and associated similar things such as a contact manager and reserve the camera for texting only. I never use a phone for listening to music so can't comment on that function.

Motorola/Lenovo have done a very good job with this phone for its primary purpose. Mine has excellent call quality, a decent camera and is fast. I usually purchase my phones outright as unlocked, new old stock and one generation behind. But for the price paid and quality of this phone, I purchased a new model. I am thrilled this phone is unlocked, has no software bloat and is as close to stock Android as possible. It will work with most U.S carriers and many overseas carriers, GSM or CDMA.

title: It's alright.
text:
The phone isn't great, but it works well enough for what I need. For now. I just wanted a slim phone to replace my razr v3 that wasn't overly chintzy and had decent battery life. I didn't want a smart phone; all that extra stuff isn't useful to me. I wouldn't carry a phone at all if I weren't required to have one.

Problems I've encountered:

First, I cannot disable the touch functionality on the front screen, so even with it programmed to lock, from time to time it'll go into camera mode and take pictures of my pocket or start browsing the web on its own. The leather pockets on my jacket are "close enough" for the phone to think I'm fiddling with it. This is especially after I miss a call - the front screen does not lock itself until I clear the missed call message and it will gladly browse and take pictures until then.

Second, the internet cannot be shut off on the phone. I don't have a data plan, so any pocket browsing that takes place comes at a very steep premium. I've read that I have to go through AT&T to shut off data completely, but the plan isn't in my name so I can't even do that.

Third, which I am not sure if this is specific to my phone or it it's a problem with all of the razr v9 models, the battery door on the back does not stay on. The bottom two clips grab nicely, but there is no way for the top clips to attach to the phone, so the top just hangs loosely and from time to time the door just comes off. One of these times, the bottom clips are going to break off and the door will be permanently useless. At least the battery is in there tight enough that it doesn't shut off my phone when the door comes off.

My razr v3 didn't have any of these problems. If I could take the battery out of this v9x and put it back in that, I'd use my old phone again instead. It's also quite clear that this new phone won't hold up for the six year span I've had that v3. The battery on that started to swell, so I figured it was time to update. They don't make them like they used to.

text:
I bought this phone knowing it was a risk. I am on Verizon and have heard mixed reviews as to whether or not I would even be able to use this phone with this carrier. I've only had it a few days, but so far I have no complaints. No issues receiving texts, emails, etc. I love the QWERTY keyboard (of course...it's the main reason I got it). The screen is small and the resolution isn't great but honestly that's not a problem for me - I don't plan to watch videos on this phone anyway. The speaker is so much better than my last phone (Pixel), the battery life is good, it fits in my small hands unlike most new smartphones these days...and yes the camera sucks.

It's not a phone for people who spend hours on social media or YouTube. It's not a phone for people who really want a tablet that makes phone calls. It's not a phone for people who play a lot of mobile games. It's a phone for folks who like a physical keyboard and who want to use their phone for texts, calls and emails. And I love it.

title: Nice Palm OS Smartphone
text:
I've had mine for about 6 days now. At first the battery drained very rapidly. Then I followed these suggested (by John from Monroe Township) preference settings:

Go to Prefs > Power and:
* Turn "Beam Receive" OFF
* Set "Auto-off after" a 15 seconds
* Set your "Screen Brightness" to a medium setting (3 or 4 clicks under MAX or even less)
* Set "Dim backlight after" to 30 seconds
Other settings:
* Turn Bluetooth OFF if/when you are not using a wireless headset or other BT device
* Go to Prefs > Date & Time > Set "Automatically set" to "Nothing" (this makes a very significant difference in power usage

After making those changes, the battery life is pretty reasonable.

I didn't have any trouble getting it activated (via AT&T) after it was shipped from Amazon.

This is my first smart phone. I had been a happy Palm Z22 user for about 1.5 years. So far, I'm very happy with the Treo 680. My favorite Palm applications are still KeySuite (Outlook sync program) by Chapura and Ultrasoft Money (syncs with MS Money).

title: More rugged than a hard boiled egg, Sim Processor shot shortly after 6 months of use.
text:
*Update* This thing is a POS. My phone has essentially been a paperweight for months with no real reason why aside from the software/firmware is crappy to begin with. There’s nothing “rugged” about this phone. If it can’t withstand a SAHM with 2 electronically-Savy but screen limited toddlers, I can’t imagine it ever doing well on a hike, rock climb, mountain climb, etc that it claims to be great for. I do NOT recommend this, and customer service has been nonexistent from the start. Don’t waste your money.... and I am not one to typically write a bad review. Just being 100% honest.

I bought this phone for two reasons... 1) to have a phone withstand my toddler girls and I heir constant curiosity with electronics that has resulted in 2 shattered phone screens (RIP Huawei Mate SEs 😓) and 2) to have a no frills phone that has enough storage capability to take and keep one of pictures, because my animals and kids are adorable. Added bonus was that I could take underwater pictures... cool!

I guess I got what I paid for. I use Mint Mobile and the phone is essentially a paperweight if I am not connected to WiFi. My reception in my area with the Huaweis using Mint Mobile was much better. Takes forever to load a webpage and I have to turn my phone on and off if transitioning from WiFi to data unsafe. All of my Mint Mobile settings are correct and what they need to be. If not on WiFi, I don’t receive messages and texts until I restart the phone. Super annoying as a stay at home mom on the go.

We also spend a lot of time outside, and lo and behold, my 4yo picked my phone up and dropped it on brushed concrete (no pebbles sticking up) and the screen has a deep peck in the glass already that now renders the waterproof feature useless. I had the phone a whopping 2 or 3 weeks and this already happens. Not as rugged as I had hoped, and I wasn’t really even asking for much as far as ruggedness goes. I’m thankful that the screen didn’t completely shatter, but for a rugged phone... the screen is still pretty fragile. Now I can’t return it and am just kind of stuck with it. Phone repair places in my area only fix the big brand screens and prices are astronomical to fix screens anyway, to the point you’re better off buying a new phone (if you haven’t caught on, I’ve been through this before).

Sound quality is good, Bluetooth works much better than my old Huaweis as far as connecting to my car and such. I miss having a fingerprint reader, but the newest version of King Kong phones have them. The load times are seriously so slow on this phone though even on WiFi. I would have probably sent this back had my toddler not already wreaked her havoc on it.

Also, as others have said, the camera is pretty terrible. The only good ones taken are those taken outside. Thankfully, that’s where we spend most of our time, but frustrating any other time. If I had to do it over again, I’d probably splurge a little more to get the newest version or go with a different phone altogether.

title: a steal
text: this phone is a steal. with google voice, I make phone calls and send/receive texts over wifi (using the hangouts dialer) but can resort to regular voice/text when I don't have wifi and/or data. Supposedly these tracfone androids don't have data roaming, but this hasn't been an issue yet for me (I've had 3G coverage nearly everywhere I have cell service so far, and I live in the middle of nowhere northern CA). A couple of minor annoyances: syncing my google contacts to the phone resulted in a mess, so I erased those and used bluetooth to send contacts from my dumbphone to the fuel and turned off auto syncing for my contacts. Also, there are a ton of apps I don't need/want and I haven't looked into disabling or deleting them but I think other reviewers have posted links for useful info on this. I've been using a google voice number and and dumb phone for about a year, but I realized I would save minutes if I could make calls directly from the phone over VOIP (vs using my computer, which always feels weird). So now I don't burn through minutes unless I'm away from wifi, and I've got everything integrated into the phone, rather than always having to check texts and messages on the computer. Receiving calls with hangouts is pretty weird...it seems like the phone and hangouts are battling over which will take the call...tips would be appreciated if anyone else uses GV/hangouts to answer calls. Regardless, for $58 and probably around $10 a month, I don't know of a cheaper smartphone plan. So glad tracfone is getting somewhat up to date smartphones.

title: If you need a decent battery life- this is wrong phone to buy!
text:
This may be the first unhappy review I've written on Amazon...but here goes: I 'upgraded' to this phone recently from a Treo 650 that had speaker and audio problems (don't all Treo 650's suffer from that within a year's usage?). I loved my Treo 650 despite the well-known audio problems that arise, so I expected something equivalent to the 650 when I upgraded. But what I got was a 'smartphone' with quite a stupid battery life. I have decided that there is definitely some glitch in design (some online geeks suggest it might actually be the SIM card) that is causing power to run right out of the phone, in a sharp decline, even when its not in use and all possible extraneous functions are disabled and every "trick" Palm and other users suggest to extend battery performance is utilized. Add to this the fact that Palm's website's online user group is not active right now (so no users can visibly discuss this among themselves),and they have made it next to impossible to reach them to complain about this, you don't have to think too long to conclude that Palm knew this either beforehand or pretty quickly afterward, when they recently dumped this cheaper "smartphone" on the market recently. Sorry Palm, I loved you for the Treo 650 and was willing to live with some glitches, but a horrible battery life on the 680 is not something easy to tolerate. So all I can say is pretty "stupid" and wonder if this was your last hurrah before planning to exit the "smartphone" market? [Despite the prior reviews on this page that were so glowing, anyone who is doubtful of my complaint on battery life, or think that its isolated to just a defective phone here and there, I suggest that you please do a search on the internet before buying this phone, and read the numerous blogs out there on this very same complaint!)

P.S.: search under these words exactly on Amazon: "palm Treo 680 PDA Phone (Unlocked)" to read other reviews of this phone stating similar battery life complaints. Whether locked (meaning tied to any one company like Verizon or Cingular) or not, a Palm Treo 680 is still the same Palm product.

title: will not store lots of music/photos/apps but works very well
text:
PROS: This is a good phone. It doesn't freeze like some of the other cheaper phones and it is pretty quick. It will play most games and will be able to handle browsing the web seamlessly. The touch screen is very responsive. The battery life is awesome. It has a pretty nice looking, bright screen. I paid $100 for the phone and it was a good price then.

CONS: Only 8 GB of internal storage, with no MicroSD slot or any option to add more offline memory to the device. This is all there is for the android operating system, the tons of apps you don't need/do need, pictures and music.

A question on here asked if there is bloatware on the device and some of the answers said no. This is false to the fullest extent. You have whether you like it or not the original android apps which aren't too bad in my opinion; calculator, 2 calendar apps, camera, clock, 2 email apps, phone ect. Then you have google apps; drive, gmail, google settings, google+, google maps, play books, people, play store, quick office, hangouts ect which are less useful. Then you have the apps that are probably good to have when you get your phone; alert, migrate, setup, verizon tones, VZNavigator ect. Then you have the apps that just don't make any sense NFL mobile, play movies & TV, play newstand, ect. In an ideal world, the phone would come with a list of apps that are necessary;phone, contacts, play store ect. and we would download the apps we find useful, but that is not the case. In a less ideal world we could delete the bloatware, which again we cannot do. In the end this device does not suffice for people who want to download alot of music onto it, and play alot of apps. With this device you will have to pick and choose.

One of the ways people remove bloatware and get more access to control the phone how we like it, is unlocking the phone and gaining root access, In some cases like myself Motorola locked the bootloader and so it actually is impossible to remove bloatware at all and gain unrestricted access to something you own.

In some cases you can miss out on free google drive storage, and the storage only lasts for 2 years.

In summation; Motorola makes choices that aren't theirs to make. Even though you own the phone Motorola will choose what apps you have to have installed on your device and what apps you cannot have on your device (i.e. apps with unrestricted access to the phone). They took out the SD slot because users can use the cloud, making their customers access the internet in order to access their external storage. But the four stars here is accurate because the device will work for most people, and it is cheap.

title: Transitioning Sprint users beware
text:
I'm coming from 3 years with a Moto X4 on Sprint. The OnePlus Nord is a nice upgrade. Plenty of RAM to multitask, plenty of storage (no more app rationing!), and enough processor to prevent sluggishness (the camera opens and snaps quickly!).

In the small sample size, photos are okay quality. Good enough for me but I wish it was a bit better. I would have liked a smaller phone, especially since it seems that no video will fit the entire screen at this ratio.

If you are a Sprint customer, beware because you will not be able to use this and keep your service. I thought with the new T-Mobile SIM that I could simply swap the phone but this is not the case and customer service cannot help either. The IMEI is blocked by Sprint and that prevents the user from registering the phone to the SIM card, even though it is T-Mobile. To get this to work, you'd have to switch to T-Mobile billing, at which point you lose your Sprint plan. I was on an incredibly cheap Sprint unlimited plan. The closest I could find was transitioning to Mint Mobile.

title: UPDATED:  AWFUL phone!!!  --->>>>>  old review:  Awesome phone. Probably the best Android phone I have ...
text:
UPDATE: After six months, this phone has gone from hero to zero. The battery, which is NOT REPLACEABLE, lasted about five months and then wouldn't stay charged over four hours, even after charging overnight. Then one night, after the battery died, I powered it back up on a charger to be greeted with "No SIM card". I called Sharp warranty service and was told immediately that it had a broken SIM card holder. I spent $6 to get it shipped to Memphis TN for repair. At this point the phone has cost me around $156. Two days later I got an email from Sharp with a couple of pictures of the corners of the plastic case on the phone which had cracked when I happened to drop it on a CARPETED floor once. They said:

"Sharp repair notice Physical damage on device(see below).

Fee for repair is 110.00 to have device repaired.

If you would like device repaired please reply with callback number to have credit card given.

If you would like to Decline repair please reply I Decline to have device repaired."

I immediately called them and cried foul. I asked for an escalation and got this from the manager:

"We have looked into this further and found that we will not be able to repair the device without also repairing the cosmetic damage, so the $110.00 repair estimate stands.

I can extend the warranty by 2 months as a courtesy should you decide to pay for the repair at Sharp.

Please let us know how you would like to proceed."

I emailed this manager back and asked for another escalation.

This phone is VERY fragile and obviously cannot be repaired without replacement, which is why Sharp is trying to cover their losses by asking you to buy a new phone, essentially. Stay away from it. It isn't worth the $6 I took to ship it to Sharp. I will be lucky if I even get the broken device back from them. The phone starts out good, but then starts falling apart. I am leaving my initial review below just to see how far my regard has fallen. It is really awful.

-------

Awesome phone. Probably the best Android phone I have used. I constantly get comments about how clear I sound on phone calls. The Harmon Kardon sound is great. None of the issue with partitions that HTC phones have. title: Perfect for the technologically challenged
text: Prior to purchase, I had a Jitterbug flip phone, which I was satisfied with, but I dropped it and it broke. I was intimidated in buying a smartphone because I am not tech savvy, to say the least, and do not care about apps, texting or emails. However, I do use google, which jitterbug flip phones do not have. My hesitancy was also compounded by the copious amounts of bad reviews but I thought I would give the phone a go and if I didn't like it I would return it. I have no idea why so many people have problems with the phone. I have been using it a month and have had NO issues. It is easy to navigate and the instructions are easy to follow. Customer service was IMMEDIATE and it was a no hassle experience. In fact, I was shocked that it was such a pleasant experience. Maybe I got lucky, but everything was explained quite simply. Also the screen is not hyper sensitive, like other smart phones. That is another reason I did not want to purchase a smart phone. Every time I used someone's smart phone, the screen would change without me even touching it. Very frustrating! Anyway, this one is not at all sensitive and the screen remains visible for a long time. I also like that you are not locked into any plan. It is very inexpensive. I pay about $30 a month for minutes and data.  In addition, the ring tone is loud enough for anyone to hear and it is easy to type, if you need to.Furthermore I would recommend it to anyone who feels uneasy about technology.

title: THERE IS NO MANUAL FOR THIS PHONE
text:
While setting this phone up, I set up for fingerprint reader; that worked fine. I did not set up for a password, however after turning the phone off and back on again; it was asking for a PW. I went to the website to either get help or be able to download a manual. I was directed to several sites; the last one appeared to be a scam site.
I contacted Amazon's CS for assistance: The people there were very helpful and patient (my patience was wearing thin with Oukitel and the product). The Amazon people did deep-dive searches for a site that would have a manual. Most of the sites were the same as the ones that I had already visited. No manual was to be found. Oukitel does not have a CS group; or doesn't want consumers to contact them: there is no place on their site that offers assistance to the consumer.
If you purchase one of their phones and everything goes well when setting it up; that's good. But just remember that Oukitel is not going to be there if you have a problem with their product!

title: Updated...Overall, I would like to give this Blu XI+ a 4 to 4.2 stars, but...
text:
*UPDATE: OF THE TWO BLU VIVO PHONES I BOUGHT THIS LAST NOVEMBER 2019 (ITS ONLY 7 MONTHS OLD NOW), ONLY ONE STILL WORKS PRETTY MUCH 100% PHYSICALLY. MY WIFE'S PHONE THE WIFI / DATA CHIPSETS ONLY WORK INTERMITTENTLY AND DOG-SLOW. THE OTHER ISSUE IS THAT BLU KEEPS PROMISING THE ANDROID PIE UPDATE SINCE ITS 2018 RELEASE, BUT STILL HAS NOT PROVIDED ONE OTA TO EITHER OF US. I HAVE CONTACTED SUPPORT, BUT WITH NO REPLY OR RESULTS. IM NOW LOWERING MY RATING TO TWO STARS. IF I DIDNT LIKE MOST OF ITS HW FUNCTIONALITY AND PERFORMANCE, I WOULD TRUTHFULLY GIVE THIS PHONE & BLU COMPANY A SINGLE STAR FOR THEIR LACK OF HARDWARE/SOFTWARE SUPPORT.*

Overall, I would like to give this Blu XI+ a 4 to 4.2 stars, but the built-in camera software is badly unflattering for it's camera function, Android Pie OS upgrade is still a no-show after a year or more since release, and the Bluetooth has continuously poor sound quality (staticy) for phone calls shared to both my cars and Bluetooth speakers. The odd thing is that it streams music, such as Prime Music and Pandora cleanly, but poor Bluetooth phone connection to external devices. I use this Blu for car calls all the time, and although the phone itself has clear calling overall, the calling sound over Bluetooth connection, along with the other 2 issues I noted, makes this phone rate more of a 2 or 3 stars for me.
Please fix these issues for us Blu, so I can happily adjust my ratings.

title: Great Phone!
text:
I normally never really cared for Motorola phones. Everytime I have had them with AT&T the phone always froze and calls were always dropped. This phone, with Cingular, is different. I have had the phone for a little over a month now. So far, I have yet to experience any dropped calls. The reception is great. The phone is beautiful. It takes great pictures too. The sleek design is very ideal for me. It fits nicely in my small purses. I do have some concerns though.

First, when I use the bluetooth headset with the phone, the phone battery lasts for only about two days. Also, the outside monitor, on the flip, isn't nearly as clear as the picture on the inside screen of the phone. Also, the keypad does get fingerprints easily (the phone came with a motorola cleaning thing so it really comes of easily). I am though concerned about dropping the phone on my tile. The phone seems really delicate. Using the bluetooth earpiece though allows me just to take the earpiece out of my purse and walk around with that. Remember as with all phones, to occasionally power them off to receive updates from your service provider. This will increase the phone recpetion and prevent drop calls.

Overall, I am extremely happy with this phone. I encourage those who are interested in purchasing this phone to read other consumer reviews such as mine.

title: Excellent value with minimal compromise.
text:
Bought this phone (64gb version) to replace an iPhone 6s 16gb version, wanted to try Android again (tend to ping-pong Apple and Android every other generation).

The phone is incredibly fast and has lots of internal storage. The camera also has a fast shutter and takes incredible pictures when the lighting is just right. The SIM and SD card tray is a little odd until you figure out what's going on, but once you figure it out and slide the tray back in, the phone recognized both no problem. Pretty much stock Android with a few Moto quirks (twist for camera, flick for flashlight) that don't bog down the phone like Samsung software tends to do (my old Galaxy S6). Android 7.0 is its own review, but considering my last Android was 5.0, the newer features are very welcome.

Two things I'm sure people want to know:
1 - This works on T-Mobile no issues; didn't have to call anyone or anything like that, plugged in the SIM and off I went.
2 - My version is the Prime Exclusive with lock-screen ads. Basically, the difference between this and the standard version ($60 more) is twofold: mine came with Amazon's apps pre-installed on the phone, all in their own folder and the lock-screen will almost always have an ad. If you have no notifications, it will be a full screen ad which can be swiped away; if you have notifications, it will just be another notification, always below your main notifications, that can also be swiped away. These ads don't interfere with your ability to get into your phone instantly and don't interfere with notifications or checking the time.

title: A lot of bang for the buck
