title: A great deal for the money
text:
Overall, I'm really pleased with this phone. I use it more for texting, checking work emails, and work-related security such as 2 Factor Authentication and things like network utilities. I don't use social media at all.

I'm the kind of person that prefers to get the most bang for my buck. I might go as far as to say I'm cheap, but when the time comes to spend money, I'm willing to do it. To me, this phone represents a great value. I purchased it to replace a $256 Huawei P10 Lite that I had for just over 2 years. The Huawei always worked fine, but lately I started to notice that the battery wasn't holding the charge as long as it did, and wouldn't last 48 hours. I'm sure I could have gotten the phone to last another year, but the time seemed right for an all-around upgrade.

I compared the 9T Pro to things like the OnePlus and the Razer 2, but each phone seemed to excel at different things. For me, there was no clear and definitive winner in terms of performance vs screen vs camera vs weatherproofing. But getting the battery size, performance, stereo jack, and triple-camera resolution, I opted for the 9T Pro.

The packaging is all slick and a decent presentation. The SIM card was a little difficult to get out, and I was nervous I wasn't going to get it. It's a dual-SIM phone, and I couldn't find a clear definition of which SIM was #1, so I just put my Mint SIM card in one and closed it up. In a minute, I was online and my phone was restoring all my apps. The build of the phone itself seems solid, and I don't feel like I'm holding a toy, or a brick.

It's a big, beautiful screen, with practically no bevel around it. I like the colors, and I've turned the brighness up for my old eyes and also run it in 'Dark Mode' which I find much more usable. It seems silly, but looking at my old phone with the notch now seems ridiculous. I liked that the Huawei had the fingerprint reader on the back, but the screen is livable. It can take a second or 2 to identify where I'm supposed to hold my thumb, but it's still quicker than typing a 4-digit code. The phone has no branding or clear indicator on the front, so it's hard to tell if you're picking it up upside down or not. I like that I can scan multiple fingers so I can unlock it with my left or right thumbs or pointer fingers.

I did try the face unlock feature, and it works pretty well, maybe even faster than the fingerprint scanner. But in order to be used, it has to pop up the selfie camera, and I just didn't want that happening my mistake or a million times a day. More on that later.

The MIUI interface isn't horrible. Like most UI's, is really just takes getting used to before you like it. I don't use any of the Mi software or accounts, just like I didn't use the Huawei versions, so there is a noticable amount of bloatware on the phone. I prefer to stick with my Google account for all things. Luckily, changing the phone to use the default apps like Chrome for the browser aren't too difficult.

Some of the newer features of Android, the phone, and MIUI are enjoyable, like the Ambient display, the icon management, app management and so on. The phone seems more able to be customized to my liking than my previous phone, it just takes some digging. I wound up trying several weather apps before I found one that let me put a 4x2 display of the current date and time along with the weather and the last time the weather was retreived, but that's my own personal battle. By accident once I ran a Mi app to clean up the phone, and it put all my defaults back to the Mi apps, but again it wasn't hard to reset them to my liking.

Performance wise, I can see a real advantage compared to my older phone. It's definitely snappier in most operations, but this typically means in regards to the UI. The finger unlock is nearly instantaneous once you get used to wear to place your finger. Surfing, videos, games, never seem to leave me waiting. I won't say it's all instaneous, but I will say that the added expense for performance was worth it.

The camera performance isn't bad at all, and I like the 3 zoom levels. I would say that performance is again better then my last phone, and photos in decent light are pretty darn presentable and printable. I'm a bit of a snob here, so I won't be giving up my DSLR any time soon, but it's noice to have a camera that can relatively compete with some of the high-grade phone cameras out there.

Audio quality and cell service get no complaints from me. The bluetooth and WiFi all work as expected, and it seems like the BlueTooth allowed me to walk away from my BT soundbar a little farther than my previous phone.

The selfie camera is a bit of a gimick, and might make some nervous. As you switch to and from the selfie camera, the motorized camera pops up and down respectively. It takes a second to pop up or close, so you don't really notice. Quality is fine. But it does make me nervous that it will break or start popping up while in a pocket or something. With that said, I pretty much never take selfies (I'm not from this generation), so the selfie camera means nothing to me.

The battery is awesome, and sitting at my desk yesterday it was going down about 1% an hour. The quick charge feature is very nice, and the wall plug that comes with it is a qiuck charge type, which is a nice bonus. I did find it hard to locate exact specs on what chargers will give fast charging. I believe that 27W QC4.0 charges will go 'Turbo', while 18W QC3 charges will go 'Quick', and regular USB chargers will just charge normal speed.

My biggest complaints about the phone is that I wish it were waterproof, and it keeps connecting to open WiFi networks. The waterproof shouldn't really be a problem as I've never damaged a phone from water in 25 years. And I assume that the WiFi option is a setting somewhere (I've found posts that indicate settings that don't exist) or just a utility app I need to install.

I had plugged phone up just to see if it would power and someone came to my door and so I left for the phone for about 5 minutes and on return I picked phone up and the screen flashed so I gave it 30 minutes plugged up. I figured out how to start it up, press and hold the RED Key. The receiver is too weak I can't pickup any ATT data. First time for that. I get three bars on my pixels. I think I am going to proceed with the return on this and just get a pixel 6 and just use an older phone for ruffing it. So I could not test cellular data with no bars present but my wifi works. the browser picked up CNN great, clear and sharp picture. The interface looked clean. FM radio, settings, video player, calculator, email, browser, my cricket, music, calendar, gallery, alarm, messages, camera, contacts and phone show on the two page menu. I was under the impression from the Alcatel website looking at the Quick Flip 4 that it used USB C this model does not and any car charger will need to be "old timey", this one also did not come with even a quick start guide, it has 998.01 MB of storage free on startup. On this model the ability to download any app from the KaiOS store does not appear to be present. So I think my assumption that this was a quickflip 4 was wrong, there are important differences, like lack of USB C and the missing KaiOS Store. Just the fact you do get an unlocked ATT/Tmobile new generation phone is really all that is included with this. I would need to buy a car charger and a additional travel wall wart since since USB C is out. This turns out to be slightly too plain only because of just those few differences, hopefully knowing this will help you make an informed purchase decision. Oh, it will make phone calls and do texts, I did not mess with email or any app for that matter.

I bought this as a substitute phone for use when my good phone might get broke, like going fishing. When I opened the package none of the normal film was on any of the windows and the battery looked like someone used a lighter to reseal the plastic back up. In any case phone would not power up. It looked like a basic phone and that is all I wanted. I choose the send me another phone return option so by tomorrow I should know if I like it. It did not even have a quick start guide in the box. title: Great tech specs for the price point, but major issue with essential function - making calls.
text:
I really, really wanted to love this phone but, unfortunately, I cannot.

For it's price point it is a spectacular device, but it's got some sort of hardware or software problem, and I'm presuming it's software. When I attempted to make an outgoing call (using a T-Mobile SIM) the device put itself into Do Not Disturb mode and the call would not complete. I spent about an hour or so on the phone with BLU Technical Support and, after all the trouble shooting, it was determined that the unit was defective. I returned it for an exchange. Well, the replacement unit did *exactly* the same thing!! I even went to the trouble of calling Tech Support again just to see if this could be solved, and it could not, so that they would have the information that this was occurring on multiple devices. What was really weird was that one could send and receive text messages without issue as well as receiving incoming calls (and the call quality on those was very good). You just could not make an outgoing call, period.

The technical support reps were great, really patient and diligent about taking me through each and every step for the diagnostic process (and I'm a tech geek myself, so I know whereof I speak). I was really very pleased with the customer service I got from their technical support folks. If the devices were as good as the technical support was this review would probably have been 4 or 5 stars, but when you have two brand new devices in a row that have the same quirky failure, and with an essential and basic function for a phone, someone's dropped the ball.

Let's hope that they get this ironed out, as I doubt very much that these two devices will be the only two that suffer from this issue. It's stuff like this that can really tarnish the reputation of a brand if they don't get moving to figure out what's causing it and a way to solve it quickly and efficiently for those who encounter it.

IF YOU CANNOT MAKE A PHONE THAT IS AT LEAST CAPABLE OF DOING WHAT A PHONE IS SUPPOSED TO DO, THEN YOU ARE NOT SELLING PHONES. YOU ARE ENGAGING IN FALSE ADVERTISING.

This isn't a phone. This is a scam where the seller sells pieces of plastic and metal deceptively shaped like phones and appearing to work like phones just long enough to avoid the buyer calling in to demand a refund for false advertising.

I missed a review saying as much and dismissed it when I saw it out of hope that the phone wouldn't be that bad.

Don't do what I did. Instead, please listen to this review and consider that its not my lack of patience that is causing me to write it. Waited over 8 months to find a remotely-livable place to live while homeless with maggots in my feet and then for the most part while renting from a Biden voting fundamentalist Christian, and as a libertarian atheist, I was nice to her and helped clean her place and helped her pets and helped her when she broke her back and only got angry at her and raised my voice twice - the second time being when I left to come to my current residence. I could put up with lag with Jeff Bezos showing up on the screen to laugh about it along side Big Red without breaking my phone in frustration. I could beat the Dalai Lama in a staring contest and I have extreme sleep deprivation bordering on narcolepsy due to extreme untreated sleep apnea. Despite considering it a vice and for very good reason that all of what I just said and went through has vindicated REPEATEDLY, I do NOT lack patience. This is just a pernicious piece of s*** like the planet that made it. If you don't heed this, then like how Amazon and likely you think it was for me, you don't deserve the money you spent on it. You want to burn your money, then this takes second place right behind NFT's. Literally burning it wouldn't even make the top 10 or even the top 20 at this point.

title: Good but not great phone
text:
I've had this phone for a few weeks now and here are my thoughts on it:
1) Activation was a breeze, to transfer my number from my previous phone to this one. It took just a few minutes.
2) It came with Android 8 but it gave the option to update to Android Pie (9.0) on the same day.
3) The fingerprint sensor lets you store more than one fingerprint. However, it sometimes takes a few tries in order to unlock your phone.
4) The call quality is really good. It's definitely an improvement from my previous phone which was an LG Premier. The sound would sometimes break up during calls on my previous phone. I don't have that problem with this phone.
5) This phone is narrower than my previous phone, but it's probably better that way since my hands are small and thin.
6) The camera is just ok at best. Nighttime pictures come out pretty awful. There's also a bit of lag when you press the shutter button. Unfortunately, that's the primary disadvantage of a budget/midrange smartphone -- that the camera/picture quality is just average.
7) The phone has some handy features such as the "double chop" to turn on the flashlight, and the double twist of the wrist to activate the camera.
8) The 32GB of internal storage is decent, and you can even format an SD card to become part of the internal storage.
9) This phone does not have NFC, which I do not use but it's good to have that feature on a phone in case one does decide to use it at some point.
10) Definitely get a case for it, as the glass back is slippery.
11) All things considered, this is an overall good phone, especially since I only paid $69.99 for it, including the $40 airtime bundle, as it was on sale during Black Friday/Cyber Monday. Shipping was free, though it took an entire week for the phone to arrive.

title: A great replacement for a S7 phone with all the features that new Galaxy phones removed
text:
I brought this phone to replace my S7. Straight out of the box, it set up easily. The fingerprint reader works well. The facial recognition was fast and works really well. I now have a phone that does not need to be charged every two hours. I spend a lot of time on it, usually on youtube, watching videos, and listening to music. I can go through a full day and still have a good 78% charge by bedtime.

I am not sure why people are complaining about where the phone was made. MOST ALL PHONES are made in China or Vietnam. They ALL START at this version - international, then the American phone companies add in all their crappy bloatware and lock them to their networks. It's a scam and, I believe, we are the only country that does that.

You set the phone up the same way. It has loads of languages to select. And, you're done. Nothing but a nice, clean phone. It doesn't have 5G, it's still an LTE phone (4G). Not a lot of phones currently work on the 5G network so this phone should be good for some time. Just because phone companies advertise their 5G networks on TV, doesn't mean you phone is compatible. Currently, there are a handful of phones that are 5G and not every "5G city" actually has "good" 5G service.

It comes with a charging brick in the box. However the Charger has 2 round prongs/pins 220 VAC - Europe, Asia (not for USA,CA,Mex. unless used with adapter). I had to buy an Anker 25W fast charger to use with the phone.

The phone 📱 is definitely water proof and dust proof! It even has a SD card slot for expanding storage! It has 8gb of ram and 256gb of storage! The flagship samsung galaxy s21 don't have expanding storage and it has 1 less camera! Both the front and rear cameras can record in 4k uhd at 30fps! YouTube videos can be watched in up to 4k quality which is awesome!

Overall, this is a great phone for a great price. You are getting a Samsung phone that is large, has all the features you want and none of the phone company excess weighted garbage installed. If you want a newer phone, don't need or want the high end specs, or high end price, I would recommend this phone to you. It looks good, it sounds good, and it comes at a reasonable price.

The worst thing about this phone is that Cingular blocks outbound dial-up calls over USB and Bluetooth. I had hoped to use my handheld and laptop to dial-up into my computer and get internet access with out paying for a cingular plan, but they have disabled this feature. I still rate the phone a 5 because this is cingulars doing (SIM block).

Otherwise, the phone is amazing. Out of the box it is quite hard to get to your address book, but you can customize the main screen and change any of the shortcuts. title: So far, so good
text:
I've had this for 3-4 weeks now and it is a pleasure to use.

A very nice phone. No bloatware. Everything seems to function smoothly with Google aps in the Google universe.

FM radio works very well - great sound quality. Other audio has good sound quality too, loud enough volume with ear phones and outer speaker can get pretty loud, too. Face recognition very fast and convenient - however, some web sites say that it is not too secure but it is secure enough for me (I don't believe I'm a target of North Korean hackers, and I don't keep sensitive/important info on it). Fingerprint reader is finicky and hard to use - it takes many attempts for it to read the fingerprint properly. But it often is functional.

Fit/finish/quality is pretty good. Glass surface has a very smooth, slick feel. It comes with a cheap case but it is very useful and I'm glad I have it. The back is very slippery and also the case protects the back-facing cameras from getting scratched. There is one pop-out tray that holds that has two open positions - it holds the sim card and can hold a second sim card or an SD memory card. That tray is a bit fragile and should be handled with utmost care - improperly ejecting or inserting it could bend it and cause a serious problem. Whenever I have to do something with that tray I make sure to work in a quiet place with a clean tabletop and take my time. I would expect the top-priced phones to have higher quality for that sort of thing. I accept the fragility of that tray on this phone as a trade-off for the low cost (I paid $260 including tax and shipping).

Battery use is good. With moderate use I could probably go 2 days without recharging.

Negative aspects or things needing improvement
* Tray for sim and SD cards fragile (as I said above).
* Just 3 buttons - volume up, volume down, power. They are all located next to each other. Often inadvertently hitting power button and waking up or putting to sleep the phone. Would be better if the volume buttons were on the other side.
* No physical "home" button. There is a home button but it is a software button so only functions when phone is on and unlocked. I accept this as the trade off for a lower priced phone, but still would be nice to have.
* No ear phone jack. There is a USB C jack and the phone comes with a USB C to earphone jack adapter, so can use regular wired earphones. Also, can use bluetooth earphones. I have tested and it works well both ways.
* Can't remove battery.
* Would prefer a little smaller and lighter for pocket carrying, but is not too bad.

It's a nice phone. I hope it has good longevity and durability. We shall see.

title: Don't Expect Tracfone to Honor the Warranty on this Phone
text:
I purchased this phone through Tracfone about 6 months ago. The wifi reception has never been great, but recently started to fail altogether. I called Tracfone to have them replace the phone, since it's under warranty for a year. They refused to replace it (I talked to three agents, escalating until I could escalate no more). They will only replace a phone if it can't make or receive calls, but other features of the phone (camera, wifi, etc.) may break and they won't act in these cases. The warranty doesn't make any exceptions, but Tracfone knows that they can get away with this, that one little customer isn't going to be able to sue them or prosecute. So, this is my small way of saying "buyer beware." Once I use up my minutes (just bought 1000), I'm done with Tracfone. I can't support a company that won't keep their word, that won't abide by their own warranty.

If you do stick with Tracfone, buy a better used phone with better features than this one. It will have more processing power and a better screen. Tracfone now lets you bring your own device [...]. But, their customer service is so horrible, I'm still not staying. Another example: it took 3 days to port my phone number on one Tracfone phone to another. This isn't a port from one provider to another, but one *Tracfone* phone to another Tracphone phone. Talking to their agents is like talking to a robot. They literally read their script, even when you ask them questions. Maddening.

title: Dissapointing battery life and software performance
text:
As a management consultant who travels almost weekly, I was eagerly looking forward to having mobile email and internet and urged by my wife to get this phone when it came out. However, after nearly two years with this phone, I can't wait for my contract to be up. As an early adopter of the T-mobile G1, I have definitely felt all the downsides of a first generation product.

Pros
- Physical keyboard is handy for texting and surfing the web.
- GPS and turn-by-turn navigation is free and helpful.
- Phone has good integration with Google email, calendar and other apps.

Cons:
- Everything (startup time, apps, navigation, camera) on this phone is extremely sloooooow.
- Software is buggy and phone shuts down unexpectedly at times.
- Battery life is abysmal, the worst on any phone ever. You will need to charge several times per day, particularly if you use Bluetooth or surf the web.
- Syncing of music and other files is primitive compared to iphone/ipod and itunes.
- Lack of standard headphone jack is really annoying when traveling (and you want to listen to music and charge the phone at the same time).

I have a long-time friend who I met recently after many months and lo and behold he had only recently gotten his first smart phone, also a T-mobile G1, and it had even worse problems than mine. After asking him what he was thinking (he definitely should have asked me for my opinion!), I told him to make sure the software was at least up-to-date and that I wished him luck. My friend has a pretty laid-back lifestyle so he likes to crack jokes about the phone matching his pace. He is also more likely to see the phone's flaws as endearing "idiosyncrasies".

I still have a few months left on my contract but given how slow and buggy this phone is, I took out the SIM card and put it in one of the T-mobile "to-go" phones from Walmart. I am paying an extra $25 per month for the G1 service, but anything at this point is better than using this phone.

Recommendation: Don't Buy! Get a smartphone that works or a regular phone and 3G ipad (for mobile email and internet).

title: Most powerful phone on the market right now.
text:
This phone is incredible.

The 120hz display at 1440p looks amazing. Some will complain it's not AMOLED but to me that's extremely petty.

The stereo speakers sound great. With Dolby Atmos activated and a good pair of headphones everything sounds spectacular.

Huge battery, 4000mAh. Even my last phone with a fresh charge and fresh battery didn't compare to this.

Snapdragon 835 and 8GB of RAM. I ran benchmarks on this phone and it outperforms the Samsung Galaxy Note 8 and LG V30. That makes me feel good because I care not for either of those companies.

People will complain about it not having a 3.5mm audio jack for headphones. Razer opted out on it to add 500 more mAh to the battery. It comes with a USB Type-C adapter with a 3.5mm audio jack that essentially only adds 4 inches of length to your headphone cable. This is a non-problem that babies will still complain about.

No bloatware. Hate it when major companies decide what I should have on my phone so this was a nice change of pace for once.

Camera software could use some work, but again this is a non-problem. I bought a camera app for $4 that improves it A LOT. If $4 is too much to spend after blowing $700+ on a phone then I don't know what to tell you. Some will say for $700 it should come with good camera software. I agree, but an extra $4 is really nitpicky.

Fingerprint reader is snappy and accurate. Instead of some lame circle on the back of the phone it's conveniently placed on the right side of the phone.

I've seen complaints that the volume buttons are too low, but don't understand why. Considering the size of this phone and the average size of human hands the buttons are placed just fine.

I can't think of anything bad to say about this phone. It's really a great piece of tech for a reasonable price.

title: Another IPhone killer!
text:
The decline of the Apple empire. This phone is one of the reason why I will not overpaying for an IPhone. The spec is fantastic, 6G ram + 128 G memory! Are you kidding...... that is at least a $500 - 600 phone in the market place, new IPhone and Samsung will set you back twice at $1100 +.

1. Be careful of the out of box fragile screen protector, I peeled it on first day out of curiosity and cracked it.
2. NFC - none. Not required as a purchase decision for me. May be needed in a couple of years.
3. Wifi calling - none. Would be nice. Need to step into live zones, could be a positive if you need a bit of privacy to make such calls.
4. Cameras - NICE!
5. Speaker - suffice.
6. Battery life - leaves me enough juice to last a 24 hour cycle.
7. Charging - fast! Let me go thru a busy day.
8. Used a One Plus for 2 years before buying this one. Yes, 2 years is what you would expect any electronic equipment to be upgraded. Depreciation on a new I Phone is more than the VIVO XI cost.
9. DUAL SIM - wow. Switching phone numbers is a breeze. Companies should consider this phone for employees work/personal equipment. No more carrying 2 phones.
10. Get ready for a lot of questions from stranger asking about "BLU", then chat about the spec.
11. REPEAT - 128 G of memory........ !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! That is a ton load of pics!
12. Missed the Black Friday sale, Super deal at around $259.00. See if I can wait that long to get another for my wife.
13. Excited about the upcoming Android operating system upgrade.

title: A fantastic unlocked Android phone
text:
I am very impressed with this phone. For the price, you think you would think you would be sacrificing a lot of features, but you would be wrong. You get a lovely 5.7" inch display with an integrated speaker at the bottom, rugged construction, a fingerprint reader, NFC support, multiple cameras (including infrared), dual SIM support, SD card expansion, and stock Android 11.

The calling quality is great, and with dual SIM support you won't have to carry an extra device if you use two numbers. Stock Android is a dream because it has no bloat. You can put exactly what you want on it and you don't have to worry that unremovable bloat is taking up space you need.

The rugged construction is amazing. Your phone is well protected and you won't have to bother with putting a case on it as it is well protected against drops and spills. It has facial recognition in addition to fingerprint login so you have two ways of password-free security. NFC means things like Google Pay will work. It has USB-C charging for fast charge and also for connecting the phone to portable monitors to extend or enlarge the display.

You get 4GB of RAM and 64GB of built-in storage plus support for SD cards so you will have room for almost any app you want. The camera has all the bells and whistles like infrared and macro support. All for under $200. If you want an advanced Android phone but don't want to pay upwards of $1000 for it then I would highly recommend this phone. Oh, and it is unlocked, so you can use it with any GSM provider. I can't say enough good things about it!

The old phone was a touch screen which I really DISLIKED, so with much research I decided on this "alcatel" because I am 83 and my hands are not so steady anymore.  Had Verizon set it up for me yesterday and today I can't even figure out how to make a call let alone check for messages.  It is so difficult that if I did not need a phone, I would send it back for a refund.  I would send a picture but that is way beyond me let alone how to send it.  I have just printed out the online "user's manual" which I am not sure I am going to make any sense of but I've got to try.  Through all this - don't get me wrong - I don't know if the "alcatel" is worse than any other cell phone.  I would  just like a phone where I could make and answer calls. PERIOD.  That is all I do and all I need.  Why does everything have to be so complex???  I'M NOT - Why does my phone have to be?  All right - enough already.  I don't think I belong in this world anymore.  My rent paid up - I think it might be time to check out.  See you later.  cdw

title: This a great phone!
text:
I was first attracted and taken back when looking at the inexpensive purchase price. I admit my expectations were low and anticipated disappointment, but as my 5 star rating attests, I was not! I swapped from my Samsung S3 with little effort. The change from the Android 4 system to the newer Android 5, took some mental adjustment.
I admit I do not use this smartphone non-stop during the day, but the battery life is quite fantastic. I did not charge this phone for almost three days. For the smart phones I am familiar with, that’s wonderful.
I noted some feedback from other customers worried about the smaller amount of internal memory, but for the applications I run, I have no trouble. The phone seems to run well and effortlessly. To the everyday individual who uses their phone for normal day in and day out activities, including streaming video, I highly recommend this phone.
I’m replacing my Samsung because I dropped it off a moving golf cart onto a gravel surface. Needless to say, the phone did not fare well! To my delight, industry continues to bring more and more choices to us consumers and we will continue to see competition bring lower prices.

title: Otherwise Great Phone
text:
I came to this phone from an iPhone, so I had to temper my expectations. I'm not a heavy texter or talker, and just wanted to move to a basic phone for ~10 texts per day. I like the Qwerty keyboard and the menu layouts, everything's easy to figure out.

Single CON: But battery life is HORRID. I'm getting less than 24 hours of battery on a full charge, with 5-15 texts sent/received and 25 minutes total talk time. That's pitiful for a basic featured phone. Previous experiences with basic phones would give me a few days between charges at least, not 18-19 hours.

title: Bad phone and bad company
text: I would give this company a "zero" if possible. I have a family plan with four lines.  I am repeatedly billed for calls I never made. The first time I called them, they told me they couldn't do anything about it! Two of the four phones we use are absolute crap.  They have already charged my $150.00 to replace the v220 that I had recieved for "free." No wonder Consumer Reports ranks them at the bottom of service and quality.  I regret having chosen this company but am unfortunately stuck with them for another 18 months. I will never come back to this company again. Pick another phone and another company.

title: Stay Away.
text:
I bought two of these phones, one for me and my niece, My niece's phone started moving super slow and then the battery wouldn't charge after three months. She had to buy a new one. And mine didn't even last 8 months and now I have a Ghost Screen. it mirrors all my apps and I can't use it for anything but to make a call. Don't buy these phones you will regret it.

Update I sent one phone in I had to pay 12$ to mail it to get fixed, I only sent one phone because the other ones warranty ran out. The screen pixels were gone on this phone, I got the phone back fast, But now all my apps, and tabs, disappear every time I click on them, I have to reset the phone for them to all show again on the phone. and it took about an hour before my phone would start charging after I plugged it in. So I learned my lesson I bought two of these. Now its time to save up for real phones.

title: Why do people pay for iPhone and Galaxy?
text:
I bought an $80 BLU Studio C3 Super Camera a couple of years ago to replace my Galaxy 4, and I was super impressed with that cheap phone's performance against the much more costly Samsung. But after a couple of years, my first BLU was having performance issues, so I researched and got this new baby. It was on the higher price point since I paid around $350, but I really don't regret it.

First of all, it comes with great accessories. The phone is absolutely gorgeous quality, and the fingerprint sensor is great. I put in a card and memory seems almost endless! The only problem I have is getting my HP laptop to recognize it via the HDMI charger cable, but I got a Bluetooth adapter for my computer to resolve that.

This is a fast phone with excellent performance and good (not great) cameras. Let's be honest, if you are serious about photography, you need to buy a camera, not just depend on your cellphone. But this certainly takes beautiful photos. All my photos on my @40rtyPluss Instagram account were taken on this or on my original BLU.

So far no complaints.
